leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: Chapter 10 provides the general criteria for designing the means of egress established as the primary method for protection of people in buildings by allowing timely relocation or evacuation of building occupants. Both prescriptive and performance language is utilized in this chapter to provide for a basic approach in the determination of a safe exiting system for all occupancies. It addresses all portions of the egress system (exit access, exits and exit discharge) and includes design requirements as well as provisions regulating individual components. The requirements detail the size, arrangement, number and protection of means of egress components. Functional and operational characteristics that will permit the safe use of components without special knowledge or effort are specified.
The means of egress protection requirements work in coordination with other sections of the code, such as protection of vertical openings (see Chapter 7), interior finish (see Chapter 8), fire suppression and detection systems (see Chapter 9) and numerous others, all having an impact on life safety. Chapter 10 is subdivided into four main sections: general (Sections 1003—1015), exit access (Sections 1016—1021), exit (Sections 1022—1027) and exit discharge (Sections 1028—1029). Special allowances for the unique requirements for assembly spaces (Section 1030) and emergency escape and rescue openings (Section 1031) complete the chapter. Chapter 10 of this code is duplicated in Chapter 10 the International Fire Code®; however, the International Fire Code contains one additional section on maintenance of the means of egress system in existing buildings.

children.body: Buildings or portions thereof shall be provided with a means of egress system as required by this chapter. The provisions of this chapter shall control the design, construction and arrangement of means of egress components required to provide an approved means of egress from structures and portions thereof.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Basic Components
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Commentary:

The building code requires that a complete means of egress consist of three distinct parts: exit access, exit, and exit discharge. Exit access provides a clear and direct path to exits. An example is a corridor system. Exits are part of the building that provide a higher level of protection than the exit access. Examples include interior exit stairways and exit passageways. Exits then lead to the exit discharge.

The exit discharge provides a path of travel to the public way or safe dispersal area. While this looks straightforward in plan view, the interpretation and implementation can pose challenges when it's considered in three dimensions. Without reviewing site grading, what was budgeted as a sidewalk turns into an expensive stair and ramp combination.

The code defines a public way as at least 10 feet wide and open to the sky, but does not offer a prescriptive definition for safe dispersal areas—leaving it to the AHJ (Authority Having Jurisdiction) to determine what is acceptable. Designers must ensure that such areas are not only at least 50 feet away (per Section 1028) but also provide sufficient space for the expected occupant load, with at least 5 square feet per person.

It is critical to coordinate with landscape and civil disciplines early, since site grading, fencing, and even planting can unintentionally block or reduce the required egress path width.

children.body: It shall be unlawful to alter a building or structure in a manner that will reduce the number of exits or the minimum width or required capacity of the means of egress to less than required by this code.

diagrams.title: Egress: Min. Reqs., Existing Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1001.2 is to ensure that the means of egress in an existing building are not altered beyond what the code considers safe. It requires that the number of required exits is not reduced below the code required minimum for any area, space or building. It also requires that the means of egress width and capacity of the various means of egress elements that comprise the system are not reduced below the code required minimum and would apply to all required elements of the means of egress.

children.body: Means of egress shall be maintained in accordance with the International Fire Code.

Fire safety and evacuation plans shall be provided for all occupancies and buildings where required by the International Fire Code. Such fire safety and evacuation plans shall comply with the applicable provisions of Sections 401.2 and 404 of the International Fire Code.

diagrams.title: Projections in Nursing Home Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 occupancies, as long as the corridor width is not less than 96", furniture is allowed to project into the corridor as long as the furniture is attached to the floor or wall, does not reduce the clear width to less than 72", is positioned on only one side of the corridor, does not exceed 50 sq. ft. in area, is separated from other furniture pieces by 10' minimum and it is considered as part of the dire and safety plans in accordance with Section 1002.2.

diagrams.title: Lockdown Plans: Table of Contents
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Code Section 404 - Section 1002.2 of the Building Code states that fire safety and evacuation plans are to be in place and approved by the AHJ for those occupancies where the Fire Code requires them. The occupancies that require these plans are listed in Section 403, with each occupancy type having specific guidelines for their plan creation. Section 404 of the Fire Code defines and outlines the contents of three specific types of plans: fire evacuation (404.2.1), fire safety (404.2.2), and lockdown plans (404.2.3). Each of these plans may have overlapping and interconnecting sections. The fire evacuation plans focus on how and where to move people in case of a fire in each part of a building. The fire safety plan covers actions to be taken in case of fire, fire prevention and maintenance of equipment, and refers to evacuation plan for people movement in case of fire. Lockdown plans cover the threats and hazards, initiation, and termination of lockdown procedures and conditions.

children.body: The general requirements specified in Sections 1003 through 1015 shall apply to all three elements of the means of egress system, in addition to those specific requirements for the exit access, the exit and the exit discharge detailed elsewhere in this chapter.

diagrams.title: Elevators, Escalators or Moving Walks in Means of Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because mechanical devices are prone to failure due to loss of power in an emergency situation Section 1003.7 does not permit them to be used as a required means of egress. This Section only applies to Elevators, escalators and moving walks. There is a special exception for where an elevator needs to be used to provide an accessible means of egress and requires the elevator to comply with section 1009.4. Section 1009.4 requires stand-by power may require an areas of refuge.

diagrams.title: Exit Access, Exit and Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines exit, exit access and exit discharge as the following:

Exit Access: That portion of a means of egress system that leads from any occupied portion of a building or structure to an exit.

Exit: That portion of a means of egress system between the exit access and the exit discharge or public way. Exit components include exterior exit doors at the level of exit discharge, interior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, exterior exit stairways and ramps and horizontal exits.

Exit Discharge: That portion of a means of egress system between the termination of an exit and a public way.

children.body:
The means of egress shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet 6 inches (2286 mm) above the finished floor.
Exceptions:
  1. Sloped ceilings in accordance with Section 1208.2.
  2. Ceilings of dwelling units and sleeping units within residential occupancies in accordance with Section 1208.2.
  3. Allowable projections in accordance with Section 1003.3.
  4. Stair headroom in accordance with Section 1011.3.
  5. Door height in accordance with Section 1010.1.1.
  6. Ramp headroom in accordance with Section 1012.5.2.
  7. The clear height of floor levels in vehicular and pedestrian traffic areas of public and private parking garages in accordance with Section 406.2.2.
  8. Areas above and below mezzanine floors in accordance with Section 505.2.

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom and Vert. Rise
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

In addition, stairways that are too long could be dangerous from falls, or could be too physically taxing for those not able to sustain the effort to traverse a long stairway. Therefore, stair runs are limited to 12 feet in vertical rise.

children.body: Protruding objects on circulation paths shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1003.3.1 through 1003.3.4.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Recessed Objects
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Some objects are necessary, or even required by code, such as drinking fountains, that can create a non-compliant protruding object situation. One remedy would be to recess the object in a pocket in the wall, such as along a corridor. Care must be taken to provide proper knee space, width for wheelchair use and to not restrict the adjacent accessible route to less than the minimum required at that location.

diagrams.title: Protruding Object Limits
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Various items that might be considered protruding objects could include diagonal structural brace frame elements, overhanging stair landings, architectural features, wall mounted objects and signs among others. If items such as planters or other objects are used to provide cane detection, consideration should be given to the permanence or possible future moving (for items like furniture) or maintenance of the object (like planters). If the item that is provided to provide cane detection is moved, a violation of the requirement would occur.

ADA Advisory 307.2 Protrusion Limits. When a cane is used and the element is in the detectable range, it gives a person sufficient time to detect the element with the cane before there is body contact. Elements located on circulation paths, including operable elements, must comply with requirements for protruding objects. For example, awnings and their supporting structures cannot reduce the minimum required vertical clearance. Similarly, casement windows, when open, cannot encroach more than 4 inches into circulation paths above 27 inches.

children.body:
Protruding objects are permitted to extend below the minimum ceiling height required by Section 1003.2 where a minimum headroom of 80 inches (2032 mm) is provided over any circulation paths, including walks, corridors, aisles and passageways. Not more than 50 percent of the ceiling area of a means of egress shall be reduced in height by protruding objects.
Exception: Door closers, overhead doorstops, frame stops, power door operators and electromagnetic door locks shall be permitted to project into the door opening height not lower than 78 inches (1980 mm) above the floor.
A barrier shall be provided where the vertical clearance above a circulation path is less than 80 inches (2032 mm) high above the finished floor. The leading edge of such a barrier shall be located 27 inches (686 mm) maximum above the finished floor.

diagrams.title: Protruding Objects: Headroom
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because circulation paths, walks, corridors, aisles, and passageways are used for egress and egress access, the code limits the minimum ceiling height to stop smoke and other contaminants from preventing safe egress in the event of an emergency. Section 1003.3.1 ensures that any protruding objects do not lower the ceiling to a point that makes the building egress unreasonably safe. Over areas required for the means of egress protruding objects may reduce the ceiling height to 80" minimum. The aggregate area of protruding objects over a means of egress cannot exceed 50% of the ceiling area of the means of egress. Protruding objects not over the required egress width may be less than 80" when provided with a barrier, often referred to as cane detection. The barrier cannot exceed a height of 27". The code does provide an exception for door stops and closers which may not be less than 78" above the floor.

children.body:
A free-standing object mounted on a post or pylon shall not overhang that post or pylon more than 4 inches (102 mm) where the lowest point of the leading edge is more than 27 inches (686 mm) and less than 80 inches (2032 mm) above the finished floor. Where a sign or other obstruction is mounted between posts or pylons and the clear distance between the posts or pylons is greater than 12 inches (305 mm), the lowest edge of such sign or obstruction shall be 27 inches (686 mm) maximum or 80 inches (2032 mm) minimum above the finished floor or ground.
Exception: These requirements shall not apply to sloping portions of handrails between the top and bottom riser of stairs and above the ramp run.

Objects with leading edges more than 27 inches (685 mm) and not more than 80 inches (2030 mm) above the finished floor shall not project horizontally more than 4 inches (102 mm) into the circulation path.
Exception: Handrails are permitted to protrude 41/2 inches (114 mm) from the wall or guard.

diagrams.title: Recessed Objects
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Some objects are necessary, or even required by code, such as drinking fountains, that can create a non-compliant protruding object situation. One remedy would be to recess the object in a pocket in the wall, such as along a corridor. Care must be taken to provide proper knee space, width for wheelchair use and to not restrict the adjacent accessible route to less than the minimum required at that location.

diagrams.title: Stairs Horizontal Encroachments
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Generally, projections of more than 4" are not allowed into the circulation path. This doesn't include the 48" clear width between handrails for stairways used as an accessible means of egress.

The allowance for a 1-1/2" projection into the required width for trim or other non-structural projection at the base would not include structural items such as stringers for steel pan-tread type stairways. The minimum required stair width would have to be accommodated for between the structural items in that condition.

children.body: Protruding objects shall not reduce the minimum clear width of accessible routes.

children.body: Circulation paths of the means of egress shall have a slip-resistant surface and be securely attached.

diagrams.title: Slip-Resistant Surfaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: While there does not appear to be a building code definition of "slip-resistant", or "securely attached", care should be taken to make sure that aspects of means of egress are safe for use in the event the floor is wet for various reasons, and tripping hazards from loose mats are not in the means of egress.

children.body:
Where changes in elevation of less than 12 inches (305 mm) exist in the means of egress, sloped surfaces shall be used. Where the slope is greater than one unit vertical in 20 units horizontal (5-percent slope), ramps complying with Section 1012 shall be used. Where the difference in elevation is 6 inches (152 mm) or less, the ramp shall be equipped with either handrails or floor finish materials that contrast with adjacent floor finish materials.
Exceptions:
  1. Steps at exterior doors complying with Section 1010.1.4.
  2. A stair with a single riser or with two risers and a tread is permitted at locations not required to be accessible by Chapter 11 where the risers and treads comply with Section 1011.5, the minimum depth of the tread is 13 inches (330 mm) and not less than one handrail complying with Section 1014 is provided within 30 inches (762 mm) of the centerline of the normal path of egress travel on the stair.
  3. A step is permitted in aisles serving seating that has a difference in elevation less than 12 inches (305 mm) at locations not required to be accessible by Chapter 11, provided that the risers and treads comply with Section 1030.14 and the aisle is provided with a handrail complying with Section 1030.16.
Throughout a story in a Group I-2 occupancy, any change in elevation in portions of the means of egress that serve nonambulatory persons shall be by means of a ramp or sloped walkway.

The path of egress travel along a means of egress shall not be interrupted by a building element other than a means of egress component as specified in this chapter. Obstructions shall not be placed in the minimum width or required capacity of a means of egress component except projections permitted by this chapter. The minimum width or required capacity of a means of egress system shall not be diminished along the path of egress travel.

Elevators, escalators and moving walks shall not be used as a component of a required means of egress from any other part of the building.
Exception: Elevators used as an accessible means of egress in accordance with Section 1009.4.

diagrams.title: Escalator Openings (New Const.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To protect occupants on the floor above from fire and smoke passing through escalator floor openings the code limits the size of the floor opening for an escalator to twice the projected area of the escalator. The code requires a draft curtain to limit smoke's ability to migrate up to the floor above. To prevent a fire from spreading through the escalator opening closely spaced sprinklers are required around the opening. Escalator floor openings may not connect more than 4 stories except in Group B and M occupancies.

diagrams.title: Elevators, Escalators or Moving Walks in Means of Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because mechanical devices are prone to failure due to loss of power in an emergency situation Section 1003.7 does not permit them to be used as a required means of egress. This Section only applies to Elevators, escalators and moving walks. There is a special exception for where an elevator needs to be used to provide an accessible means of egress and requires the elevator to comply with section 1009.4. Section 1009.4 requires stand-by power may require an areas of refuge.

diagrams.title: Occupant Loads: Outdoor Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1004.7 is to ensure that Outdoor Areas have adequate means for emergency evacuation. It gives the building official the authority to determine the occupant load for outdoor areas. It establishes that the Means of Egress for Outdoor Areas be established per the requirements of Chapter 10 of the building code, the same requirements as any other room or space. It provides exceptions for outdoor areas used exclusively for servicing the building and outdoor areas serving R-3 buildings and R-2 dwelling units.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Gallery
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When designing a building with floors that contain rooms or areas dedicated to different functions, it's essential to calculate the design occupant load for each area independently, as specified in section 1004.3. The occupant load factor (OLF) for each specific function is determined by Table 1004.5. Architects and engineers must differentiate between net and gross floor areas in their calculations. Net floor area excludes unoccupied accessory spaces such as corridors, stairs, ramps, restrooms, and closets, while gross floor area encompasses these accessory spaces.

The design process involves categorizing various areas according to their function within the building. To calculate the occupant load, divide the area (whether net or gross) of each function by its corresponding OLF from Table 1004.5, then sum the occupant loads for all functions. Designers may encounter scenarios where a space's function doesn't directly match any listed in the table. In such cases, it's necessary to choose the function that most closely aligns with the intended use of the space. For instance, an art gallery with common workshop areas for activities like framing paintings, or more production-like activities like welding and other fabrication processes could classify these workshops under an industrial area, as it most closely resembles the activities' nature, according to Table 1004.5.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Small Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Restaurant, Non-Sprinklered

UpCodes Note: Restroom/Corridor is not normally occupied area, and major use is assembly (seating), based on "net area". Restroom/Corridor area is excluded from occupant load calculation.

The determination of occupant loads and occupancy groups are independent. Even though the occupancy group for a small assembly area may be a Group B occupancy group, the occupant load factor for "Assembly: Without Tables and Chairs" would be used if the space functions in that way. The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the space level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

When adding additional occupant loads, be sure and verify with other code requirements, such as accessibility, exit discharge and also separate bathroom requirements, are not violated. In this instance, increasing the occupant load to larger than what is allowed for a single user restroom could require an additional restroom be added, making the proposed addition problematic. In cases such as this, close working with the Building Official and consideration of the Existing Building code requirements should be considered to determine if an additional bathroom should be added.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The room or space that a mezzanine exits through is considered to be a catchment space where the occupant load of both are accumulated before the exiting from the main space is calculated for width and number of exits.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a building is comprised of multiple occupancies, the means of egress serving each occupancy shall apply to that portion of the building for which it is provided.

Example 1: in a building that is part B occupancy and part H-4 occupancy where each is provided it's own exit corridor, the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the B occupancy need not be rated and the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the H-4 occupancy is required to have a 1-hour fire resistance (per Table 1020.1). When a means of egress component is utilized or shared by two or more occupancies the component shall be required to meet the most stringent requirements of the occupancies served.

Example 2: in a mixed use building where a B occupancy and an H-4 occupancy share an exit corridor the exit corridor must have a 1-hour fire resistance rating as that (as we know from Example 1) is the most stringent corridor requirement of the uses that will share the corridor. The applicable requirements apply to the entire component, not just the walls or elements adjacent to each occupancy, i.e. both sides of the corridor for the entire length in the example would be required to meet the requirements for 1-hour fire resistant construction for it to be shared by both a B and H-4 occupancy.

diagrams.title: Gross Area Calc.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Calculating the gross floor area is essential for understanding various aspects of a building, including occupant load and fire safety requirements. In the building code, the gross floor area is determined as the area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts (Building Code Section 202). For areas without surrounding walls, they are included in the gross floor area if they fall within the horizontal projection of a roof or floor above. Next, sum the results of all areas calculated for each floor together to get the total gross floor area.

diagrams.title: Example: OL, Exits and Common Path of Travel
Occupant Load: Multiple Function Spaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category A-2, Restaurant with Commercial Kitchen, Sprinklered
Restaurant space has multiple assembly functions with different ways to calculate occupant loads such as net area, length of seating, and fixed seats. Each individual use area within a common space is required to be accounted for in the calculation.

UpCodes Note: Restroom/Corridor is a not normally occupied area, and major use is assembly (seating), based on "net area". Restroom/Corridor area is excluded from occupant load calculation.

The building code does not explicitly address whether to round occupant loads up at the space or room level. However, section 1004.5 does say "For areas without fixed seating, the occupant load shall be not less than that number determined...". So whether rounding at the before or after the occupant loads are added together, care must be taken to not have an occupant load lower than calculated from the OLF. Rounding down is discouraged as it would most likely violate this requirement. Rounding up at the space level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding. It usually will not make a practical difference unless it is near a threshold which can require an added exit, exit access or additional toilets.

diagrams.title: Gross vs. Net Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
BUILDING CODE DEFINITION
Floor Area, Gross: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the exterior walls of the building under consideration, exclusive of vent shafts and courts, without deduction for corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, the thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. The floor area of a building, or portion thereof, not provided with surrounding exterior walls shall be the usable area under the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above. The gross floor area shall not include shafts with no openings or interior courts.

Area, Building: The area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the building area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.

Floor Area, Net: The actual occupied area not including unoccupied accessory areas such as corridors, stairways, ramps, toilet rooms, mechanical rooms and closets.

The 2014 NYC Building Code further explicitly excludes wall thicknesses, columns, fixed cabinets, equipment and furred-in spaces. Other codes do not explicitly address these items in the definition of Net Floor Area.

NFPA 1 and NFPA 101 DEFINITION
Gross Floor Area: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the outside walls of the building under consideration with no deduction for hallways, stairs, closets, thickness of interior walls, columns, elevator and building services shafts, or other features, but excluding floor openings associated with atriums and communicating spaces.

Net Floor Area: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the outside walls, or the outside walls and fire walls of the building, or outside and/or inside walls that bound an occupancy or incidental use area requiring the occupant load to be calculated using net floor area under consideration with deductions for hallways, stairs, closets, thickness of interior walls, columns, or other features.

Both Gross and Net area is used for occupant load calculations depending the function of the space chosen in Table 1004.5. Although effectively the same, the Building Area used for allowable building area calculations found in Chapter 5 has a unique definition, "Area, Building", in Chapter 2.

children.body: In determining means of egress requirements, the number of occupants for whom means of egress facilities are provided shall be determined in accordance with this section.

diagrams.title: Single Exits: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Single exits are permitted to serve multiple occupancies and multiple stories provided a number of additional limitations are met by the design. For a single exit, exit access stairway or ramp to serve a story with multiple occupancies each occupancy in and of itself must meet the requirements of Table 1006.3.3(1) or Table 1006.3.3(2). In addition where a single exit serves a story or multiple stories the sum of the ratios for each occupancy of the design occupant load divided by the allowable occupant load from Table 1006.3.3(2) for each story served by the exit must not exceed 1. When dwelling units are on a floor, the ratio used for dwelling units in the summation is the number of dwelling units divided by 4.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Even though the restroom and corridor is not normally occupied area, the major use is Mercantile. For mall structures the occupant load for the entire Mall is determined by Figure 7.3.1.2(a) and Figure 7.3.1.2(b) and is based on the size of the mall.

children.body: Where the path of egress travel includes intervening rooms, areas or spaces, cumulative occupant loads shall be determined in accordance with this section.

Where occupants egress from one or more rooms, areas or spaces through others, the design occupant load shall be the combined occupant load of interconnected accessory or intervening spaces. Design of egress path capacity shall be based on the cumulative portion of occupant loads of all rooms, areas or spaces to that point along the path of egress travel.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

children.body: That portion of the occupant load of a mezzanine with required egress through a room, area or space on an adjacent level shall be added to the occupant load of that room, area or space.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The room or space that a mezzanine exits through is considered to be a catchment space where the occupant load of both are accumulated before the exiting from the main space is calculated for width and number of exits.

children.body: Other than for the egress components designed for convergence in accordance with Section 1005.6, the occupant load from separate stories shall not be added.

Where an area under consideration contains multiple functions having different occupant load factors, the design occupant load for such area shall be based on the floor area of each function calculated independently.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Gallery
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When designing a building with floors that contain rooms or areas dedicated to different functions, it's essential to calculate the design occupant load for each area independently, as specified in section 1004.3. The occupant load factor (OLF) for each specific function is determined by Table 1004.5. Architects and engineers must differentiate between net and gross floor areas in their calculations. Net floor area excludes unoccupied accessory spaces such as corridors, stairs, ramps, restrooms, and closets, while gross floor area encompasses these accessory spaces.

The design process involves categorizing various areas according to their function within the building. To calculate the occupant load, divide the area (whether net or gross) of each function by its corresponding OLF from Table 1004.5, then sum the occupant loads for all functions. Designers may encounter scenarios where a space's function doesn't directly match any listed in the table. In such cases, it's necessary to choose the function that most closely aligns with the intended use of the space. For instance, an art gallery with common workshop areas for activities like framing paintings, or more production-like activities like welding and other fabrication processes could classify these workshops under an industrial area, as it most closely resembles the activities' nature, according to Table 1004.5.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category A-2, Restaurant with Commercial Kitchen, Sprinklered
Restaurant space has multiple assembly functions with different ways to calculate occupant loads such as net area, length of seating, and fixed seats. Each individual use area within a common space is required to be accounted for in the calculation.

UpCodes Note: Restroom/Corridor is a not normally occupied area, and major use is assembly (seating), based on "net area". Restroom/Corridor area is excluded from occupant load calculation.

The building code does not explicitly address whether to round occupant loads up at the space or room level. However, section 1004.5 does say "For areas without fixed seating, the occupant load shall be not less than that number determined...". So whether rounding at the before or after the occupant loads are added together, care must be taken to not have an occupant load lower than calculated from the OLF. Rounding down is discouraged as it would most likely violate this requirement. Rounding up at the space level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding. It usually will not make a practical difference unless it is near a threshold which can require an added exit, exit access or additional toilets.

children.body: Where a building contains two or more occupancies, the means of egress requirements shall apply to each portion of the building based on the occupancy of that space. Where two or more occupancies utilize portions of the same means of egress system, those egress components shall meet the more stringent requirements of all occupancies that are served.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a building is comprised of multiple occupancies, the means of egress serving each occupancy shall apply to that portion of the building for which it is provided.

Example 1: in a building that is part B occupancy and part H-4 occupancy where each is provided it's own exit corridor, the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the B occupancy need not be rated and the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the H-4 occupancy is required to have a 1-hour fire resistance (per Table 1020.1). When a means of egress component is utilized or shared by two or more occupancies the component shall be required to meet the most stringent requirements of the occupancies served.

Example 2: in a mixed use building where a B occupancy and an H-4 occupancy share an exit corridor the exit corridor must have a 1-hour fire resistance rating as that (as we know from Example 1) is the most stringent corridor requirement of the uses that will share the corridor. The applicable requirements apply to the entire component, not just the walls or elements adjacent to each occupancy, i.e. both sides of the corridor for the entire length in the example would be required to meet the requirements for 1-hour fire resistant construction for it to be shared by both a B and H-4 occupancy.

diagrams.title: Assembly + Educational: Simultaneous Egress Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where egress of an auditorium or gymnasium utilizes the same exits serving other parts of the building, the exiting capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the combined occupant load of both uses. Where the authority having jurisdiction agrees that the assembly space will only be utilized by the same occupants as the rest of the building and therefore, simultaneous occupancy will not occur, the egress capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the assembly space or the rest of the building whichever exit capacity is greater.

diagrams.title: Assembly + Educational: Non-Simultaneous  Egress Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where egress of an auditorium or gymnasium utilizes the same exits serving other parts of the building, the exiting capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the combined occupant load of both uses. Where the authority having jurisdiction agrees that the assembly space will only be utilized by the same occupants as the rest of the building and therefore, simultaneous occupancy will not occur, the egress capacity shall be sufficient to accommodate the assembly space or the rest of the building whichever exit capacity is greater.

The number of occupants shall be computed at the rate of one occupant per unit of area as prescribed in Table 1004.5. For areas without fixed seating, the occupant load shall be not less than that number determined by dividing the floor area under consideration by the occupant load factor assigned to the function of the space as set forth in Table 1004.5. Single-Occupancy Category B, Restaurant, Non-Sprinklered

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For floors utilizing stairs as a means of egress the minimum required combined width of the stairs is determined by multiplying the occupant load for the floor served by the egress capacity factor of 0.3". Egress stairs must be built in accordance with Section 1011, which requires a 44" minimum stair width. Exceptions apply for buildings protected throughout by an automatic sprinkler system and protected by an EVACS system, for smoke-protected assembly seating, and for open air assembly seating.

If one stair is becomes no longer available for service, then the remaining stairs are required to provide at least 50% of the required capacity or width.

diagrams.title: Concentrated Business Use (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Occupant loads are determined by dividing the square footage of a space by the occupant load factor, for the use of the space, as shown in this table. This example shows a business occupancy. To account for the total occupant load each space must be calculated on its intended use. In the example the business occupancy is further separated into concentrated business use, assembly spaces, and collaboration spaces. The occupant load factor, per Table 101:7.3.1.2, allows 150 sq.ft/person for general business use. If it is a concentrated business use, then the allowance is reduced to 50 sq.ft./person. The annex information for this section from NFPA describes concentrated business use as, "The value for concentrated business use is intended to address business use spaces with a higher density of occupants than would normally be expected in a general business occupancy. Where furnishings and floor layouts are arranged to maximize the number of occupants in the space, the value for concentrated business use should be applied. Examples of concentrated business use areas are call centers, trading floors, and data processing centers."

Additionally, our example shows several collaboration spaces. Collaboration spaces less than 450 sq.ft. are factored at 30 sq.ft/person, greater than 450 sq.ft. at 15 sq.ft./person. These are defined by NFPA as, "Collaboration rooms/spaces are common to office buildings. Their principal function is to permit collaboration among occupants in the privacy of a small room/space. These rooms/spaces are primarily used by occupants of the business occupancy to transition temporarily from their regular workstation area in order to obtain privacy and to avoid disturbing other employees located in the open office environment. Collaboration rooms/spaces have been commonly referred to as quiet rooms, focus rooms, huddle rooms, and team rooms." Some confusion may be had as to whether a space is considered a conference room or a collaboration space. For the most part, and AHJ, will refer to whatever the space is named on the drawing and apply that occupant load factor. However, if a collaboration space is greater than 450 sq.ft. the occupant load factor is reduced to 15 sq.ft./person. As the primary function of a conference room, as opposed to a collaboration space, is for the purpose of assembly, those spaces larger than 450 sq.ft can be considered a "less concentrated use" assembly space. The occupant load factor still remains at 15 sq.ft./person.

diagrams.title: Egress Req. for Temporary Structures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Temporary structures are those erected for a period of less than 180 days. These structures include special event structures, tents, umbrella structures, and other membrane structures that meet the specified duration requirements. Temporary structures are expected to conform to the structural strength, fire safety, means of egress, accessibility, light, ventilation, and sanitary requirements of the building code to ensure public health, safety, and general welfare. Exit access distance shall not exceed 100 feet, and it must comply with the applicable accessibility requirements as well.

children.body: The occupant load permitted in any building, or portion thereof, is permitted to be increased from that number established for the occupancies in Table 1004.5, provided that all other requirements of the code are met based on such modified number and the occupant load does not exceed one occupant per 7 square feet (0.65 m2) of occupiable floor space. Where required by the building official, an approved aisle, seating or fixed equipment diagram substantiating any increase in occupant load shall be submitted. Where required by the building official, such diagram shall be posted.

For areas having fixed seats and aisles, the occupant load shall be determined by the number of fixed seats installed therein. The occupant load for areas in which fixed seating is not installed, such as waiting spaces, shall be determined in accordance with Section 1004.5 and added to the number of fixed seats.
The occupant load of wheelchair spaces and the associated companion seat shall be based on one occupant for each wheelchair space and one occupant for the associated companion seat provided in accordance with Section 1109.2.3.
For areas having fixed seating without dividing arms, the occupant load shall be not less than the number of seats based on one person for each 18 inches (457 mm) of seating length.
The occupant load of seating booths shall be based on one person for each 24 inches (610 mm) of booth seat length measured at the backrest of the seating booth.

All portions of the means of egress system shall be sized in accordance with this section.
Exception: Aisles and aisle accessways in rooms or spaces used for assembly purposes complying with Section 1030.

diagrams.title: Corridor Widths in Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Life and Safety Code and the Building Code. Section 18.2.3.4 of Life and Safety Code calls for exit access corridors to have width not less than 8'. Section 1020.3 of the building code calls for the width to be the greater width as determined by occupant load per section 1005.1 or per Table 1020.2 (or Table 1020.3). This table calls for 96" minimum width for exit access corridors in areas required for bed movement and 44" minimum width in areas where bed movement is not required. The width may be reduced to 6' at fixed furniture provided the width meets the occupant load egress required per section 1005.1 of the building code. The hospital facilities guidelines code calls for corridor width to comply with two other codes.

diagrams.title: Egress: Min. Reqs., Existing Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1001.2 is to ensure that the means of egress in an existing building are not altered beyond what the code considers safe. It requires that the number of required exits is not reduced below the code required minimum for any area, space or building. It also requires that the means of egress width and capacity of the various means of egress elements that comprise the system are not reduced below the code required minimum and would apply to all required elements of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Aisles with Tables and Fixtures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Aisle accessways and aisles must be maintained in areas where non-fixed seating exists. Chairs and tables are easy to be moved, rearranged and placed in locations that block aisle accessways and aisles. Even though this is not typically a feature installed during construction, the design of the space and operations after occupancy must continue to consider this code requirement.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Width and Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The width of an exit passageway should be sized to accommodate the required capacity of all exits, however the minimum width shall not be less than 44 inches. Exit passageways that serve an occupant load of less than 50 shall not be less than 36 inches in width.

diagrams.title: Handrails at Hospital Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The hospital guidelines call for handrails on both sides of corridors used by patients. Rails are require to be continuous with exceptions being made for doors, nurses stations, alcoves, fire extinguisher cabinets and where features are less than 24" apart (2022). Railing ends are required to return wall or floor. The gripping surface is required to be smooth and free of sharp or abrasive conditions, with 1/8"min. radius. Edges and corners are required to be eased. The finish of the railing must contrast with the wall surface finish by a minimum of 30% and be able to withstand cleaning and disinfection.

diagrams.title: Min. Assembly Aisle Widths
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Minimal aisle width for stepped aisles that serve seating on both sides is 48". Level or ramped aisles serving seating on both sides of the aisle is required to be a minimum of 42". Where an aisle serves seating on only one side, the minimum aisle width can be 36". Where an aisle is divided by a handrail or guard, a minimum of 20" between the rail and seating is required. Exceptions, as shown in this section, apply.

children.body: The minimum width, in inches (mm), of any means of egress components shall be not less than that specified for such component, elsewhere in this code.
The required capacity, in inches (mm), of the means of egress for any room, area, space or story shall be not less than that determined in accordance with Sections 1005.3.1 and 1005.3.2.

diagrams.title: Egress Width: High Hazard (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The building code requires the width be based on "occupants served". The Life Safety Code and NFPA 1 Fire Code allows the capacity to be calculated based on an occupant load served by the corridor divided by the number of exits the corridor is joined to. However, the width is not allowed to be less than the required capacity of the exit to which it leads.

children.displayTitle: 1005.3 Required Capacity Based on Occupant Load
children.titleText: Required Capacity Based on Occupant Load

children.body:
The capacity, in inches, of means of egress stairways shall be calculated by multiplying the occupant load served by such stairways by a means of egress capacity factor of 0.3 inch (7.6 mm) per occupant. Where stairways serve more than one story, only the occupant load of each story considered individually shall be used in calculating the required capacity of the stairways serving that story.
Exceptions:
  1. For other than Group H and I-2 occupancies, the capacity, in inches, of means of egress stairways shall be calculated by multiplying the occupant load served by such stairways by a means of egress capacity factor of 0.2 inch (5.1 mm) per occupant in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 and an emergency voice/alarm communication system in accordance with Section 907.5.2.2.
  2. Facilities with smoke-protected assembly seating shall be permitted to use the capacity factors in Table 1030.6.2 indicated for stepped aisles for exit access or exit stairways where the entire path for means of egress from the seating to the exit discharge is provided with a smoke control system complying with Section 909.
  3. Facilities with open-air assembly seating shall be permitted to the capacity factors in Section 1030.6.3 indicated for stepped aisles for exit access or exit stairways where the entire path for means of egress from the seating to the exit discharge is open to the outdoors.

diagrams.title: Stair Width with Chair Lift (Metal Pan Condition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1011.2 defines the required exit stair width. The required width is based on the Occupant load served by the stairway. The minimum width required is 0.3" per occupant per section 1005.1 but not less than 44". There are a few exceptions: The code does allow for 36" wide stairs for stairs that serve and occupant load of <50. Spiral stairs width is covered by section 1011.10. Stairways that serve R-3 occupancy or are within R-2 dwelling units with a folding inclined platform or stairway chairlift must have 20" clear passage measured at the folded lift.

Commentary: Encroachment of stringers appear to depend on if it is a structural member, or just a skirt trim board. If the stringer is a structural element, then 1005.7.2 would seem to prohibit the obstruction, and the stair width would need to be measured between the face of stringers. However, if it were a non-structural trim piece such as a skirt board, then a projection may be allowed. Check with your local building official for the final interpretation of allowed projections into a stairway.

diagrams.title: Example: Concrete Stairs at Elevated Slab
EVACS Systems
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency voice/alarm communications systems (EVACS) are used to alert and instruct occupants on what to do when a fire incident occurs. When a smoke detector, sprinkler system, or manual pull station is activated the EVACS system should sound an alert tone, followed by recorded voice instructions (these instructions should be outlined in the fire safety and evacuation plans per Section 404). In high-rise buildings, in case of fire, the EVACS system only needs to activate on the fire floor, floor above, and floor below. Additionally, EVACS speakers are to be provided throughout the building by paging zones - every floor, elevator groups, areas of refuge, and interior stairways. All EVACS systems are to be designed, installed, tested, and maintained in accordance with NFPA 72, National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code.

diagrams.title: Min. Stairway Widths and Loss of Exit
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For floors utilizing stairs as a means of egress the minimum required combined width of the stairs is determined by multiplying the occupant load for the floor served by the egress capacity factor of 0.3". Egress stairs must be built in accordance with Section 1011, which requires a 44" minimum stair width. Exceptions apply for buildings protected throughout by an automatic sprinkler system and protected by an EVACS system, for smoke-protected assembly seating, and for open air assembly seating.

If one stair is becomes no longer available for service, then the remaining stairs are required to provide at least 50% of the required capacity or width.

children.body:
The capacity, in inches, of means of egress components other than stairways shall be calculated by multiplying the occupant load served by such component by a means of egress capacity factor of 0.2 inch (5.1 mm) per occupant.
Exceptions:
  1. For other than Group H and I-2 occupancies, the capacity, in inches, of means of egress components other than stairways shall be calculated by multiplying the occupant load served by such component by a means of egress capacity factor of 0.15 inch (3.8 mm) per occupant in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 and an emergency voice/alarm communication system in accordance with Section 907.5.2.2.
  2. Facilities with smoke-protected assembly seating shall be permitted to use the capacity factors in Table 1030.6.2 indicated for level or ramped aisles for means of egress components other than stairways where the entire path for means of egress from the seating to the exit discharge is provided with a smoke control system complying with Section 909.
  3. Facilities with open-air assembly seating shall be permitted to the capacity factors in Section 1030.6.3 indicated for level or ramped aisles for means of egress components other than stairways where the entire path for means of egress from the seating to the exit discharge is open to the outdoors.

diagrams.title: Exits through Lobbies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Lobbies, often classified as Group A-3 occupancies or accessory to another Group A occupancy, are frequently gathering or waiting spaces for other assembly areas, or for a catchment area between the public and private areas of a building. The code allows the number of lobby exits only to be based on the occupant load of the lobby, but the width of the exits must be sufficiently sized for the cumulative occupant load. In the example shown, at least three 36" wide doors (assuming 34" actual opening width, with door at 90 degree open angle) would be required to provide the 95.5" min. width.

diagrams.title: Corridor Width Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Corridor widths are determined by the total occupants feeding into the corridor without consideration for how many exits are from that corridor. If a Emergency Voice / Alarm Communications System is used with either an NFPA 13 or 13R system, then a narrower corridor is possible if the corridor does not serve an H or I-2 occupancy space.

diagrams.title: Min. Corridor Width by Occupancy (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Life Safety Code Section 7.3 outlines egress capacity, minimum egress width, and formulas for determining occupant load related to egress capacity. This section should be followed, unless the occupancy specific sections in chapters 11-43 state specific minimum egress corridor widths. Where a minimum corridor width is not specified for the occupancy type, it shall not be less than 36". For all existing occupancies, minimum corridor widths are to never be less than 28".

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency voice/alarm communications systems (EVACS) are used to alert and instruct occupants on what to do when a fire incident occurs. When a smoke detector, sprinkler system, or manual pull station is activated the EVACS system should sound an alert tone, followed by recorded voice instructions (these instructions should be outlined in the fire safety and evacuation plans per Section 404). In high-rise buildings, in case of fire, the EVACS system only needs to activate on the fire floor, floor above, and floor below. Additionally, EVACS speakers are to be provided throughout the building by paging zones - every floor, elevator groups, areas of refuge, and interior stairways. All EVACS systems are to be designed, installed, tested, and maintained in accordance with NFPA 72, National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code.

children.body: The minimum width or required capacity of the means of egress required from any story of a building shall not be reduced along the path of egress travel until arrival at the public way.

diagrams.title: Egress From Stories or Occupied Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml: For a building to be safe all stories need to be provided with adequate egress. Section 1006.3 requires that each story or occupied roof be provided with the number of separate exits or access to exits based on the occupant load of the story. The number of required exits required for a story are defined in Table 1006.3.3. The exits or exit access from each story need to sized to address the occupant load of the story being served. Section 1005 defines how to size various egress elements. The various stories and occupied roof may share a common exit stairway. An exit stairway serving multiple stories needs to be sized to serve the occupant load of the story or occupied roof with the greatest occupant load that it serves not the aggregate occupant load of all stories served.

children.body: Where more than one exit, or access to more than one exit, is required, the means of egress shall be configured such that the loss of any one exit, or access to one exit, shall not reduce the available capacity or width to less than 50 percent of the required capacity or width.

For floors utilizing stairs as a means of egress the minimum required combined width of the stairs is determined by multiplying the occupant load for the floor served by the egress capacity factor of 0.3". Egress stairs must be built in accordance with Section 1011, which requires a 44" minimum stair width. Exceptions apply for buildings protected throughout by an automatic sprinkler system and protected by an EVACS system, for smoke-protected assembly seating, and for open air assembly seating.

children.displayTitle: 1005.5 Distribution of Minimum Width and Required Capacity
children.titleText: Distribution of Minimum Width and Required Capacity

children.body: Where the means of egress from stories above and below converge at an intermediate level, the capacity of the means of egress from the point of convergence shall be not less than the largest minimum width or the sum of the required capacities for the stairways or ramps serving the two adjacent stories, whichever is larger.
Encroachments into the required means of egress width shall be in accordance with the provisions of this section.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

children.body:
Doors, when fully opened, shall not reduce the required width by more than 7 inches (178 mm). Doors in any position shall not reduce the required width by more than one-half.
Exceptions:
  1. Surface-mounted latch release hardware shall be exempt from inclusion in the 7-inch maximum (178 mm) encroachment where both of the following conditions exist:
    1.1.  The hardware is mounted to the side of the door facing away from the adjacent wall where the door is in the open position.
    1.2.  The hardware is mounted not less than 34 inches (865 mm) nor more than 48 inches (1219 mm) above the finished floor.
  2. The restrictions on door swing shall not apply to doors within individual dwelling units and sleeping units of Group R-2 occupancies and dwelling units of Group R-3 occupancies.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

children.body:
Handrail projections shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section 1014.9. Other nonstructural projections such as trim and similar decorative features shall be permitted to project into the required width not more than 11/2 inches (38 mm) on each side.
Exception: Projections are permitted in corridors within Group I-2, Condition 1 in accordance with Section 407.4.3.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Stairs Horizontal Encroachments
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Generally, projections of more than 4" are not allowed into the circulation path. This doesn't include the 48" clear width between handrails for stairways used as an accessible means of egress.

The allowance for a 1-1/2" projection into the required width for trim or other non-structural projection at the base would not include structural items such as stringers for steel pan-tread type stairways. The minimum required stair width would have to be accommodated for between the structural items in that condition.

children.body: Protruding objects shall comply with the applicable requirements of Section 1003.3.

diagrams.title: Protruding Objects: Headroom
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because circulation paths, walks, corridors, aisles, and passageways are used for egress and egress access, the code limits the minimum ceiling height to stop smoke and other contaminants from preventing safe egress in the event of an emergency. Section 1003.3.1 ensures that any protruding objects do not lower the ceiling to a point that makes the building egress unreasonably safe. Over areas required for the means of egress protruding objects may reduce the ceiling height to 80" minimum. The aggregate area of protruding objects over a means of egress cannot exceed 50% of the ceiling area of the means of egress. Protruding objects not over the required egress width may be less than 80" when provided with a barrier, often referred to as cane detection. The barrier cannot exceed a height of 27". The code does provide an exception for door stops and closers which may not be less than 78" above the floor.

diagrams.title: Group I-4 Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1006.2.1 (2021 and 2024) outlines how the code considers the varying evacuation needs of different occupancies. It modifies the criteria for requiring two exits based on three factors: the occupancy group, the occupant load, and the common path of egress travel. For instance, an I-4 daycare occupancy has a low threshold, requiring more than 10 occupants for two exits, compared to a B office occupancy, which requires more than 49 occupants. This distinction acknowledges that occupants in a B office can evacuate quickly and independently, while daycare occupants may need assistance and more time, necessitating more accessible egress options.

diagrams.title: Egress: Min. Reqs., Existing Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1001.2 is to ensure that the means of egress in an existing building are not altered beyond what the code considers safe. It requires that the number of required exits is not reduced below the code required minimum for any area, space or building. It also requires that the means of egress width and capacity of the various means of egress elements that comprise the system are not reduced below the code required minimum and would apply to all required elements of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Travel Distance: R-3 and R-4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Use of an NFPA 13D sprinkler system in a Group R-3 building allows greater exit access distances than in an R-4. Group R-4 involves custodial care, so a shorter distance is allowed.

diagrams.title: Example: Single Exit Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Non-Sprinklered

Spaces are allowed to have only a single exit if they have less than a prescribed amount of occupants, depending on the occupancy group. Also, the common path of egress travel must be less than that allowed by Table 1006.2.1. However, dead end corridors themselves are not limited when only one exit is required.

diagrams.title: Single Exits: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Single exits are permitted to serve multiple occupancies and multiple stories provided a number of additional limitations are met by the design. For a single exit, exit access stairway or ramp to serve a story with multiple occupancies each occupancy in and of itself must meet the requirements of Table 1006.3.3(1) or Table 1006.3.3(2). In addition where a single exit serves a story or multiple stories the sum of the ratios for each occupancy of the design occupant load divided by the allowable occupant load from Table 1006.3.3(2) for each story served by the exit must not exceed 1. When dwelling units are on a floor, the ratio used for dwelling units in the summation is the number of dwelling units divided by 4.

diagrams.title: Exterior Egress Door Arrangement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1022.2.2 is to ensure that exits lead to a location that provides adequate escape from the building upon exiting. It ensures that all exits provide adequate access to a public way, either directly or via an exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Required Exits: Three or More
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exits are required to be placed far enough apart to allow independent exiting if one exit is blocked.

UpCodes Note: The exact distance between the third (or forth) exit and the primary exits (first and second) is not clear. The requirement is a performance requirement that it must be a "reasonable" distance apart to provide use if one is blocked. Please check with your local building or fire official regarding the application of this section, as the interpretation of "reasonable distance" may be different between code officials and design professionals.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Lobbies, often classified as Group A-3 occupancies or accessory to another Group A occupancy, are frequently gathering or waiting spaces for other assembly areas, or for a catchment area between the public and private areas of a building. The code allows the number of lobby exits only to be based on the occupant load of the lobby, but the width of the exits must be sufficiently sized for the cumulative occupant load. diagrams.title: Stories with Single Exits - Condition 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where any one of the following conditions is met any story or occupied roof space may have single exit:
Condition 1: The Exit access travel distance, occupant load and number of dwelling units do not exceed the values in Table 1006.3.4(1) or Table 1006.3.4(2)
Condition 2: Rooms, areas and spaces that comply with Section 1006.2.1 and have exits that discharge directly to the exterior at the level of exit discharge
Condition 3: Parking garage where vehicles are mechanically parked
Condition 4: Group R-3 and R-4 occupancies
Condition 5: Individual Dwelling Units that comply with section 1006.2.1 that exit directly to the exterior or exit to exit access that provides access to two approved independent exits.

diagrams.title: Common Path of Travel from Assembly Seating
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In an assembly occupancy that provides seating whether the seating is fixed or not the maximum travel distance from any seat to a point where two separate paths are available leading to different exits, the common path of travel, may not exceed 30'. In assembly occupancies with an occupant load less than 50 the common path of travel may not exceed 75'. The common path of egress travel shall from seating in a smoke-protected or open-air assembly occupancy may not exceed 50'.

children.displayTitle: Section 1006 Number of Exits and Exit Access Doorways
children.titleText: Number of Exits and Exit Access Doorways

children.body: The number of exits or exit access doorways required within the means of egress system shall comply with the provisions of Section 1006.2 for spaces, including mezzanines, and Section 1006.3 for stories or occupiable roofs.
Rooms, areas or spaces, including mezzanines, within a story or basement shall be provided with the number of exits or access to exits in accordance with this section.

Two exits or exit access doorways from any space shall be provided where the design occupant load or the common path of egress travel distance exceeds the values listed in Table 1006.2.1. The cumulative occupant load from adjacent rooms, areas or spaces shall be determined in accordance with Section 1004.2.
Exceptions:
  1. The number of exits from foyers, lobbies, vestibules or similar spaces need not be based on cumulative occupant loads for areas discharging through such spaces, but the capacity of the exits from such spaces shall be based on applicable cumulative occupant loads.
  2. Care suites in Group I-2 occupancies complying with Section 407.4.
  3. Unoccupied mechanical rooms and penthouses are not required to comply with the common path of egress travel distance measurement.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1006.2.1 (2021 and 2024) outlines how the code considers the varying evacuation needs of different occupancies. It modifies the criteria for requiring two exits based on three factors: the occupancy group, the occupant load, and the common path of egress travel. This distinction acknowledges that occupants in a B office can evacuate quickly and independently, while daycare occupants may need assistance and more time, necessitating more accessible egress options.

diagrams.title: Common Path of Egress Travel
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines COMMON PATH OF EGRESS TRAVEL. as that portion of exit access travel distance measured from the most remote point of each room, area or space to that point where the occupants have separate and distinct access to two exits or exit access doorways.

Common Path of Egress Travel limitations establish the maximum distance occupants may travel before optional egress route(s) must be provided. Rooms or spaces otherwise permitted to exist with one exit access route, by occupancy, use occupant load or stories, will require additional exit access when common path of egress travel exceeds values in Table 1006.2.1. Travel should be measured orthogonally and not as a direct diagonal. The path should be measured along the longest potential path around known and anticipated obstructions to travel, including partitions, tables, chairs, and other fixtures reasonably likely to occur in the space.

Most state codes refer to "Maximum Common Path of Egress Travel Distance" in Table 1006.2.1. New Jersey has amended the table to reference "Exit Access Travel Distance". Exit access travel distance (1017.3) is measured along the "natural and unobstructed path of horizontal... egress travel." This definition would suggest a case-by-case consideration of the appropriate path of travel through a room.

Where a second exit access is provided due to excessive common path of egress travel, the exit access shall be separated per 1007.1.1. Additionally, the separate exit access from a room or space shall provide access to independent exits. Two or more means of egress from a room or space that then converge to depend on a single exit are still considered a common path of egress travel, and do not meet the code intent.
