Condition 4: Group R-3 and R-4 occupancies
Condition 5: Individual Dwelling Units that comply with section 1006.2.1 that exit directly to the exterior or exit to exit access that provides access to two approved independent exits.

diagrams.title: Stories with Single Exits - Condition 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where any one of the following conditions is met any story or occupied roof space may have single exit:
Condition 1: The Exit access travel distance, occupant load and number of dwelling units do not exceed the values in Table 1006.3.4(1) or Table 1006.3.4(2)
Condition 2: Rooms, areas and spaces that comply with Section 1006.2.1 and have exits that discharge directly to the exterior at the level of exit discharge
Condition 3: Parking garage where vehicles are mechanically parked
Condition 4: Group R-3 and R-4 occupancies
Condition 5: Individual Dwelling Units that comply with section 1006.2.1 that exit directly to the exterior or exit to exit access that provides access to two approved independent exits.

diagrams.title: Example: Exit Access Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Common path of egress travel and exit access distances are two different but related concepts. Common path of egress travel measures the distance from the start of egress travel to the point at which occupants have a choice of travel to more than one exit. The exit access travel distance is a cumulative measurement of the common path of travel, and the remaining distance to the nearest exit.

If the common path of egress travel does not provide access to two separate and distinct exits or exit access doorways, within the distance specified by Section 1006, an additional exit or exit access is required. The maximum travel distance in the exit access is dependent on the occupancy group and fire sprinkler status and is limited to that specified by Table 1017.2. So long as the allowable common path of egress travel is met, the exit access travel distance (Table 1017.2) must only be satisfied for the closest exit to the space under consideration.

In the example, a B occupancy with NFPA 13 sprinkler system throughout, the maximum exit access travel distance is 300 feet. Given the dimensions shown, both the common path of egress travel and exit access travel distances are satisfied.

diagrams.title: Egress Through an Elevator Lobby
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Egress through intervening spaces lets a person exit a building by going through other rooms or spaces instead of directly into a hallway or exit. The main idea is that exit routes should stay safe, clear, and easy to follow, but there are a few exceptions. You're allowed to exit through elevator lobbies, but at least one exit must be reachable without going through the lobby. In other than Group H occupancy buildings you can also pass through nearby rooms if they're related to the main space and the way out is obvious. For hazardous occupancies, the adjoining room must be the same or a lower hazard level. There are also limits on where exits can go. You can't exit through rooms that can be locked against you, through other people's bedrooms, bathrooms, kitchens, storage rooms, or closets, unless certain conditions are met. In Group M, you can exit through a stockroom, but only if it meets certain requirements. The stock should be the same hazardous class as what's in the main sales area, no more than half the path goes through the stockroom, the door isn't locked, and there's a clearly marked 44" wide aisle that leads directly to the exit. The rules let people use adjoining spaces as exit paths, but only when it's safe, obvious, and not blocked or locked.

children.displayTitle: 1006.2.1 Egress Based on Occupant Load and Common Path of Egress Travel Distance
children.titleText: Egress Based on Occupant Load and Common Path of Egress Travel Distance

children.body: Three exits or exit access doorways shall be provided from any space with an occupant load of 501 to 1,000. Four exits or exit access doorways shall be provided from any space with an occupant load greater than 1,000.

diagrams.title: Required Exits: Three or More
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exits are required to be placed far enough apart to allow independent exiting if one exit is blocked.

UpCodes Note: The exact distance between the third (or forth) exit and the primary exits (first and second) is not clear. The requirement is a performance requirement that it must be a "reasonable" distance apart to provide use if one is blocked. Please check with your local building or fire official regarding the application of this section, as the interpretation of "reasonable distance" may be different between code officials and design professionals.

children.displayTitle: 1006.2.1.1 Three or More Exits or Exit Access Doorways
children.titleText: Three or More Exits or Exit Access Doorways

children.body: The numbers, configuration and types of components of exits or access to exits shall be provided in the uses described in Sections 1006.2.2.1 through 1006.2.2.6.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Travel Distance: R-3 and R-4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Use of an NFPA 13D sprinkler system in a Group R-3 building allows greater exit access distances than in an R-4. Group R-4 involves custodial care, so a shorter distance is allowed.

diagrams.title: Example: Exit Access Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Common path of egress travel and exit access distances are two different but related concepts. Common path of egress travel measures the distance from the start of egress travel to the point at which occupants have a choice of travel to more than one exit. The exit access travel distance is a cumulative measurement of the common path of travel, and the remaining distance to the nearest exit.

If the common path of egress travel does not provide access to two separate and distinct exits or exit access doorways, within the distance specified by Section 1006, an additional exit or exit access is required. The maximum travel distance in the exit access is dependent on the occupancy group and fire sprinkler status and is limited to that specified by Table 1017.2. So long as the allowable common path of egress travel is met, the exit access travel distance (Table 1017.2) must only be satisfied for the closest exit to the space under consideration.

In the example, a B occupancy with NFPA 13 sprinkler system throughout, the maximum exit access travel distance is 300 feet. Given the dimensions shown, both the common path of egress travel and exit access travel distances are satisfied.

children.body: Two exit access doorways are required in boiler, incinerator and furnace rooms where the area is over 500 square feet (46 m2) and any fuel-fired equipment exceeds 400,000 British thermal units (Btu) (422 000 KJ) input capacity. Where two exit access doorways are required, one is permitted to be a fixed ladder or an alternating tread device. Exit access doorways shall be separated by a horizontal distance equal to one-half the length of the maximum overall diagonal dimension of the room.

diagrams.title: Exits from Boiler, Incinerator and Furnace Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Boiler, incinerator, and furnace rooms house equipment that operate at high temperatures and pressures. If something goes wrong, there is a potential risk for fires or explosions. Having two exit access doorways ensures that if one exit becomes blocked or compromised, there is an alternative escape route available.

diagrams.title: Ladders: Where Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Permanent ladders may not be a part of the means of egress from any occupied space. Details related to the ladder construction are in the mechanical code section 306.5. The ladder's structural live load requirements are defined in section 1607.17 of the building code. Permanent ladders may be utilized to provide access to the following types of areas and spaces.
  1. Spaces that only need to be accessed by personnel for the maintenance, repair or monitoring of equipment.
  2. Nonoccupied spaces such as crawl spaces, catwalks, freight elevators or very narrow passageways as may be found in a theater or large mechanical room.
  3. Areas primarily utilized for security, life safety or fire safety such as guard towers and lifeguard stands, typically encountered in institutional occupancies.
  4. In group U occupancies areas not open to the general public.
  5. Roofs that are nonoccupied and do not require a stairway by Section 1011.12.1
  6. Where Section 306.5 of the Mechanical Code allows for ladders to access equipment and appliances.

diagrams.title: Equipment, Boiler and Furnace Rooms (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because equipment, boiler and furnace rooms have such a low occupant load the life safety code has more lenient common path of travel requirements specifically for equipment, boiler and furnace rooms and limits the common path of travel to not exceed 50 ft. The common path of travel from an equipment, boiler or furnace room may be increased to 100 ft when the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system, there is no fuel-fired equipment in the space, or if the equipment room is within an existing building. The common path of travel may be increased to 150 ft provided the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system, there is no fuel-fired equipment in the space, and the egress path is readily identifiable to occupants within the equipment, boiler or furnace room. In existing health care occupancies the path of travel limitations of section 7.13.1 do not apply provided the arrangement of exits complies with 19.2.5 and the travel distance limits of 19.2.6 are satisfied.

children.body:
Machinery rooms larger than 1,000 square feet (93 m2) shall have not less than two exits or exit access doorways. Where two exit access doorways are required, one such doorway is permitted to be served by a fixed ladder or an alternating tread device. Exit access doorways shall be separated by a horizontal distance equal to one-half the maximum horizontal dimension of the room.
Exit access travel distance shall be determined as specified in Section 1017.1, but all portions of a refrigeration machinery room shall be within 150 feet (45 720 mm) of an exit or exit access doorway where such rooms are not protected by an approved automatic sprinkler system. Egress is allowed through adjoining refrigeration machinery rooms or adjoining refrigerated rooms or spaces.
Exit and exit access doorways shall swing in the direction of egress travel and shall be equipped with panic hardware, regardless of the occupant load served. Exit and exit access doorways shall be tight fitting and self-closing.

diagrams.title: Refrigeration Machinery Rooms: Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Refrigeration machinery rooms can contain hazardous materials, like refrigerants that could leak and displace oxygen, leading to asphyxiation risks. If there's a leak or a fire, personnel inside the room might need an immediate escape route. Having two exits ensures that if one is blocked or compromised, there's a secondary route to safety.

children.body:
Rooms or spaces having a floor area larger than 1,000 square feet (93 m2), containing a refrigerant evaporator and maintained at a temperature below 68°F (20°C), shall have access to not less than two exits or exit access doorways.
Exit access travel distance shall be determined as specified in Section 1017.1, but all portions of a refrigerated room or space shall be within 150 feet (45 720 mm) of an exit or exit access doorway where such rooms are not protected by an approved automatic sprinkler system. Egress is allowed through adjoining refrigerated rooms or spaces.
Exception: Where using refrigerants in quantities limited to the amounts based on the volume set forth in the International Mechanical Code.

The location and number of exit or exit access doorways shall be provided for electrical rooms in accordance with Section 110.26 of NFPA 70 for electrical equipment rated 1,000 volts or less, and Section 110.33 of NFPA 70 for electrical equipment rated over 1,000 volts. Panic hardware shall be provided where required in accordance with Section 1010.2.8.2.

diagrams.title: Clearances at Electrical Equipment
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The depth of working space in front of equipment that is less than 1000V is dependent on one of three conditions. Condition 1: Exposed live parts on one side of the working space. Condition 2: Exposed live parts on one side and grounded parts or concrete walls on the other. Condition 3: Exposed live parts on both sides.

Voltage ranges can be three ranges: 0-150 Volts to ground (all your 120/240 or 120/208 panels); 151-600 Volts to ground (all your 277/480 volt panels, transformers); 601-1000 Volts to ground (Higher voltage equipment).

Visualize that you are standing in front of a panel with exposed live parts. Then assess what is behind you, and what voltage the voltage of the equipment that is in front of you.

diagrams.title: Allowed Clearance at Open Equipment Doors (<1000V)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A path 24" wide by 6-1/2 feet tall must be provided for access to and egress from the work space required for electrical equipment. Equipment doors in an open position may not restrict the required access and egress from electrical work spaces. Access and egress from and electrical work space is considered to be restricted if the path is reduced to be less than 24" wide or less than 6-1/2 feet tall.

diagrams.title: Electrical Working Space Conditions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The minimum required depth of working space in front of electrical equipment must meet the minimum distances specified in Table 110.26(A)(1) based on voltage to ground and the opposing surface per condition, unless exceptions requirements are met. Condition 1 provides that exposed live parts do not have live or grounded parts opposing it, or exposed live parts on both sides of working space are guarded by insulating materials. Condition 2 provides that exposed live parts are opposite grounded parts. Lastly, condition 3 provides that exposed live parts are opposite each other on both sides of working space.

children.body: Vehicular ramps shall not be considered as an exit access ramp unless pedestrian facilities are provided.

Where Group R-3 occupancies are permitted by Section 903.2.8 to be protected by an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3, the exit access travel distance for Group R-3 shall be not more than 125 feet (38 100 mm). Where Group R-4 occupancies are permitted by Section 903.2.8 to be protected by an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3, the exit access travel distance for Group R-4 shall be not more than 75 feet (22 860 mm).

diagrams.title: Exit Access Travel Distance: R-3 and R-4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Use of an NFPA 13D sprinkler system in a Group R-3 building allows greater exit access distances than in an R-4. Group R-4 involves custodial care, so a shorter distance is allowed.

children.body: All spaces located on a story or occupiable roof shall have access to the required number of separate and distinct exits or access to exits based on the aggregate occupant load served in accordance with this section.

diagrams.title: High Rise: Additional Stairway
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a building (other than Group R-2 occupancy type) exceeds 420' in height, an additional stairwell is required. This is in addition to the minimum egress requirements of Section 1006.3. If the building is equipped with an occupant evacuation elevator, then this additional stairwell is not required. Where other parts of the building have a maximum occupiable height of less than 420', that section of the building is not required to have the extra stairwell.

diagrams.title: Egress From Stories or Occupied Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml: For a building to be safe all stories need to be provided with adequate egress. Section 1006.3 requires that each story or occupied roof be provided with the number of separate exits or access to exits based on the occupant load of the story. The number of required exits required for a story are defined in Table 1006.3.3. The exits or exit access from each story need to sized to address the occupant load of the story being served. Section 1005 defines how to size various egress elements. The various stories and occupied roof may share a common exit stairway. An exit stairway serving multiple stories needs to be sized to serve the occupant load of the story or occupied roof with the greatest occupant load that it serves not the aggregate occupant load of all stories served.

diagrams.title: Penthouse Stair Access to Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Penthouse: An enclosed, unoccupied rooftop structure used for sheltering mechanical and electrical equipment, tanks, elevators and related machinery, stairways, and vertical shaft openings.

Penthouses for rooftop access stairs have specific requirements from Chapter 15 as well as Chapter 10.

diagrams.title: Single Exits: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Single exits are permitted to serve multiple occupancies and multiple stories provided a number of additional limitations are met by the design. For a single exit, exit access stairway or ramp to serve a story with multiple occupancies each occupancy in and of itself must meet the requirements of Table 1006.3.3(1) or Table 1006.3.3(2). In addition where a single exit serves a story or multiple stories the sum of the ratios for each occupancy of the design occupant load divided by the allowable occupant load from Table 1006.3.3(2) for each story served by the exit must not exceed 1. When dwelling units are on a floor, the ratio used for dwelling units in the summation is the number of dwelling units divided by 4.

diagrams.title: Occupant Loads: Outdoor Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1004.7 is to ensure that Outdoor Areas have adequate means for emergency evacuation. It gives the building official the authority to determine the occupant load for outdoor areas. It establishes that the Means of Egress for Outdoor Areas be established per the requirements of Chapter 10 of the building code, the same requirements as any other room or space. It provides exceptions for outdoor areas used exclusively for servicing the building and outdoor areas serving R-3 buildings and R-2 dwelling units.

children.displayTitle: 1006.3 Egress From Stories or Occupiable Roofs
children.titleText: Egress From Stories or Occupiable Roofs

children.body: Where stairways serve more than one story, or more than one story and an occupiable roof, only the occupant load of each story or occupiable roof, considered individually, shall be used when calculating the required number of exits or access to exits serving that story.

The path of egress travel to an exit shall not pass through more than one adjacent story.
Exception: The path of egress travel to an exit shall be permitted to pass through more than one adjacent story in any of the following:
  1. In Group R-1, R-2 or R-3 occupancies, exit access stairways and ramps connecting four stories or less serving and contained within an individual dwelling unit, sleeping unit or live/work unit.
  2. Exit access stairways serving and contained within a Group R-3 congregate residence or a Group R-4 facility.
  3. Exit access stairways and ramps within an atrium complying with Section 404.
  4. Exit access stairways and ramps in open parking garages that serve only the parking garage.
  5. Exit access stairways and ramps serving smoke-protected assembly seating and open-air assembly seating complying with the exit access travel distance requirements of Section 1030.7.
  6. Exit access stairways and ramps between the balcony, gallery or press box and the main assembly floor in occupancies such as theaters, places of religious worship, auditoriums and sports facilities.
  7. Exterior exit access stairways and ramps between occupiable roofs.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stair: Balconies (Ex. 8)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways serving balconies that end in the main assembly space don't have to be enclosed. But keep in mind that unenclosed exit access stairways are not exits. They are a part of the exit access. When the path of exit access includes unenclosed stairways, Section 1017.3.1 requires the distance of travel on such means of egress components to be included in the total travel distance measurement. The measurement along stairways must be made on a plane parallel and tangent to the stair tread nosings in the center of the stairway. This increases the actual exit path distance compared to a simple plan view measurement.

children.body: Each story and occupiable roof shall have the minimum number of separate and distinct exits, or access to exits, as specified in Table 1006.3.3. A single exit or access to a single exit shall be permitted in accordance with Section 1006.3.4. The required number of exits, or exit access stairways or ramps providing access to exits, from any story or occupiable roof shall be maintained until arrival at the exit discharge or a public way.

diagrams.title: Required Exits: Three or More
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exits are required to be placed far enough apart to allow independent exiting if one exit is blocked.

UpCodes Note: The exact distance between the third (or forth) exit and the primary exits (first and second) is not clear. The requirement is a performance requirement that it must be a "reasonable" distance apart to provide use if one is blocked. Please check with your local building or fire official regarding the application of this section, as the interpretation of "reasonable distance" may be different between code officials and design professionals.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exit Egress Analysis
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When used correctly, in certain situations, use of a horizontal exit can reduce the number of stairways provided while maintaining a consistent level of protection for all occupants. With certain exceptions, horizontal exits are limited to satisfying no more than 50% of the required exits, exit capacity or exit width required from a space under consideration. They may not serve as the only exit from any space. The space to which a horizontal exit leads must be a public area, or occupied by the same tenant and shall serve as a refuge area. The refuge area must be of sufficient size to accommodate the occupants existing in the space and the occupants entering the space assuming 3 s.f. per person for the combined occupant load.

children.body:
A single exit or access to a single exit shall be permitted from any story or occupiable roof where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. The occupant load, number of dwelling units and exit access travel distance do not exceed the values in Table 1006.3.4(1) or 1006.3.4(2).
  2. Rooms, areas and spaces complying with Section 1006.2.1 with exits that discharge directly to the exterior at the level of exit discharge, are permitted to have one exit or access to a single exit.
  3. Parking garages where vehicles are mechanically parked shall be permitted to have one exit or access to a single exit.
  4. Group R-3 and R-4 occupancies shall be permitted to have one exit or access to a single exit.
  5. Individual single-story or multistory dwelling units shall be permitted to have a single exit or access to a single exit from the dwelling unit provided that both of the following criteria are met:
    5.1.  The dwelling unit complies with Section 1006.2.1 as a space with one means of egress.
    5.2.  Either the exit from the dwelling unit discharges directly to the exterior at the level of exit discharge, or the exit access outside the dwelling unit's entrance door provides access to not less than two approved independent exits.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

diagrams.title: Common Path of Egress Travel
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines COMMON PATH OF EGRESS TRAVEL. as that portion of exit access travel distance measured from the most remote point of each room, area or space to that point where the occupants have separate and distinct access to two exits or exit access doorways.

Common Path of Egress Travel limitations establish the maximum distance occupants may travel before optional egress route(s) must be provided. Rooms or spaces otherwise permitted to exist with one exit access route, by occupancy, use occupant load or stories, will require additional exit access when common path of egress travel exceeds values in Table 1006.2.1. Travel should be measured orthogonally and not as a direct diagonal. The path should be measured along the longest potential path around known and anticipated obstructions to travel, including partitions, tables, chairs, and other fixtures reasonably likely to occur in the space.

Most state codes refer to "Maximum Common Path of Egress Travel Distance" in Table 1006.2.1. New Jersey has amended the table to reference "Exit Access Travel Distance". Exit access travel distance (1017.3) is measured along the "natural and unobstructed path of horizontal... egress travel." This definition would suggest a case-by-case consideration of the appropriate path of travel through a room.

Where a second exit access is provided due to excessive common path of egress travel, the exit access shall be separated per 1007.1.1. Additionally, the separate exit access from a room or space shall provide access to independent exits. Two or more means of egress from a room or space that then converge to depend on a single exit are still considered a common path of egress travel, and do not meet the code intent.

diagrams.title: Stairway Door Operations - Excpt. 4 & 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Interior stairway means of egress doors shall be openable from both sides without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.

Exception 4 states that stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group B, F, M, and S occupancies where the only interior access to the tenant space is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

Exception 5 states that stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group R-2 occupancies where the only interior access to the dwelling unit is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

diagrams.title: Stories with Single Exits - Condition 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where any one of the following conditions is met any story or occupied roof space may have single exit:
Condition 1: The Exit access travel distance, occupant load and number of dwelling units do not exceed the values in Table 1006.3.4(1) or Table 1006.3.4(2)
Condition 2: Rooms, areas and spaces that comply with Section 1006.2.1 and have exits that discharge directly to the exterior at the level of exit discharge
Condition 3: Parking garage where vehicles are mechanically parked

children.body: Where one exit, or exit access stairway or ramp providing access to exits at other stories, is permitted to serve individual stories, mixed occupancies shall be permitted to be served by single exits provided that each individual occupancy complies with the applicable requirements of Table 1006.3.4(1) or 1006.3.4(2) for that occupancy. Where applicable, cumulative occupant loads from adjacent occupancies shall be considered to be in accordance with the provisions of Section 1004.1. In each story of a mixed occupancy building, the maximum number of occupants served by a single exit shall be such that the sum of the ratios of the calculated number of occupants of the space divided by the allowable number of occupants indicated in Table 1006.3.4(2) for each occupancy does not exceed one. Where dwelling units are located on a story with other occupancies, the actual number of dwelling units divided by four plus the ratio from the other occupancy does not exceed one.

diagrams.title: Single Exits: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Single exits are permitted to serve multiple occupancies and multiple stories provided a number of additional limitations are met by the design. For a single exit, exit access stairway or ramp to serve a story with multiple occupancies each occupancy in and of itself must meet the requirements of Table 1006.3.3(1) or Table 1006.3.3(2). In addition where a single exit serves a story or multiple stories the sum of the ratios for each occupancy of the design occupant load divided by the allowable occupant load from Table 1006.3.3(2) for each story served by the exit must not exceed 1. When dwelling units are on a floor, the ratio used for dwelling units in the summation is the number of dwelling units divided by 4.

diagrams.title: Assembly: Other Exits - No Main Exit Provided
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Assembly spaces with an occupant load greater than 300 are usually provided with a main entrance. In addition to the main entrance providing egress other means of egress are required. Where a main entrance is provided the other required means of egress combined need to accommodate one-half of the occupant load of the space. Where the main entrance is not well defined or multiple main entries are provided the exits may be distributed around the exterior of the assembly space and must be able to accommodate at least 100 percent of the occupant load of the space. The required means of egress for each level of an assembly space must be arranged and separated from each other in accordance with section 1007.1

diagrams.title: Assembly: Other Exits - Main Exit Provided
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Assembly spaces with an occupant load greater than 300 are usually provided with a main entrance. In addition to the main entrance providing egress other means of egress are required. Where a main entrance is provided the other required means of egress combined need to accommodate one-half of the occupant load of the space. Where the main entrance is not well defined or multiple main entries are provided the exits may be distributed around the exterior of the assembly space and must be able to accommodate at least 100 percent of the occupant load of the space. The required means of egress for each level of an assembly space must be arranged and separated from each other in accordance with section 1007.1

diagrams.title: Egress: Min. Reqs., Existing Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1001.2 is to ensure that the means of egress in an existing building are not altered beyond what the code considers safe. It requires that the number of required exits is not reduced below the code required minimum for any area, space or building. It also requires that the means of egress width and capacity of the various means of egress elements that comprise the system are not reduced below the code required minimum and would apply to all required elements of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Separation of Exit and Exit Access Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Minimum separation of exits provides for the safe exit from a space, floor or building if one exit becomes blocked. Note that the separation distance applies to any part of the width of the doorway per 1007.1.1.1.

If scissor stairs (not shown here), are connected by a 1-hour fire resistance rated corridor per 1020, exit separation distance may be measured along the corridor. In order to use this measurement method, the corridor must meet the rating requirement, even if Table 1020.1 does not require a rating for the occupancy. The interconnected scissor stairs must also be fully separated per 1023.2.

diagrams.title: Remoteness of Exit Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Remoteness of exit access stairways or ramps refers to the concept where exits are placed a safe distance apart from each other. This helps ensure that if one exit is blocked or compromised in an emergency situation, occupants can still evacuate the building through alternative routes.

diagrams.title: Exterior Egress Door Arrangement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1022.2.2 is to ensure that exits lead to a location that provides adequate escape from the building upon exiting. It ensures that all exits provide adequate access to a public way, either directly or via an exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Required Exits: Three or More
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exits are required to be placed far enough apart to allow independent exiting if one exit is blocked.

UpCodes Note: The exact distance between the third (or forth) exit and the primary exits (first and second) is not clear. The requirement is a performance requirement that it must be a "reasonable" distance apart to provide use if one is blocked. Please check with your local building or fire official regarding the application of this section, as the interpretation of "reasonable distance" may be different between code officials and design professionals.

diagrams.title: Separation of a Third Stairway
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Separation of a third or more stairways from others are addressed simply by the statement that they "shall be arranged a reasonable distance apart so that if one becomes blocked, the others will be available.". However, in practice this may not be so easy. The shape of the building or lot might require the exit system from a third stairway to double back or be in close proximity to the second stairway. Alternately, local officials may determine that the design does not provide a reasonable distance apart, and may force a redesign of the building or an alternate means application might be required to provide compliance. In conditions where the placement of the third stair is in doubt, it's always a best practice to check with the building official and/or fire marshal to verify the placement of such stairs would be acceptable to the jurisdiction.

diagrams.title: Arrangement of Means of Egress: Apartments (NFPA)
Separation of Exit and Exit Access Doors (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Minimum separation of exits provides for the safe exit from a space, floor or building if one exit becomes blocked. Note that the separation distance applies to the nearest edges of the width of the doorway per Section 7.5.1.3.2, whereas the building code allows measurement to any point along the doorway.

children.displayTitle: Section 1007 Exit and Exit Access Doorway Configuration
children.titleText: Exit and Exit Access Doorway Configuration

children.body: Exits, exit access doorways, and exit access stairways and ramps serving spaces, including individual building stories, shall be separated in accordance with the provisions of this section.

Where two exits, exit access doorways, exit access stairways or ramps, or any combination thereof, are required from any portion of the exit access, they shall be placed a distance apart equal to not less than one-half of the length of the maximum overall diagonal dimension of the building or area to be served measured in a straight line between them. Interlocking or scissor stairways shall be counted as one exit stairway.
Exceptions:
  1. Where interior exit stairways or ramps are interconnected by a 1-hour fire-resistance-rated corridor conforming to the requirements of Section 1020, the required exit separation shall be measured along the shortest direct line of travel within the corridor.
  2. Where a building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2, the separation distance shall be not less than one-third of the length of the maximum overall diagonal dimension of the area served.

diagrams.title: Exit Separation Distance with Rated Corridors - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If exit stair enclosures are connected with a one-hour rated corridor, the required exit separation distance can be measured along the shortest direct line of travel within the corridor instead of the standard one-half of the diagonal of the area served (Building Code, Reference: 1007.1.1, Exception 1). The corridor must conform to the requirements of Sections 1020 and 708.

diagrams.title: Exit Stairways in Atriums
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways in atriums have several requirements to be met, per Section 404.10, in order for them to be used as an interior exit stairway. This shows the upper floor level of an atrium condition. The level of exit discharge shall comply with Section 1028.

Fire Partition Continuity: Corridors (Ex. 2.1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 708.4 Exception 2.1 more easily applies to floor construction that does not have cavities within, such as wood or light gauge metal joists. In those situations, special care needs to be paid to the detailing of the room side membrane extending to the floor/roof sheathing above.

diagrams.title: Fire Partition Continuity: Corridors (Ex. 2.2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 708.4 Exception 2.2 allows the presence of NFPA13 or NFPA13R (where allowed) automatic sprinkler systems above a fire partition to provide equivalent protection as the extension of the fire partitions at a corridor to the underside of the floor above.

children.titleText: Two Exits or Exit Access Doorways

children.body:
The separation distance required in Section 1007.1.1 shall be measured in accordance with the following:
  1. The separation distance to exit or exit access doorways shall be measured to any point along the width of the doorway.
  2. The separation distance to exit access stairways shall be measured to the closest riser.
  3. The separation distance to exit access ramps shall be measured to the start of the ramp run.

diagrams.title: Exits from Boiler, Incinerator and Furnace Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Boiler, incinerator, and furnace rooms house equipment that operate at high temperatures and pressures. If something goes wrong, there is a potential risk for fires or explosions. Having two exit access doorways ensures that if one exit becomes blocked or compromised, there is an alternative escape route available.

children.body: Where access to three or more exits is required, not less than two exit or exit access doorways shall be arranged in accordance with the provisions of Section 1007.1.1. Additional required exit or exit access doorways shall be arranged a reasonable distance apart so that if one becomes blocked, the others will be available.

diagrams.title: Stair Separations in High Rise Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairs in high-rise buildings are typically in a core that includes stairs and an elevator core. Separation of stairways is slightly less than typical buildings, possibly because of the central nature of the stairs to the occupied space. However, scissor stairs must only be considered as a single stair because in the event the stair is damaged or unable to service in an emergency, a scissor stair will not provide two independent ways out of the building. In the NYC Building Code, stairs sharing any common wall, floors, ceilings, scissor stair assemblies, or other enclosures shall be counted as one exit stairway.

children.displayTitle: 1007.1.2 Three or More Exits or Exit Access Doorways
children.titleText: Three or More Exits or Exit Access Doorways

children.body: Where two exit access stairways or ramps provide the required means of egress to exits at another story, the required separation distance shall be maintained for all portions of such exit access stairways or ramps.

This helps ensure that if one exit is blocked or compromised in an emergency situation, occupants can still evacuate the building through alternative routes.

children.displayTitle: 1007.1.3 Remoteness of Exit Access Stairways or Ramps
children.titleText: Remoteness of Exit Access Stairways or Ramps

children.body: Where more than two exit access stairways or ramps provide the required means of egress, not less than two shall be arranged in accordance with Section 1007.1.3.

diagrams.title: Illumination Level Under Normal Power
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Means of egress exit access flooring is required to be illuminated at not less than 1 fc. The walking surfaces of stairways and landings that are part of the means of egress are required to be illuminated at not less than 10 fc. The code has an exception for assembly spaces such as auditoriums, movie theaters and similar occupancies where during performances the exit access flooring illumination level may be reduced to 0.2 fc and steps, landings, and ramps may be marked with self-luminous materials. The exception is only allowed where the required illumination level is automatically provided when the fire alarm is activated.

diagrams.title: Lumens and Footcandles
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A footcandle is the measurement of the amount of light that falls on 1 sf of a surface and is dependent on the light source's intensity and the distance the surface being illuminated is from the light source. Lumens are a measurement of the amount of visible light emitted from a light source, in essences the brightness of the light source. The illumination level of a surface (footcandles) equals the Lumens per square foot that land on the surface, i.e. lumens / projected area in sf = footcandles of illumination.

diagrams.title: Emergency Electrical System: Locations for Illumination - Part 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1008.3 states that an emergency electrical system should provide automatic illumination during a power failure in specific areas to ensure safe egress. In rooms or buildings requiring two or more exits, this includes aisles, corridors, and exit access stairways and ramps. Also, at buildings that require two or more exits or access to exits, this includes interior exit access stairways and ramps, interior and exterior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, vestibules on level of discharge used for exit discharge, and exterior landings for exit doorways leading to discharge. Lastly, at other rooms and spaces, this includes electrical equipment rooms, fire command centers, fire pump rooms, generator rooms, and public restrooms larger than 300 SF.

children.body: Illumination shall be provided in the means of egress in accordance with Section 1008.2. In the event of power supply failure, means of egress illumination shall comply with Section 1008.3.

The means of egress serving a room or space shall be illuminated at all times that the room or space is occupied.
Exceptions:
  1. Occupancies in Group U.
  2. Self-service storage units 400 square feet (37.2 m2) or less in area and accessed directly from the exterior of the building.
  3. Aisle accessways in Group A.
  4. Dwelling units and sleeping units in Groups R-1, R-2 and R-3.
  5. Sleeping units of Group I occupancies.

The means of egress illumination level shall be not less than 1 footcandle (11 lux) at the walking surface. Along exit access stairways, exit stairways and at their required landings, the illumination level shall not be less than 10 footcandles (108 lux) at the walking surface when the stairway is in use.
Exception: For auditoriums, theaters, concert or opera halls and similar assembly occupancies, the illumination at the walking surface is permitted to be reduced during performances by one of the following methods provided that the required illumination is automatically restored upon activation of a premises' fire alarm system:
  1. Externally illuminated walking surfaces shall be permitted to be illuminated to not less than 0.2 footcandle (2.15 lux).
  2. Steps, landings and the sides of ramps shall be permitted to be marked with self-luminous materials in accordance with Sections 1025.2.1, 1025.2.2 and 1025.2.4 by systems listed in accordance with UL 1994.

children.body: In Group I-2 occupancies where two or more exits are required, on the exterior landings required by Section 1010.1.5, means of egress illumination levels for the exit discharge shall be provided such that failure of a single lamp in a luminaire shall not reduce the illumination level on that landing to less than 1 footcandle (11 lux).

Illumination shall be provided along the path of travel for the exit discharge from each exit to the public way.
Exception: Illumination shall not be required where the path of the exit discharge meets both of the following requirements:
  1. The path of exit discharge is illuminated from the exit to a safe dispersal area complying with Section 1028.5.
  2. A dispersal area shall be illuminated to a level not less than 1 footcandle (11 lux) at the walking surface.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Illumination:  Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit discharge pathways outside the building also require emergency exit illumination provisions. If egress is necessary in the dark to a designated area or public way, the pathway will need to be lit so occupants can safely egress the building. Note that in CA, special requirements exist in Section 1028.5 for exit discharge locations for Group E and for correctional facilities.

children.body: The power supply for means of egress illumination shall normally be provided by the premises' electrical supply.

An emergency electrical system shall be provided to automatically illuminate the following areas in the event of a power supply failure:
  1. In rooms or spaces that require two or more exits or access to exits:
    1.1.  Aisles. 
    1.2.  Corridors.
    1.3.  Exit access stairways and ramps.
  2. In buildings that require two or more exits or access to exits:
    2.1.  Interior exit access stairways and ramps.
    2.2.  Interior and exterior exit stairways and ramps.
    2.3.  Exit passageways.
    2.4.  Vestibules and areas on the level of discharge used for exit discharge in accordance with Section 1028.2.
    2.5.  Exterior landings as required by Section 1010.1.5 for exit doorways that lead directly to the exit discharge.
  3. In other rooms and spaces: 
    3.1.  Electrical equipment rooms.
    3.2.  Fire command centers.
    3.3.  Fire pump rooms.
    3.4.  Generator rooms.
    3.5.  Public restrooms with an area greater than 300 square feet (27.87 m2).

children.displayTitle: 1008.3 Illumination Required by an Emergency Electrical System
children.titleText: Illumination Required by an Emergency Electrical System

children.body: The emergency power system shall provide power for a duration of not less than 90 minutes and shall consist of storage batteries, unit equipment or an on-site generator. The installation of the emergency power system shall be in accordance with Section 2702.

Emergency lighting facilities shall be arranged to provide initial illumination that is not less than an average of 1 footcandle (11 lux) and a minimum at any point of 0.1 footcandle (1 lux) measured along the path of egress at floor level. Illumination levels shall be permitted to decline to 0.6 footcandle (6 lux) average and a minimum at any point of 0.06 footcandle (0.6 lux) at the end of the emergency lighting time duration. A maximum-to-minimum illumination uniformity ratio of 40 to 1 shall not be exceeded. In Group I-2 occupancies, failure of a single lamp in a luminaire shall not reduce the illumination level to less than 0.2 footcandle (2.2 lux).

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Area of Refuge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairways located in the accessible means of egress, shall either incorporate an area of refuge within enlarged floor-level landing or shall be accessed from an area of refuge complying with Section 1009.6.

An area of refuge is an area where persons unable to use stairways can remain temporarily to await instructions or assistance during an emergency evacuation.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order for stairways to be part of the accessible means of egress, there must be a clear distance of 48" minimum between the handrails. Exceptions exist for certain sprinkered buildings and stairs accessed from a refuge area related to a horizontal exit. The purpose of a stairway meeting these width requirements is to provide the width to allow two firemen to assist a wheelchair user down the stairs, one on each side of the person, or other related fire rescue operations.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairs: Accessible Means of Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1009.3.1 is to ensure that all different accessible floor areas and levels within the same story are provided with an accessible means of egress as required by section 1009.1. It does so by eliminating exit access stairways that interconnect different levels on the same story as part of an accessible means of egress. Section 1009.3.1 also provides a special exception for exit access stairways that serve mezzanines to be a part of an accessible means of egress.

diagrams.title: Exterior Area of Refuge at Exit
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Steep terrain and other constraints can make it difficult to provide an accessible means of egress from building exits to a public way. The building code requires an exterior area for assisted rescue, a protected area immediately outside a building exit, where a connecting accessible route to a public way from the level of exit discharge is not practicable.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance to Area of Refuge
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area of refuge adjacent to a stairwell is considered an a part of the exit feature itself. It is part of the area of higher protection afforded by a stairwell for the means of egress, as an exit component. Therefore, the exit travel distance should be measured to the area of refuge location.

children.body:
Accessible means of egress shall comply with this section. Accessible spaces shall be provided with not less than one accessible means of egress. Where more than one means of egress is required by Section 1006.2 or 1006.3 from any accessible space, each accessible portion of the space shall be served by not less than two accessible means of egress.
Exceptions:
  1. One accessible means of egress is required from an accessible mezzanine level in accordance with Section 1009.3, 1009.4 or 1009.5.
  2. In assembly areas with ramped aisles or stepped aisles, one accessible means of egress is permitted where the common path of egress travel is accessible and meets the requirements in Section 1030.8.

diagrams.title: Common Path of Egress Travel
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines COMMON PATH OF EGRESS TRAVEL. as that portion of exit access travel distance measured from the most remote point of each room, area or space to that point where the occupants have separate and distinct access to two exits or exit access doorways.

Common Path of Egress Travel limitations establish the maximum distance occupants may travel before optional egress route(s) must be provided. Rooms or spaces otherwise permitted to exist with one exit access route, by occupancy, use occupant load or stories, will require additional exit access when common path of egress travel exceeds values in Table 1006.2.1. Travel should be measured orthogonally and not as a direct diagonal. The path should be measured along the longest potential path around known and anticipated obstructions to travel, including partitions, tables, chairs, and other fixtures reasonably likely to occur in the space.

Most state codes refer to "Maximum Common Path of Egress Travel Distance" in Table 1006.2.1. New Jersey has amended the table to reference "Exit Access Travel Distance". Exit access travel distance (1017.3) is measured along the "natural and unobstructed path of horizontal... egress travel." This definition would suggest a case-by-case consideration of the appropriate path of travel through a room.

Where a second exit access is provided due to excessive common path of egress travel, the exit access shall be separated per 1007.1.1. Additionally, the separate exit access from a room or space shall provide access to independent exits. Two or more means of egress from a room or space that then converge to depend on a single exit are still considered a common path of egress travel, and do not meet the code intent.

children.body:
Each required accessible means of egress shall be continuous to a public way and shall consist of one or more of the following components:
  1. Accessible routes complying with Section 1104.
  2. Interior exit stairways complying with Sections 1009.3 and 1023.
  3. Exit access stairways complying with Sections 1009.3 and 1019.3 or 1019.4.
  4. Exterior exit stairways complying with Sections 1009.3 and 1027 and serving levels other than the level of exit discharge.
  5. Elevators complying with Section 1009.4.
  6. Platform lifts complying with Section 1009.5.
  7. Horizontal exits complying with Section 1026.
  8. Ramps complying with Section 1012.
  9. Areas of refuge complying with Section 1009.6.
  10. Exterior areas for assisted rescue complying with Section 1009.7 serving exits at the level of exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exit Egress Analysis
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When used correctly, in certain situations, use of a horizontal exit can reduce the number of stairways provided while maintaining a consistent level of protection for all occupants. With certain exceptions, horizontal exits are limited to satisfying no more than 50% of the required exits, exit capacity or exit width required from a space under consideration. They may not serve as the only exit from any space. The space to which a horizontal exit leads must be a public area, or occupied by the same tenant and shall serve as a refuge area. The refuge area must be of sufficient size to accommodate the occupants existing in the space and the occupants entering the space assuming 3 s.f. per person for the combined occupant load.

children.body:
In buildings where a required accessible floor is four or more stories above or below a level of exit discharge or where an accessible occupiable roof is above a story that is three or more stories above the level of exit discharge, not less than one required accessible means of egress shall include an elevator complying with Section 1009.4.
Exceptions:
  1. In buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2, the elevator shall not be required as part of the accessible means of egress on floors provided with a horizontal exit and located at or above the levels of exit discharge.
  2. In buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2, the elevator shall not be required as part of the accessible means of egress on floors or occupiable roofs provided with a ramp conforming to the provisions of Section 1012.

diagrams.title: Access. Means of Egress: Elevators
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In buildings with four or more stories above or below the level of exit discharge, at least one accessible means of egress must be an elevator with standby power and emergency signaling devices. Designed to remain operational even when regular electrical service is lost, they are used by emergency responders to move personnel and fire-fighting equipment and to provide assisted rescue. Like all elevators, they are not to be used independently by building occupants in emergencies.

children.body:
Where doors are part of an accessible route to provide access to an exit, area of refuge or exterior area of assisted rescue, maneuvering clearances shall be provided at such doors as required by ICC A117.1 in the direction of egress. Where doors lead to an area of refuge or exterior area for assisted rescue and reentry to the floor is possible, door maneuvering clearances shall be provided on both sides of the door.
Exception: Maneuvering clearances are not required at doors to exit stairways for levels above and below the level of exit discharge where the exit enclosure does not include an area of refuge.
In order to be considered part of an accessible means of egress, a stairway between stories shall comply with Sections 1009.3.1 through 1009.3.3.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairways located in the accessible means of egress, shall either incorporate an area of refuge within enlarged floor-level landing or shall be accessed from an area of refuge complying with Section 1009.6.

An area of refuge is an area where persons unable to use stairways can remain temporarily to await instructions or assistance during an emergency evacuation.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order for stairways to be part of the accessible means of egress, there must be a clear distance of 48" minimum between the handrails. Exceptions exist for certain sprinkered buildings and stairs accessed from a refuge area related to a horizontal exit. The purpose of a stairway meeting these width requirements is to provide the width to allow two firemen to assist a wheelchair user down the stairs, one on each side of the person, or other related fire rescue operations.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Areas of refuge are fire-resistance rated and smoke protected areas where those unable to use stairs can register a call for evacuation assistance and await instructions or assistance. They must provide direct access to an exit stairway (or to an elevator equipped with standby power). Horizontal exits can substitute for areas of refuge.

When areas of refuge are not designed to be directly in the stairway enclosure, the area of refuge must generally be directly adjacent to the stairway, accessible means-of-egress elevator. An exception exists for an interior area of refuge at the level of exit discharge that provides direct access to an exterior exit door. These are not required to be located adjacent to a stair or accessible means of egress elevator.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A means of egress is an unobstructed path to leave buildings, structures, and spaces. A means of egress is comprised of exit access, exit, and exit discharge. An accessible means of egress, as defined by the code, is a "continuous and unobstructed way of egress travel from any point in a building or facility that provides an accessible route to an area of refuge, a horizontal exit, or a public way." Where more than one means of egress is required from any accessible space, each accessible portion of the space must be served by at least two accessible means of egress. Accessible spaces can be served by one accessible means of egress only where the code permits one means of egress.

diagrams.title: Areas of Refuge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Areas of refuge provide fire and smoke protected areas where those unable to use stairs can register a call for help and await evacuation assistance. These areas must provide direct access to exit stairways and can be located adjacent to stairway enclosures or on stair landings outside the minimum exit width. Incidentally, the New York City Building Code refers to these as Areas of Rescue Assistance.

If areas of refuge are outside of an exit enclosure, they must be designed to minimize the intrusion of smoke by use of a smoke barrier or horizontal exit.

Conditions where areas of refuge have changed over various code cycles. Verify the requirement for the area of refuge so that the building is not altered to be out of compliance with the code it was constructed under.

children.body:
Exit access stairways that connect levels in the same story are not permitted as part of an accessible means of egress.
Exception: Exit access stairways providing means of egress from mezzanines are permitted as part of an accessible means of egress.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairs: Accessible Means of Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1009.3.1 is to ensure that all different accessible floor areas and levels within the same story are provided with an accessible means of egress as required by section 1009.1. It does so by eliminating exit access stairways that interconnect different levels on the same story as part of an accessible means of egress. Section 1009.3.1 also provides a special exception for exit access stairways that serve mezzanines to be a part of an accessible means of egress.

Exceptions:

diagrams.title: Hydraulic Elevator
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A hydraulic elevator is a type of power elevator in which the energy is applied by means of a liquid under pressure within a hydraulic jack.

diagrams.title: Example: Traction Elevator
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A traction elevator refers to an elevator system that uses a special type of driving machine. This machine works on the principle of traction, in which it relies on traction between the cables and the sheave (a grooved wheel that holds the cables) to control movement.

diagrams.title: Fire Recall Switches and Backup Power
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Commercial elevators have a safety feature called "fire recall" that sends them to a specific floor when fire alarms are activated so that emergency responders can use them. However, this feature could put the elevator cab and passengers at risk of flooding in areas where flooding is possible.

If an elevator is meant to serve areas that may flood, it should have a float switch system that will turn on when there is flooding and send the elevator cab to a floor above the base flood elevation (BFE).

This Section only applies to Elevators, escalators and moving walks. There is a special exception for where an elevator needs to be used to provide an accessible means of egress and requires the elevator to comply with section 1009.4. Section 1009.4 requires stand-by power may require an areas of refuge.

children.body: The elevator shall meet the emergency operation and signaling device requirements of Section 2.27 of ASME A17.1/CSA B44. Standby power shall be provided in accordance with Chapter 27 and Section 3003.

diagrams.title: Standby Power Systems
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standby and emergency standby power systems is an alternate source of power that is utilized to run critical systems when the primary power source fails. These are typically generators with an independent fuel source (diesel, gasoline, solar). Standby power systems are required to operate critical building systems, hazardous materials operations, and ventilation systems. Emergency standby power systems are required to operate life safety and fire alarm systems.

Standby power systems must automatically transfer on a power outage within 60 seconds, whereas emergency standby power systems must transfer within 10 seconds. Both of these systems are required to provide at least 2 hours of power. These systems must be UL 2200 listed, and be installed in accordance with IFC, NFPA 110, and NFPA 111. Section 2702.2 of the building code outlines specific occupancies and systems where these are required.

children.body:
The elevator shall be accessed from an area of refuge complying with Section 1009.6.
Exceptions:
  1. Areas of refuge are not required at the elevator in open parking garages.
  2. Areas of refuge are not required in buildings and facilities equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. Areas of refuge are not required at elevators not required to be located in a shaft in accordance with Section 712.
  4. Areas of refuge are not required at elevators serving smoke-protected or open-air assembly seating areas complying with Sections 1030.6.2 and 1030.6.3.
  5. Areas of refuge are not required for elevators accessed from a refuge area in conjunction with a horizontal exit.

Platform lifts shall be permitted to serve as part of an accessible means of egress where allowed as part of a required accessible route in Section 1110.11 except for Item 10. Standby power for the platform lift shall be provided in accordance with Chapter 27.

diagrams.title: Platform Lift Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Platform lifts may be used as part of an accessible means of egress under certain conditions. Inclined platform lifts may be used within dwelling units, but the stairways in which they exist must meet the requirements of Section 1011.2, Exception 3. Platform and stairway (inclined) chairlifts must meet the requirements of ASME A18.1.

diagrams.title: Vertical Platform Lifts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Vertical platform lifts, designed to provide short-distance vertical transportation for people with disabilities, typically include a platform that travels up and down along a vertical structure. These lifts can be either enclosed or non-enclosed, depending on the application and local code requirements. They can be installed both indoors and outdoors and are often used to provide access to raised entrances, stages, decks, or mezzanines.

Floor surfaces in platform lifts must comply with ADA Standards in sections 302 and 303. The controls for platform lifts should comply with ADA Standard section 309. Vertical platform lifts must not be attendant-operated, meaning they should allow for independent use by the person with a disability.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance to Area of Refuge
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area of refuge adjacent to a stairwell is considered an a part of the exit feature itself. It is part of the area of higher protection afforded by a stairwell for the means of egress, as an exit component. Therefore, the exit travel distance should be measured to the area of refuge location.

Every required area of refuge shall have direct access to a stairway complying with Sections 1009.3 and 1023 or an elevator complying with Section 1009.4.
Exception: An interior area of refuge at the level of exit discharge that provides direct access to an exterior exit door.

Such wheelchair spaces shall not reduce the means of egress minimum width or required capacity. Access to any of the required wheelchair spaces in an area of refuge shall not be obstructed by more than one adjoining wheelchair space.

diagrams.title: Exterior Area for Assisted Rescue
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Steep terrain and other constraints can make it difficult to provide an accessible means of egress from building exits to a public way. The building code requires an exterior area for assisted rescue, a protected area immediately outside a building exit, where a connecting accessible route to a public way from the level of exit discharge is not practicable.

Each area of refuge shall be separated from the remainder of the story by a smoke barrier complying with Section 709 or a horizontal exit complying with Section 1026. Each area of refuge shall be designed to minimize the intrusion of smoke.
Exceptions:
  1. Areas of refuge located within an enclosure for interior exit stairways complying with Section 1023.
  2. Areas of refuge in outdoor facilities where exit access is essentially open to the outside.
Areas of refuge shall be provided with a two-way communication system complying with Sections 1009.8.1 and 1009.8.2.

Exterior areas for assisted rescue shall be accessed by an accessible route from the area served.
Where the exit discharge does not include an accessible route from an exit located on the level of exit discharge to a public way, an exterior area of assisted rescue shall be provided on the exterior landing in accordance with Sections 1009.7.1 through 1009.7.4.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Basic Components
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Commentary:

The building code requires that a complete means of egress consist of three distinct parts: exit access, exit, and exit discharge. Exit access provides a clear and direct path to exits. An example is a corridor system. Exits are part of the building that provide a higher level of protection than the exit access. Examples include interior exit stairways and exit passageways. Exits then lead to the exit discharge.

The exit discharge provides a path of travel to the public way or safe dispersal area. While this looks straightforward in plan view, the interpretation and implementation can pose challenges when it's considered in three dimensions. Without reviewing site grading, what was budgeted as a sidewalk turns into an expensive stair and ramp combination.

The code defines a public way as at least 10 feet wide and open to the sky, but does not offer a prescriptive definition for safe dispersal areas—leaving it to the AHJ (Authority Having Jurisdiction) to determine what is acceptable. Designers must ensure that such areas are not only at least 50 feet away (per Section 1028) but also provide sufficient space for the expected occupant load, with at least 5 square feet per person.

It is critical to coordinate with landscape and civil disciplines early, since site grading, fencing, and even planting can unintentionally block or reduce the required egress path width.

diagrams.title: Exterior Area of Refuge at Exit
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Steep terrain and other constraints can make it difficult to provide an accessible means of egress from building exits to a public way. The building code requires an exterior area for assisted rescue, a protected area immediately outside a building exit, where a connecting accessible route to a public way from the level of exit discharge is not practicable.

children.body: Each exterior area for assisted rescue shall be sized to accommodate wheelchair spaces in accordance with Section 1009.6.3.

Exterior walls separating the exterior area of assisted rescue from the interior of the building shall have a minimum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour, rated for exposure to fire from the inside. The fire-resistance-rated exterior wall construction shall extend horizontally not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) beyond the landing on either side of the landing or equivalent fire-resistance-rated construction is permitted to extend out perpendicular to the exterior wall not less than 4 feet (1219 mm) on the side of the landing. The fire-resistance-rated construction shall extend vertically from the ground to a point not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) above the floor level of the area for assisted rescue or to the roof line, whichever is lower. Openings within such fire-resistance-rated exterior walls shall be protected in accordance with Section 716.
Exception: The fire-resistance rating and opening protectives are not required in the exterior wall where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.

The exterior area for assisted rescue shall be open to the outside air. The sides other than the separation walls shall be not less than 50 percent open, and the open area shall be distributed so as to minimize the accumulation of smoke or toxic gases.

Stairways that are part of the means of egress for the exterior area for assisted rescue shall provide a minimum clear width of 48 inches (1219 mm) between handrails.
Exception: The minimum clear width of 48 inches (1219 mm) between handrails is not required at stairways serving buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order for stairways to be part of the accessible means of egress, there must be a clear distance of 48" minimum between the handrails. Exceptions exist for certain sprinkered buildings and stairs accessed from a refuge area related to a horizontal exit. The purpose of a stairway meeting these width requirements is to provide the width to allow two firemen to assist a wheelchair user down the stairs, one on each side of the person, or other related fire rescue operations.

children.body:
A two-way communication system complying with Sections 1009.8.1 and 1009.8.2 shall be provided at the landing serving each elevator or bank of elevators on each accessible floor that is one or more stories above or below the level of exit discharge.
Exceptions:
  1. Two-way communication systems are not required at the landing serving each elevator or bank of elevators where the two-way communication system is provided within areas of refuge in accordance with Section 1009.6.5.
  2. Two-way communication systems are not required on floors provided with ramps conforming to the provisions of Section 1012.
  3. Two-way communication systems are not required at the landings serving only service elevators that are not designated as part of the accessible means of egress or serve as part of the required accessible route into a facility.
  4. Two-way communication systems are not required at the landings serving only freight elevators.
  5. Two-way communication systems are not required at the landing serving a private residence elevator.
  6. Two-way communication systems are not required in Group I-2 or I-3 facilities.
