children.body: Two-way communication systems shall provide communication between each required location and the fire command center or a central control point location approved by the fire department. Where the central control point is not a constantly attended location, the two-way communication system shall have timed, automatic telephone dial-out capability that provides two-way communication with an approved supervising station or emergency services. The two-way communication system shall include both audible and visible signals. Systems shall be listed in accordance with  UL 2525 and installed in accordance with NFPA 72.

Directions for the use of the two-way communication system, instructions for summoning assistance via the two-way communication system and written identification of the location shall be posted adjacent to the two-way communication system. Signage shall comply with the ICC A117.1 requirements for visual characters.

Signage indicating special accessibility provisions shall be provided as shown:
  1. Each door providing access to an area of refuge from an adjacent floor area shall be identified by a sign stating, "AREA OF REFUGE."
  2. Each door providing access to an exterior area for assisted rescue shall be identified by a sign stating, "EXTERIOR AREA FOR ASSISTED RESCUE."
Signage shall comply with the ICC A117.1 requirements for visual characters and include the International Symbol of Accessibility. Where exit sign illumination is required by Section 1013.3, the signs shall be illuminated. Additionally, visual characters, raised character and braille signage complying with ICC A117.1 shall be located at each door to an area of refuge and exterior area for assisted rescue in accordance with Section 1013.4.

diagrams.title: Exterior Area for Assisted Rescue
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Steep terrain and other constraints can make it difficult to provide an accessible means of egress from building exits to a public way. The building code requires an exterior area for assisted rescue, a protected area immediately outside a building exit, where a connecting accessible route to a public way from the level of exit discharge is not practicable.

children.body:
Directional signage indicating the location of all other means of egress and which of those are accessible means of egress shall be provided at the following:
  1. At exits serving a required accessible space but not providing an approved accessible means of egress.
  2. At elevator landings.
  3. Within areas of refuge.

In areas of refuge, exterior areas for assisted rescue and locations required to provide two-way communications systems complying with Section 1009.8, instructions on the use of the area under emergency conditions shall be posted. Signage shall comply with the ICC A117.1 requirements for visual characters. The instructions shall include all of the following:
  1. Persons able to use the exit stairway do so as soon as possible, unless they are assisting others.
  2. Information on planned availability of assistance in the use of stairs or supervised operation of elevators and how to summon such assistance.
  3. Directions for use of the two-way communication system where provided.

diagrams.title: Opaque Doors (ASHRAE)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: All opaque doors shall have a maximum U-factor as specified in Tables 5.5-0 through 5.5-8. Exceptions: non-swinging doors that are horizontally hinged sectional doors with a single row of fenestration whose area is at least 14% and no more than 25% of the total door area shall have an assembly U-factor less than or equal to 0.440 in Climate Zones 0 through 6 for conditioned spaces and in Climate Zones 3 through 6 for semi-heated spaces and less than or equal to 0.360 in Climate Zones 7 and 8, for both conditioned and semi-heated spaces.

children.body:
Doors in the means of egress shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1010.1.1 through 1010.3.4. Exterior exit doors shall also comply with the requirements of Section 1022.2. Gates in the means of egress shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1010.4 and 1010.4.1. Turnstiles in the means of egress shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1010.5 through 1010.5.4.
Doors, gates and turnstiles provided for egress purposes in numbers greater than required by this code shall comply with the requirements of this section.
Doors in the means of egress shall be readily distinguishable from the adjacent construction and finishes such that the doors are easily recognizable as doors. Mirrors or similar reflecting materials shall not be used on means of egress doors. Means of egress doors shall not be concealed by curtains, drapes, decorations or similar materials.

diagrams.title: Doors at Equipment Spaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where equipment spaces are only frequented by service personnel the codes do not require them to be accessible. The landings associated with access to the space may therefore be at different levels. The difference in landing elevations is limited to not create a stairway.

diagrams.title: Size of Means of Egress Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Width Exceptions:
Exception 1: Minimum width do not apply to doors in R-2 and R-3 dwelling units that are not required to be accessible and are not a required means of egress.
Exception 2: 28 inches minimum width is allowed at group I-3 sleeping units not required to be accessible.
Exception 3: No minimum width requirement for Doors to Storage closets that are less than 10 sf.
Exception 4: Maximum width of Revolving door leaves in compliance with section 1010.3.1 is not limited.
Exception 5: Maximum width of power-operated doors in compliance with 1010.1.3.2 is not limited.
Exception 8: In Groups I-1, R-2, R-3 and R-4, in dwelling and sleeping units that are not required to be Accessible, Type A or Type B units, the minimum clear opening widths shall not apply to interior egress doors.
Exception 9: Door openings required to be accessible within Type B units intended for user passage shall have a minimum clear opening width of 31.75 inches
Exception 10: Doors to walk-in freezers and coolers less than 1,000 square feet in area shall have a maximum width of 60 inches nominal.
Exception 11: Doors serving nonaccessible single-user shower or sauna compartments, toilet stalls or dressing, fitting, or changing rooms shall have a minimum clear opening width of 20 inches.

Height Exceptions:
Exception 6: Door openings within a dwelling or sleeping unit shall have a minimum clear height of 78 inches.
Exception 7: In dwelling and sleeping units not required to be accessible, Type A or Type B, exterior doors other than the required exit door shall have a minimum clear height of 76 inches.

diagrams.title: Glazing In / Adjacent to Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing in or adjacent to doors shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Building Code and Existing Building Code sections regarding Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies are to ensure that the occupants of habitable rooms in educational facilities and institutions that provide custodial care such as day cares are capable of exiting any room within the facility. This section is added because the occupants of these facilities often have limited capabilities or knowledge that needs to taken into account. These sections ensure that exit door operation is kept as simple and straight forward as possible for the users.

diagrams.title: Arrangement of Doors in Series
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1010.1.7 specifies how doors should swing if they are arranged in a series, but it does not provide a specific distance that determines when doors are no longer considered "in series". However, the spirit of the rule is meant to ensure that occupants moving between the doors should not be impeded or confused, especially during an emergency evacuation. Hence, the doors are considered "in series" if their operation could conceivably impact one another or potentially confuse an occupant trying to exit swiftly. In practice, an interpretation of what constitutes doors in a series is typically up to the local code official or fire marshal. It would be advisable to seek their input for any specific installation scenario. The ADA allows doors in series swinging into a space to be at least 48" from the end of the open door, to the end of the next open door. Be sure and verify that doors in series also meet any state, local or federal requirements for accessibility, or energy code requirements for vestibules.

diagrams.title: Glazing In / Adjacent to Doors - Except.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Most glazing in or adjacent to doors shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. However, there are several exceptions that permit non-safety glazing materials.

diagrams.title: Latching: Closet Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Closet doors need to be openable from within the closet to ensure the safety of occupants, especially in emergency situations. This requirement is in place to avoid trapping anyone accidentally inside the closet, allowing them to exit safely without the need for a key, tool, or special knowledge.

diagrams.title: Door Widths in Group R-2 / R-3
Width of Doors in I-2 with Stretchers
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1010.1.1 addresses the minimum egress door size where the movement of beds or stretchers is required in an I-2 Occupancy. The minimum required clear opening height is 80 inches and the minimum clear width is 41-1/2 inches. When a door opening contains two door leaves, one leaf is required to provide the minimum clear width.

Doors to specialized areas of hospitals may be required to be wider by the locally adopted standards for hospitals. For example, the Facilities Guidelines Institute standards (2022) requires door openings for patient rooms and diagnostic and treatment areas such as X-ray, surgery, or physical therapy, to be 44-1/2" wide.

diagrams.title: Stairway Door Operations - Excpt. 4 & 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Interior stairway means of egress doors shall be openable from both sides without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.

Exception 4 states that stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group B, F, M, and S occupancies where the only interior access to the tenant space is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

Exception 5 states that stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group R-2 occupancies where the only interior access to the dwelling unit is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

diagrams.title: Stairway Door Operations - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior stairway means of egress doors shall be openable from both sides without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort. However, exception 1 states that stairway discharge doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side.

diagrams.title: Security Grilles
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Security grilles such as those typically installed at retail tenant space entries are allowed at the main exit at group B, F, M and S occupancies. If the space requires 2 or more exits not more than one-half of the required exits may have a horizontal or vertical security gate. Security gates must be openable by occupants from the inside without the use of a key, special knowledge or effort when the space is occupied.

diagrams.title: Door Opening Forces: Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Typical door forces for non-fire rated doors is 5 pounds. The ADA allows the administrative authority to establish the pull force for fire doors. These are typically established in the building, fire and life safety codes.

ADA Advisory 404.2.9 Door and Gate Opening Force. The maximum force pertains to the continuous application of force necessary to fully open a door, not the initial force needed to overcome the inertia of the door. It does not apply to the force required to retract bolts or to disengage other devices used to keep the door in a closed position.

diagrams.title: Door Hardware Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Accessible doors have specific requirements for items such as hardware and vision lights so that they may be used by people operating the door from a wheelchair. Other features such as the 10" smooth surface prevents canes, wheelchairs, and walkers from getting caught on projections found on the door's surface. Items that extend into this range such as extended door handles, locking hardware at the floor, surface mounted locking bolts, decorative surfaces that are more than 1/16" deep/high and other similar features do not comply with the 10" smooth surface requirements.

diagrams.title: Stadium Gates
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When all of the following conditions are met the gates utilized by the public to exit a stadium are not required to have panic hardware. The gates are under constant immediate supervision when the public is present Safe dispersal areas providing an aggregate area of 3 sf per occupant within the gated area are provided. The dispersal areas are located no less than 50 feet from the enclosed space.

diagrams.title: Entry Door: 180° Viewer
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A peephole, also known as a door viewer, is a small opening or lens installed in a door, allowing people inside a building to see who is outside, without having to open the door. Peepholes provide a 180-degree range of view, enhancing the security and privacy of the occupants.

diagrams.title: Exits through Lobbies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Lobbies, often classified as Group A-3 occupancies or accessory to another Group A occupancy, are frequently gathering or waiting spaces for other assembly areas, or for a catchment area between the public and private areas of a building. The code allows the number of lobby exits only to be based on the occupant load of the lobby, but the width of the exits must be sufficiently sized for the cumulative occupant load. In the example shown, at least three 36" wide doors (assuming 34" actual opening width, with door at 90 degree open angle) would be required to provide the 95.5" min. width.

Doors: Types & Openings (Hospitals)

diagrams.descriptionHtml: The clear width is measured from the stop to the face of doors or gates open 90° (or to the leading edge of sliding or folding doors. No projection into the clear width is permitted below 34".

diagrams.title: Doors: Min. Required Clear Opening Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A door has to be at least 32" minimum clear width to provide enough space for people with mobility impairments or those who use mobility aids (such as wheelchairs, walkers or crutches) to pass through comfortably. diagrams.title: Ext. Doors and the Public Way
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Windows and door are not permitted to open or project into the public right-of-way.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

diagrams.title: Encroachments of Public Way at Steps and Awnings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to the building code, architectural elements that are above grade but below 8 feet are not permitted to encroach into the public right-of-way. Steps are permitted to encroach into the right-of-way a maximum of 12 inches as long as they are guarded by either an approved device that is a minimum of 3 feet in height or they are situated between columns or pilasters. Such columns or pilasters are not permitted to project more than 12 inches into the public right-of-way either. When awnings are provided above the stairs, the vertical clearance from the public right-of-way to the lowest portion of any awning, shall be not less than 7 feet.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Doors in Group H occupancies and for egress doors serving spaces or rooms of more than 50 people are required to swing in the direction of egress travel. diagrams.title: Sliding Pocket Door (FHA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the FHA Design Manual: "The traditional handle and latch installed in pocket doors are difficult for many people to operate because the hardware is recessed into the face of the door so the door can slide completely into the wall pocket. If carefully monitored, it may be possible to install a 32-inch wide pocket door that yields a nominal 32-inch clear opening; however, without modifying the door hardware, the door is still difficult to open and close. Lacking complete control of variables such as the specific manufacturer's design of the door track assembly, the builder's installation method, the decision to install door stops (which vary in thickness), and other field conditions, it is recommended that pocket doors wider than 32 inches be installed. If a 36-inch wide door is installed, residents may make the following simple modifications later so the door is easier to operate: add loop handles on the door and a stop at the floor to prevent the door from sliding so far into the wall pocket that the handle is tight against the door jamb. This ensures that when the door is in the open position the handle will remain exposed and 32 inches will remain clear for passage.

State and local codes and regulations should be consulted. In addition, if a project scoping falls under the scoping of both the FHA and ADA Standards, the most restrictive of both sets of regulations apply, per DOJ / HUD Joint statement and the Advisory 224.1, in addition to state and local regulations.

The forces to unlatch doors shall comply with the following:
  1. Where door hardware operates by push or pull, the operational force to unlatch the door shall not exceed 15 pounds (67 N).
  2. Where door hardware operates by rotation, the operational force to unlatch the door shall not exceed 28 inch-pounds (315 N-cm).
The force to open doors shall comply with the following:
  1. For interior swinging egress doors that are manually operated, other than doors required to be fire rated, the force for pushing or pulling open the door shall not exceed 5 pounds (22 N).
  2. For other swinging doors, sliding doors or folding doors, and doors required to be fire rated, the door shall require not more than a 30-pound (133 N) force to be set in motion and shall move to a full-open position when subjected to not more than a 15-pound (67 N) force.

children.titleText: Forces to Unlatch and Open Doors

children.body: Forces shall be applied to the latch side of the door.
Where a manual horizontal sliding door is required to latch, the latch or other mechanism shall prevent the door from rebounding into a partially open position when the door is closed.

There shall be a floor or landing on each side of a door. Such floor or landing shall be at the same elevation on each side of the door. Landings shall be level except for exterior landings, which are permitted to have a slope not to exceed 0.25 unit vertical in 12 units horizontal (2-percent slope).
Exceptions:
  1. At doors serving individual dwelling units or sleeping units in Groups R-2 and R-3, a door is permitted to open at the top step of an interior flight of stairs, provided that the door does not swing over the top step.
  2. At exterior doors serving Groups F, H, R-2 and S and where such doors are not part of an accessible route, the landing at an exterior door shall not be more than 7 inches (178 mm) below the landing on the egress side of the door, provided that the door, other than an exterior storm or screen door, does not swing over the landing.
  3. At exterior doors serving Group U and individual dwelling units and sleeping units in Groups R-2 and R-3, and where such units are not required to be Accessible units, Type A units or Type B units, the landing at an exterior doorway shall be not more than 73/4 inches (197 mm) below the landing on the egress side of the door. Such doors, including storm or screen doors, shall be permitted to swing over either landing.
  4. Variations in elevation due to differences in finish materials, but not more than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm).
  5. Exterior decks, patios or balconies that are part of Type B dwelling units or sleeping units, that have impervious surfaces and that are not more than 4 inches (102 mm) below the finished floor level of the adjacent interior space of the dwelling unit or sleeping unit.
  6. Doors serving equipment spaces not required to be accessible in accordance with Section 1103.2.9 and serving an occupant load of five or less shall be permitted to have a landing on one side to be not more than 7 inches (178 mm) above or below the landing on the egress side of the door.

diagrams.title: Doors at Equipment Spaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where equipment spaces are only frequented by service personnel the codes do not require them to be accessible. The landings associated with access to the space may therefore be at different levels. The difference in landing elevations is limited to not create a stairway.

diagrams.title: Floor elevation at Required Egress Doors

children.body:
Landings shall have a width not less than the width of the stairway or the door, whichever is greater. Doors in the fully open position shall not reduce a required dimension by more than 7 inches (178 mm). Where a landing serves an occupant load of 50 or more, doors in any position shall not reduce the landing to less than one-half its required width. Landings shall have a length measured in the direction of travel of not less than 44 inches (1118 mm).
Exception: Landing length in the direction of travel in Groups R-3 and U and within individual units of Group R-2 need not exceed 36 inches (914 mm).

diagrams.title: Stair Landings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stair landings are required to be of a minimum dimension to provide for changing directions and to provide sufficient space for the safe opening of a door onto a stair landing.

Exceptions:
  1. In occupancy Group R-2 or R-3, threshold heights for sliding and side-hinged exterior doors shall be permitted to be up to 73/4 inches (197 mm) in height if all of the following apply:
    1.1.  The door is not part of the required means of egress.
    1.2.  The door is not part of an accessible route as required by Chapter 11.
    1.3.  The door is not part of an Accessible unit, Type A unit or Type B unit.
  2. In Type B units, where Exception 5 to Section 1010.1.4 permits a 4-inch (102 mm) elevation change at the door, the threshold height on the exterior side of the door shall not exceed 43/4 inches (120 mm) in height above the exterior deck, patio or balcony for sliding doors or 41/2 inches (114 mm) above the exterior deck, patio or balcony for other doors.

Space between two doors in a series shall be 48 inches (1219 mm) minimum plus the width of a door swinging into the space. Doors in a series shall swing either in the same direction or away from the space between the doors.
Exceptions:
  1. The minimum distance between horizontal sliding power-operated doors in a series shall be 48 inches (1219 mm).
  2. Storm and screen doors serving individual dwelling units in Groups R-2 and R-3 need not be spaced 48 inches (1219 mm) from the other door.
  3. Doors within individual dwelling units in Groups R-2 and R-3 other than within Type A dwelling units.
