Interior stairway means of egress doors shall be openable from both sides without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.

Exception 4 states that stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group B, F, M, and S occupancies where the only interior access to the tenant space is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

Exception 5 states that stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group R-2 occupancies where the only interior access to the dwelling unit is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

diagrams.title: Stairway Door Operations - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior stairway means of egress doors shall be openable from both sides without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort. However, exception 1 states that stairway discharge doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side.

diagrams.title: Doors: Swing & Hardware (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Hospital Guidelines, Except for doors serving non-habitable spaces, doors may not swing into corridors unless provided with an alcove that is deep enough to contain the door swing. Latching lever or push/pull type strike side hardware is required on doors except for some operating room conditions. Operating rooms in a designated suite that do not open to an egress corridor are not required to have latching hardware and may be self-closing with push/pull plates.

diagrams.title: Door Hardware Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code defines acceptable hardware mounting heights for that are a part of the means of egress. Handles, pulls, latches locks other operating devices are required to be from 34" minimum to 48" maximum above the finish floor. Locks used only for security purposes may be at any height provided the lock is not used for normal operation of the door. The code makes an exception for doors and gates that are part of a barrier for pools, spas or hot tubs, which may have the latch release for the self-latching device not more than 54" above the finish floor.

children.body:
The unlatching of any door or leaf for egress shall require not more than one motion in a single linear or rotational direction to release all latching and all locking devices. locking devices. Manual bolts are not permitted.
Exceptions:
  1. Places of detention or restraint.
  2. Doors with manual bolts, automatic flush bolts and constant latching bolts as permitted by Section 1010.2.4, Item 4.
  3. Doors from individual dwelling units and sleeping units of Group R occupancies as permitted by Section 1010.2.4, Item 5.
Door handles, pulls, latches, locks and other operating devices on doors required to be accessible by Chapter 11 shall not require tight grasping, tight pinching or twisting of the wrist to operate.

diagrams.title: Door Hardware Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Accessible doors have specific requirements for items such as hardware and vision lights so that they may be used by people operating the door from a wheelchair. Other features such as the 10" smooth surface prevents canes, wheelchairs, and walkers from getting caught on projections found on the door's surface. Items that extend into this range such as extended door handles, locking hardware at the floor, surface mounted locking bolts, decorative surfaces that are more than 1/16" deep/high and other similar features do not comply with the 10" smooth surface requirements.

children.body:
Door handles, pulls, latches, locks and other operating devices shall be installed 34 inches (864 mm) minimum and 48 inches (1219 mm) maximum above the finished floor.
Exceptions:
  1.  Locks used only for security purposes and not used for normal operation are permitted at any height.
  2. Where the International Swimming Pool and Spa Code requires restricting access to a pool, spa or hot tub, and where door and gate latch release mechanisms are accessed from the outside of the barrier and are not of the self-locking type, such a mechanism shall be located above the finished floor or ground surface not less than 52 inches (1219 mm) and not greater than 54 inches (1370 mm), provided that the latch release mechanism is not a self-locking type such as where the lock is operated by means of a key, electronic opener or the entry of a combination into an integral combination lock.

diagrams.title: Door Hardware Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Accessible doors have specific requirements for items such as hardware and vision lights so that they may be used by people operating the door from a wheelchair. Other features such as the 10" smooth surface prevents canes, wheelchairs, and walkers from getting caught on projections found on the door's surface. Items that extend into this range such as extended door handles, locking hardware at the floor, surface mounted locking bolts, decorative surfaces that are more than 1/16" deep/high and other similar features do not comply with the 10" smooth surface requirements.

diagrams.title: Door Hardware Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code defines acceptable hardware mounting heights for that are a part of the means of egress. Handles, pulls, latches locks other operating devices are required to be from 34" minimum to 48" maximum above the finish floor. Locks used only for security purposes may be at any height provided the lock is not used for normal operation of the door. The code makes an exception for doors and gates that are part of a barrier for pools, spas or hot tubs, which may have the latch release for the self-latching device not more than 54" above the finish floor.

children.body:
Locks and latches shall be permitted to prevent operation of doors where any of the following exist:
  1. Places of detention or restraint.
  2. In Group I-1, Condition 2 and Group I-2 occupancies where the clinical needs of persons receiving care require containment or where persons receiving care pose a security threat, provided that all clinical staff can readily unlock doors at all times, and all such locks are keyed to keys carried by all clinical staff at all times or all clinical staff have the codes or other means necessary to operate the locks at all times.
  3. In buildings in occupancy Group A having an occupant load of 300 or less, Groups B, F, M and S, and in places of religious worship, the main door or doors are permitted to be equipped with key-operated locking devices from the egress side provided that:
    3.1.  The doors are the main exterior doors to the building, or the doors are the main doors to the tenant space.
    3.2.  The locking device is readily distinguishable as locked.
    3.3.  A readily visible durable sign is posted on the egress side on or adjacent to the door stating: THIS DOOR TO REMAIN UNLOCKED WHEN THIS SPACE IS OCCUPIED. The sign shall be in letters 1 inch (25 mm) high on a contrasting background.
    3.4.  The use of the key-operated locking device is revocable by the building official for due cause.
  4. Manual bolts, automatic flush bolts and constant latching bolts on the inactive leaf of a pair of doors in accordance with Table 1010.2.4, provided that the inactive leaf does not have a doorknob, panic hardware, or similar operating hardware.
  5. Doors from individual dwelling or sleeping units of Group R occupancies permitted to have a single exit in accordance with Section 1006.2.1 or 1006.3.4 are permitted to be equipped with a night latch, dead bolt, manual bolt, or security chain, that requires a second releasing motion, provided such devices are openable from the inside without the use of a key or tool.
  6. Fire doors after the minimum elevated temperature has disabled the unlatching mechanism in accordance with listed fire door test procedures.
  7. Doors serving roofs not intended to be occupied shall be permitted to be locked preventing entry to the building from the roof.
  8. Other than egress courts, where occupants must egress from an exterior space through the building for means of egress, exit access doors shall be permitted to be equipped with an approved locking device where installed and operated in accordance with all of the following:
    8.1.  The maximum occupant load shall be posted where required by Section 1004.9. Such signage shall be permanently affixed inside the building and shall be posted in a conspicuous space near all the exit access doorways.
    8.2.  A weatherproof telephone or two-way communication system installed in accordance with Sections 1009.8.1 and 1009.8.2 shall be located adjacent to not less than one required exit access door on the exterior side.
    8.3.  The egress door locking device is readily distinguishable as locked and shall be a key-operated locking device.
    8.4.  A clear window or glazed door opening, not less than 5 square feet (0.46 m2) in area, shall be provided at each exit access door to determine if there are occupants using the outdoor area.
    8.5.  A readily visible, durable sign shall be posted on the interior side on or adjacent to each locked required exit access door serving the exterior area stating, "THIS DOOR TO REMAIN UNLOCKED WHEN THE OUTDOOR AREA IS OCCUPIED." The letters on the sign shall be not less than 1 inch (25.4 mm) high on a contrasting background.
    8.6.  The occupant load of the occupied exterior area shall not exceed 300 occupants in accordance with Section 1004.
  9. Locking devices are permitted on doors to balconies, decks or other exterior spaces serving individual dwelling or sleeping units.
  10. Locking devices are permitted on doors to balconies, decks or other exterior spaces of 250 square feet (23.23 m2) or less serving a private office space.
Closet doors that latch in the closed position shall be openable from inside the closet.

diagrams.title: Latching: Closet Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Closet doors need to be openable from within the closet to ensure the safety of occupants, especially in emergency situations. This requirement is in place to avoid trapping anyone accidentally inside the closet, allowing them to exit safely without the need for a key, tool, or special knowledge.

diagrams.title: Return Air Openings - Closet
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The mechanical code allows for return air openings to be located in closets. Return air openings in closets are only allowed to serve the return air needs of the closet space itself and are not meant to also draw air from from other rooms. If the closet is less than 30 sf the mechanical code calls for an additional opening with 30 square inches of net free area. The additional opening may be an air transfer grille, a louvered door or a door undercut that is a minimum of 1-1/2".

diagrams.title: Return Air Openings - Closet <30 sf ft
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The mechanical code allows for return air openings to be located in closets. Return air openings in closets are only allowed to serve the return air needs of the closet space itself and are not meant to also draw air from from other rooms. If the closet is less than 30 sf the mechanical code calls for an additional opening with 30 square inches of net free area. The additional opening may be an air transfer grille, a louvered door or a door undercut that is a minimum of 1-1/2".

children.body:
Interior stairway means of egress doors shall be openable from both sides without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.
Exceptions:
  1. Stairway discharge doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side.
  2. This section shall not apply to doors arranged in accordance with Section 403.5.3.
  3. Stairway exit doors shall not be locked from the side opposite the egress side, unless they are openable from the egress side and capable of being unlocked simultaneously without unlatching by all of the following methods:
    3.1.  Shall be capable of being unlocked individually or simultaneously upon a signal from the fire command center, where present, or a signal by emergency personnel from a single location inside the main entrance to the building.
    3.2.  Shall unlock simultaneously upon activation of a fire alarm signal when a fire alarm system is present in an area served by the stairway.
    3.3.  Shall unlock upon failure of the power supply to the electric lock or the locking system.
  4. Stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group B, F, M and S occupancies where the only interior access to the tenant space is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.
  5. Stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group R-2 occupancies where the only interior access to the dwelling unit is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

diagrams.title: Stairway Door Operations - Excpt. 4 & 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Interior stairway means of egress doors shall be openable from both sides without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.

Exception 4 states that stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group B, F, M, and S occupancies where the only interior access to the tenant space is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

Exception 5 states that stairway exit doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side in Group R-2 occupancies where the only interior access to the dwelling unit is from a single exit stairway where permitted in Section 1006.3.4.

diagrams.title: Stairway Door Operations - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior stairway means of egress doors shall be openable from both sides without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort. However, exception 1 states that stairway discharge doors shall be openable from the egress side and shall only be locked from the opposite side.

children.body:
In Group E occupancies, Group B educational occupancies and Group I-4 occupancies, egress doors from classrooms, offices and other occupied rooms with locking arrangements designed to keep intruders from entering the room shall comply with all of the following conditions:
  1. The door shall be capable of being unlocked from outside the room with a key or other approved means.
  2. The door shall be openable from within the room in accordance with Section 1010.2.
  3. Modifications shall not be made to listed panic hardware, fire door hardware or door closers.
  4. Modifications to fire door assemblies shall be in accordance with NFPA 80.
Remote locking or unlocking of doors from an approved location shall be permitted in addition to the unlocking operation in Item 1.

diagrams.title: Group I-4 Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1006.2.1 (2021 and 2024) outlines how the code considers the varying evacuation needs of different occupancies. It modifies the criteria for requiring two exits based on three factors: the occupancy group, the occupant load, and the common path of egress travel. For instance, an I-4 daycare occupancy has a low threshold, requiring more than 10 occupants for two exits, compared to a B office occupancy, which requires more than 49 occupants. This distinction acknowledges that occupants in a B office can evacuate quickly and independently, while daycare occupants may need assistance and more time, necessitating more accessible egress options.

diagrams.title: Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Building Code and Existing Building Code sections regarding Locking Arrangements in Educational Occupancies are to ensure that the occupants of habitable rooms in educational facilities and institutions that provide custodial care such as day cares are capable of exiting any room within the facility. This section is added because the occupants of these facilities often have limited capabilities or knowledge that needs to taken into account. These sections ensure that exit door operation is kept as simple and straight forward as possible for the users.

children.body:
Swinging doors serving a Group H occupancy and swinging doors serving rooms or spaces with an occupant load of 50 or more in a Group A or E occupancy shall not be provided with a latch or lock other than panic hardware or fire exit hardware.
Exceptions:
  1. A main exit of a Group A occupancy shall be permitted to have locking devices in accordance with Section 1010.2.4, Item 3.
  2. Doors provided with panic hardware or fire exit hardware and serving a Group A or E occupancy shall be permitted to be electrically locked in accordance with Section 1010.2.10.
  3. Exit access doors serving occupied exterior areas shall be permitted to be locked in accordance with Section 1010.2.4, Item 8.
  4. Courtrooms shall be permitted to be locked in accordance with Section 1010.2.12, Item 3.

diagrams.title: Door Swing Direction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Doors in Group H occupancies and for egress doors serving spaces or rooms of more than 50 people are required to swing in the direction of egress travel. Other requirements such as panic or fire-exit hardware, strike-side pull clearances, intrusions on corridor widths,or intrusions into the public way should also be considered for secondary effects on the design.

children.body: Refrigeration machinery rooms larger than 1,000 square feet (93 m2) shall have not less than two exit or exit access doorways that swing in the direction of egress travel and shall be equipped with panic hardware or fire exit hardware.

diagrams.title: Refrigeration Machinery Rooms: Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Refrigeration machinery rooms can contain hazardous materials, like refrigerants that could leak and displace oxygen, leading to asphyxiation risks. If there's a leak or a fire, personnel inside the room might need an immediate escape route. Having two exits ensures that if one is blocked or compromised, there's a secondary route to safety.

children.body: Exit or exit access doors serving transformer vaults, rooms designated for batteries or energy storage systems, or modular data centers shall be equipped with panic hardware or fire exit hardware. Rooms containing electrical equipment rated 800 amperes or more that contain overcurrent devices, switching devices or control devices and where the exit or exit access door is less than 25 feet (7620 mm) from the equipment working space as required by NFPA 70, such doors shall not be provided with a latch or lock other than panic hardware or fire exit hardware. The doors shall swing in the direction of egress travel.

diagrams.title: Rooms w/ Electrical Equipment: Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit or exit access doors that serve electrical equipment rooms must swing in the direction of egress travel. In the event of a power failure an emergency electrical system shall automatically provide lighting in electrical equipment rooms. If the room or space served by the exit doorway contains a transformer, an energy storage system such as batteries or a modular data center the exit doorway is required to be equipped with panic or fire exit hardware. If the electrical equipment served by the exit doorway is rated 800 amperes or more and contains overcurrent devices, switching devices or control devices, and the doorway is less than 25 feet from the required working space for the equipment, then the door shall not be provided with a latch or lock other than panic hardware or fire exit hardware.

diagrams.title: Doors at Equipment Spaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where equipment spaces are only frequented by service personnel the codes do not require them to be accessible. The landings associated with access to the space may therefore be at different levels. The difference in landing elevations is limited to not create a stairway.

diagrams.title: Elect. Equip.: Entrance/Egress from Working Space, pt. 1
Elect. Equip.: Entrance/Egress from Working Space, pt. 3
Elect. Equip.: Entrance/Egress from Working Space, pt. 2
Clearances at Electrical Equipment
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The depth of working space in front of equipment that is less than 1000V is dependent on one of three conditions. Condition 1: Exposed live parts on one side of the working space. Condition 2: Exposed live parts on one side and grounded parts or concrete walls on the other. Condition 3: Exposed live parts on both sides.

Voltage ranges can be three ranges: 0-150 Volts to ground (all your 120/240 or 120/208 panels); 151-600 Volts to ground (all your 277/480 volt panels, transformers); 601-1000 Volts to ground (Higher voltage equipment).

Visualize that you are standing in front of a panel with exposed live parts. Then assess what is behind you, and what voltage the voltage of the equipment that is in front of you.

diagrams.title: Electrical Working Space Conditions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The minimum required depth of working space in front of electrical equipment must meet the minimum distances specified in Table 110.26(A)(1) based on voltage to ground and the opposing surface per condition, unless exceptions requirements are met. Condition 1 provides that exposed live parts do not have live or grounded parts opposing it, or exposed live parts on both sides of working space are guarded by insulating materials. Condition 2 provides that exposed live parts are opposite grounded parts. Lastly, condition 3 provides that exposed live parts are opposite each other on both sides of working space.

diagrams.title: Allowed Clearance at Open Equipment Doors (<1000V)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A path 24" wide by 6-1/2 feet tall must be provided for access to and egress from the work space required for electrical equipment. Equipment doors in an open position may not restrict the required access and egress from electrical work spaces. Access and egress from and electrical work space is considered to be restricted if the path is reduced to be less than 24" wide or less than 6-1/2 feet tall.

children.body:
Where panic or fire exit hardware is installed, it shall comply with the following:
  1. Panic hardware shall be listed in accordance with UL 305.
  2. Fire exit hardware shall be listed in accordance with UL 10C and UL 305.
  3. The actuating portion of the releasing device shall extend not less than one-half of the door leaf width.
  4. The maximum unlatching force shall not exceed 15 pounds (67 N).

If balanced doors are used and panic hardware is required, the panic hardware shall be the push-pad type and the pad shall not extend more than one-half the width of the door measured from the latch side.

Where electrical systems that monitor or record egress activity are incorporated, or where the door has an access control system, the locking system on the egress side of the door shall comply with Section 1010.2.10, 1010.2.11, 1010.2.12, 1010.2.13, 1010.2.14 or 1010.2.15 or shall be readily openable from the egress side without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.
children.displayTitle: 1010.2.9 Monitored or Recorded Egress, and Access Control Systems
children.titleText: Monitored or Recorded Egress, and Access Control Systems

children.body:
Door hardware release of electrical locking systems shall be permitted on doors in the means of egress in any occupancy except Group H where installed and operated in accordance with all of the following:
  1. The door hardware that is affixed to the door leaf has an obvious method of operation that is readily operated under all lighting conditions.
  2. The door hardware is capable of being operated with one hand and shall comply with Section 1010.2.1.
  3. Operation of the door hardware directly interrupts the power to the electric lock and unlocks the door immediately.
  4. Loss of power to the electrical locking system automatically unlocks the electric lock.
  5. Where panic or fire exit hardware is required by Section 1010.2.8, operation of the panic or fire exit hardware also releases the electric lock.
  6. The electromechanical or electromagnetic locking device shall be listed in accordance with either UL 294 or UL1034.
children.displayTitle: 1010.2.10 Door Hardware Release of Electrically Locked Egress Doors
children.titleText: Door Hardware Release of Electrically Locked Egress Doors

children.body:
Sensor release of electrical locking systems shall be permitted on doors located in the means of egress in any occupancy except Group H where installed and operated in accordance with all of the following criteria:
  1. The sensor shall be installed on the egress side, arranged to detect an occupant approaching the doors, and shall cause the electrical locking system to unlock the electric lock.
  2. Upon a signal from a sensor or loss of power to the sensor, the electrical locking system shall unlock the electric lock.
  3. Loss of power to the electric lock or the electrical locking system shall automatically unlock the electric locks.
  4. The doors shall be arranged to unlock the electric lock from a manual unlocking device located 40 inches to 48 inches (1016 mm to 1219 mm) vertically above the floor and within 5 feet (1524 mm) of the secured doors. Ready access shall be provided to the manual unlocking device and the device shall be clearly identified by a sign that reads "PUSH TO EXIT." When operated, the manual unlocking device shall result in direct interruption of power to the electric lock—independent of other electronics—and the electric lock shall remain unlocked for not less than 30 seconds.
  5. Activation of the building fire alarm system, where provided, shall automatically unlock the electric lock, and the electric lock shall remain unlocked until the fire alarm system has been reset.
  6. Activation of the building automatic sprinkler system or fire detection system, where provided, shall automatically unlock the electric lock. The electric lock shall remain unlocked until the fire alarm system has been reset.
  7. Emergency lighting shall be provided on the egress side of the door.
  8. The electromechanical or electromagnetic locking device shall be listed in accordance with either UL 294 or UL 1034.
children.displayTitle: 1010.2.11 Sensor Release of Electrically Locked Egress Doors
children.titleText: Sensor Release of Electrically Locked Egress Doors

children.body:
Delayed egress electrical locking systems shall be permitted on doors in the means of egress serving the following occupancies in buildings that are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or an approved automatic smoke or heat detection system installed in accordance with Section 907.
  1. Group B, F, I, M, R, S and U occupancies.
  2. Group E classrooms with an occupant load of less than 50.
  3. In courtrooms in Group A-3 and B occupancies, delayed egress electrical locking systems shall be permitted to be installed on exit or exit access doors, other than the main exit or exit access door, in buildings that are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

The delayed egress electrical locking system shall be installed and operated in accordance with all of the following:
  1. The delay of the delayed egress electrical locking system shall deactivate upon actuation of the automatic sprinkler system or automatic fire detection system, allowing immediate free egress.
  2. The delay of the delayed egress electrical locking system shall deactivate upon loss of power to the electrical locking system or electrical lock, allowing immediate free egress.
  3. The delay of the delayed egress locking electrical system shall have the capability of being deactivated at the fire command center and other approved locations.
  4. An attempt to egress shall initiate an irreversible process that shall allow such egress in not more than 15 seconds when a physical effort to exit is applied to the egress side door hardware for not more than 3 seconds. Initiation of the irreversible process shall activate an audible signal in the vicinity of the door. Once the delay has been deactivated, rearming the delay electronics shall be by manual means only.
    Exception: Where approved, a delay of not more than 30 seconds is permitted on a delayed egress door.
  5. The egress path from any point shall not pass through more than one delayed egress locking system.
    Exceptions:
    1. In Group I-1, Condition 2, Group I-2 or I-3 occupancies, the egress path from any point in the building shall pass through not more than two delayed egress locking systems provided that the combined delay does not exceed 30 seconds.
    2. In Group I-1, Condition 1 or Group I-4 occupancies, the egress path from any point in the building shall pass through not more than two delayed egress locking systems provided the combined delay does not exceed 30 seconds and the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  6. A sign shall be provided on the door and shall be located above and within 12 inches (305 mm) of the door exit hardware.
    Exception: Where approved, in Group I occupancies, the installation of a sign is not required where care recipients who because of clinical needs require restraint or containment as part of the function of the treatment area.
    6.1.  For doors that swing in the direction of egress, the sign shall read, "PUSH UNTIL ALARM SOUNDS. DOOR CAN BE OPENED IN 15 [30] SECONDS."
    6.2.  For doors that swing in the opposite direction of egress, the sign shall read, "PULL UNTIL ALARM SOUNDS. DOOR CAN BE OPENED IN 15 [30] SECONDS."
    6.3.  The sign shall comply with the visual character requirements in ICC A117.1.
  7. Emergency lighting shall be provided on the egress side of the door.
  8. The electromechanical or electromagnetic locking device shall be listed in accordance with either UL 294 or UL 1034.

Controlled egress electrical locking systems where egress is controlled by authorized personnel shall be permitted on doors in the means of egress in Group I-1 or I-2 occupancies where the clinical needs of persons receiving care require their containment. Controlled egress doors shall be permitted in such occupancies where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or an approved automatic smoke detection system installed in accordance with Section 907, provided that the doors are installed and operate in accordance with all of the following:
  1. The door's electric locks shall unlock on actuation of the automatic sprinkler system or automatic smoke detection system allowing immediate free egress.
  2. The door's electric  locks shall unlock on loss of power to the electrical locking system or to the electric lock mechanism allowing immediate free egress.
  3. The electrical locking system shall be installed to have the capability of unlocking the electric locks by a switch located at the fire command center, a nursing station or other approved location. The switch shall directly break power to the electric lock.
  4. A building occupant shall not be required to pass through more than one door equipped with a controlled egress locking system before entering an exit.
  5. The procedures for unlocking the doors shall be described and approved as part of the emergency planning and preparedness required by Chapter 4 of the International Fire Code.
  6. All clinical staff shall have the keys, codes or other means necessary to operate the controlled egress electrical locking systems.
  7. Emergency lighting shall be provided at the door.
  8. The electromechanical or electromagnetic locking device shall be listed in accordance with either UL 294 or UL 1034.
Exceptions:
  1. Items 1 through 4 shall not apply to doors to areas occupied by persons who, because of clinical needs, require restraint or containment as part of the function of a psychiatric or cognitive treatment area.
  2. Items 1 through 4 shall not apply to doors to areas where a listed egress control system is utilized to reduce the risk of child abduction from nursery and obstetric areas of a Group I-2 hospital.
children.displayTitle: 1010.2.13 Controlled Egress Doors in Groups I-1 and I-2
children.titleText: Controlled Egress Doors in Groups I-1 and I-2

children.body:
Electrically locked exit access doors providing egress from elevator lobbies shall meet the following conditions:
  1. For all occupants of the floor, the path of exit access travel to not less than two exits is not required to pass through the elevator lobby.
  2. The building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, and a fire alarm system in accordance with Section 907. Elevator lobbies shall be provided with an automatic smoke detection system in accordance with Section 907.
  3. Upon activation of the building fire alarm system by means other than a manual fire alarm box shall automatically unlock the electric locks providing exit access from the elevator lobbies, and the electric locks shall remain unlocked until the fire alarm system is reset.
  4. The electric locks shall unlock on loss of power to the electric locks or electrical locking system.
  5. The electric locks shall have the capability of being unlocked by a switch located at the fire command center, security station or other approved location.
  6. A two-way communication system complying with Sections 1009.8.1 and 1009.8.2, shall be located in the elevator lobby adjacent to the electrically locked exit access door and connected to an approved constantly attended station. This constantly attended station shall have the capability of unlocking the electric locks of the elevator lobby exit access doors.
  7. Emergency lighting shall be provided in the elevator lobby on both sides of the electrically locked door.
  8. The electromechanical or electromagnetic locking device shall be listed in accordance with either UL 294 or UL 1034.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Nonsprinklered, 0-75 ft) - 2024
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited except for rooms with an electrically locked exit access door providing egress from an elevator lobby shall be permitted in accordance with Section 1010.2.14 (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. In other than group H occupancies, egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2)). In group H occupancies, egress through adjoining or intervening room or areas of the same or lesser hazard occupancy group with a discernible path of egress travel to an exit is allowed.
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7)
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1)
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby, is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), 1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed elevator lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless (a)the shaft is pressurized, or (b)smoke-stop doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors) (§716.2.2.1.1). This applies for all rated corridors, even if smoke protection for the elevator shaft is not required per §3006.2. (Table 1020.2 + Table 716.1(2) + 716.2.2.1) (If the elevator connects 4 or more floors, the enclosed elevator lobby is also required per §3006.2, except at the level of exit discharge.)
  10. At least one exit without passing through the enclosed elevator lobby.(§1016.2(1)
  11. Corridors require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2)
  12. Corridors require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke)rating (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).
  13. Unenclosed exit access stairs or ramps serving a rated corridor require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.7 + §1020.2)
  14. Unenclosed exit access stairs or ramps serving a rated corridor require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (1020.7 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1).
  15. Foyers, lobbies, or reception rooms serving a rated corridor require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.7 Exception 1 + §1020.2)
  16. Foyers, lobbies, or reception rooms serving a rated corridor require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (§1020.7 Exception 1 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1).
  17. Any enclosed elevator lobby bisecting a rated corridor requires 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2).
  18. Corridor doors at an enclosed elevator lobby must be 20-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).
  19. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Shafts connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§713.4). In Type I construction, 2-hour fire barriers are required in all cases (§713.4 + Table 601).
  20. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute automatic-closing smoke-activated fire doors. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §713.7 + §716.2.6.6). An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), but the mitigation described in Note 9 is mandatory
  21. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Stair enclosures connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1)

diagrams.title: Egress Through Space with Lockable Door
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Egress through intervening spaces lets a person exit a building by going through other rooms or spaces instead of directly into a hallway or exit. The main idea is that exit routes should stay safe, clear, and easy to follow, but there are a few exceptions. You're allowed to exit through elevator lobbies, but at least one exit must be reachable without going through the lobby. In other than Group H occupancy buildings you can also pass through nearby rooms if they're related to the main space and the way out is obvious. For hazardous occupancies, the adjoining room must be the same or a lower hazard level. There are also limits on where exits can go. You can't exit through rooms that can be locked against you, through other people's bedrooms, bathrooms, kitchens, storage rooms, or closets, unless certain conditions are met. In Group M, you can exit through a stockroom, but only if it meets certain requirements. The stock should be the same hazardous class as what's in the main sales area, no more than half the path goes through the stockroom, the door isn't locked, and there's a clearly marked 44" wide aisle that leads directly to the exit. The rules let people use adjoining spaces as exit paths, but only when it's safe, obvious, and not blocked or locked.

children.body:
In buildings within correctional and detention facilities, doors in means of egress serving rooms or spaces occupied by persons whose movements are controlled for security reasons shall be permitted to be locked where equipped with egress control devices that shall unlock manually and by not less than one of the following means:
  1. Activation of an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  2. Activation of an approved manual fire alarm box.
  3. A signal from a constantly attended location.
children.displayTitle: 1010.2.15 Locking Arrangements in Buildings Within Correctional Facilities
children.titleText: Locking Arrangements in Buildings Within Correctional Facilities

children.body: Special doors and security grilles shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1010.3.1 through 1010.3.4.

diagrams.title: Security Grilles
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Security grilles such as those typically installed at retail tenant space entries are allowed at the main exit at group B, F, M and S occupancies. If the space requires 2 or more exits not more than one-half of the required exits may have a horizontal or vertical security gate. Security gates must be openable by occupants from the inside without the use of a key, special knowledge or effort when the space is occupied.

children.body:
Revolving doors shall comply with the following:
  1. Revolving doors shall comply with BHMA A156.27 and shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
  2. Each revolving door shall be capable of breakout in accordance with BHMA A156.27 and shall provide an aggregate width of not less than 36 inches (914 mm).
  3. A revolving door shall not be located within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the foot or top of stairways or escalators. A dispersal area shall be provided between the stairways or escalators and the revolving doors.
  4. The revolutions per minute (rpm) for a revolving door shall not exceed the maximum rpm as specified in BHMA A156.27. Manual revolving doors shall comply with Table 1010.3.1(1). Automatic or power-operated revolving doors shall comply with Table 1010.3.1(2).
  5. An emergency stop switch shall be provided near each entry point of power or automatic operated revolving doors within 48 inches (1219 mm) of the door and between 34 inches (864 mm) and 48 inches (1219 mm) above the floor. The activation area of the emergency stop switch button shall be not less than 1 inch (25 mm) in diameter and shall be red.
  6. Each revolving door shall have a side-hinged swinging door that complies with Section 1010.1 in the same wall and within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the revolving door.
  7. Revolving doors shall not be part of an accessible route required by Section 1009 and Chapter 11.

A revolving door used as a component of a means of egress shall comply with Section 1010.3.1 and the following three conditions:
  1. Revolving doors shall not be given credit for more than 50 percent of the minimum width or required capacity.
  2. Each revolving door shall be credited with a capacity based on not more than a 50-person occupant load.
  3. Each revolving door shall provide for egress in accordance with BHMA A156.27 with a breakout force of not more than 130 pounds (578 N).

A revolving door used as other than a component of a means of egress shall comply with Section 1010.3.1. The breakout force of a revolving door not used as a component of a means of egress shall not be more than 180 pounds (801 N).
Exception: A breakout force in excess of 180 pounds (801 N) is permitted if the breakout force is reduced to not more than 130 pounds (578 N) when not less than one of the following conditions is satisfied:
  1. There is a power failure or power is removed to the device holding the door wings in position.
  2. There is an actuation of the automatic sprinkler system where such system is provided.
  3. There is an actuation of a smoke detection system that is installed in accordance with Section 907 to provide coverage in areas within the building that are within 75 feet (22 860 mm) of the revolving doors.
  4. There is an actuation of a manual control switch, in an approved location and clearly identified, that reduces the breakout force to not more than 130 pounds (578 N).

Where means of egress doors are operated or assisted by power, the design shall be such that in the event of power failure, the door is capable of being opened manually to permit means of egress travel or closed where necessary to safeguard means of egress. The forces required to open these doors manually shall not exceed those specified in Section 1010.1.3, except that the force to set the door in motion shall not exceed 50 pounds (220 N). The door shall be capable of opening from any position to the full width of the opening in which such door is installed when a force is applied to the door on the side from which egress is made. Power-operated swinging doors, power-operated sliding doors and power-operated folding doors shall comply with BHMA A156.10. Power-assisted swinging doors and low-energy power-operated swinging doors shall comply with BHMA A156.19. Low-energy power-operated sliding doors and low-energy power-operated folding doors shall comply with BHMA A156.38.
Exceptions:
  1. Occupancies in Group I-3.
  2. Special purpose horizontal sliding, accordion or folding doors complying with Section 1010.3.3.
  3. For a biparting door in the emergency breakout mode, a door leaf located within a multiple-leaf opening shall be exempt from the minimum 32-inch (813 mm) single-leaf requirement of Section 1010.1.1, provided that a minimum 32-inch (813 mm) clear opening is provided when the two biparting leaves meeting in the center are broken out.

diagrams.title: Air Leakage Vestibule
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vestibules for required to prevent conditioned air leakage are also required to meet all accessibility requirements for spacing of doors in series. Also vestibules part of the exit discharge must meet emergency power lighting requirements.

children.body:
In other than Group H occupancies, special purpose horizontal sliding, accordion or folding door assemblies permitted to be a component of a means of egress in accordance with Exception 6 to Section 1010.1.2 shall comply with all of the following criteria:
  1. The doors shall be power operated and shall be capable of being operated manually in the event of power failure.
  2. The doors shall be openable by a simple method without special knowledge or effort from the egress side or sides.
  3. The force required to operate the door shall not exceed 30 pounds (133 N) to set the door in motion and 15 pounds (67 N) to close the door or open it to the minimum required width.
  4. The door shall be openable with a force not to exceed 15 pounds (67 N) when a force of 250 pounds (1100 N) is applied perpendicular to the door adjacent to the operating device.
  5. The door assembly shall comply with the applicable fire protection rating and, where rated, shall be self-closing or automatic closing by smoke detection in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6, shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 80 and shall comply with Section 716.
  6. The door assembly shall have an integrated standby power supply.
  7. The door assembly power supply shall be electrically supervised.
  8. The door shall open to the minimum required width within 10 seconds after activation of the operating device.
children.displayTitle: 1010.3.3 Special Purpose Horizontal Sliding, Accordion or Folding Doors
children.titleText: Special Purpose Horizontal Sliding, Accordion or Folding Doors

children.body: In Groups B, F, M and S, horizontal sliding or vertical security grilles are permitted at the main exit and shall be openable from the inside without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort during periods that the space is occupied. The grilles shall remain secured in the full-open position during the period of occupancy by the general public. Where two or more exits or access to exits are required, not more than one-half of the exits or exit access doorways shall be equipped with horizontal sliding or vertical security grilles.

diagrams.title: Security Grilles
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Security grilles such as those typically installed at retail tenant space entries are allowed at the main exit at group B, F, M and S occupancies. If the space requires 2 or more exits not more than one-half of the required exits may have a horizontal or vertical security gate. Security gates must be openable by occupants from the inside without the use of a key, special knowledge or effort when the space is occupied.

children.body: Gates serving the means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of this section. Gates used as a component in a means of egress shall conform to the applicable requirements for doors.

diagrams.title: Stairway Discharge Identification
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit Stairways require signage to indicate the exit discharge, as well as barriers such as gates to prevent those exiting from continuing down into areas below the level of exit discharge.

children.body: Panic hardware is not required on gates surrounding stadiums where such gates are under constant immediate supervision while the public is present, and where safe dispersal areas based on 3 square feet (0.28 m2) per occupant are located between the fence and enclosed space. Such required safe dispersal areas shall not be located less than 50 feet (15 240 mm) from the enclosed space. See Section 1028.5 for means of egress from safe dispersal areas.

diagrams.title: Stadium Gates
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When all of the following conditions are met the gates utilized by the public to exit a stadium are not required to have panic hardware. The gates are under constant immediate supervision when the public is present Safe dispersal areas providing an aggregate area of 3 sf per occupant within the gated area are provided. The dispersal areas are located no less than 50 feet from the enclosed space.

children.body: Turnstiles or similar devices that restrict travel to one direction shall not be placed so as to obstruct any required means of egress, except where permitted in accordance with Sections 1010.5.1, 1010.5.2 and 1010.5.3.

Each turnstile or similar device shall be credited with a capacity based on not more than a 50-person occupant load where all of the following provisions are met:
  1. Each device shall turn free in the direction of egress travel when primary power is lost and on the manual release by an employee in the area.
  2. Such devices are not given credit for more than 50 percent of the required egress capacity or width.
  3. Each device is not more than 39 inches (991 mm) high.
  4. Each device has not less than 161/2 inches (419 mm) clear width at and below a height of 39 inches (991 mm) and not less than 22 inches (559 mm) clear width at heights above 39 inches (991 mm).

Where located as part of an accessible route, turnstiles shall have not less than 36 inches (914 mm) clear width at and below a height of 34 inches (864 mm), not less than 32 inches (813 mm) clear width between 34 inches (864 mm) and 80 inches (2032 mm) and shall consist of a mechanism other than a revolving device.

Security access turnstiles that inhibit travel in the direction of egress utilizing a physical barrier shall be permitted to be considered as a component of the means of egress, provided that all of the following criteria are met:
  1. The building is protected throughout by an approved, supervised automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  2. Each security access turnstile lane configuration has a minimum clear passage width of 22 inches (559 mm).
  3. Any security access turnstile lane configuration providing a clear passage width of less than 32 inches (810 mm) shall be credited with a maximum egress capacity of 50 persons.
  4. Any security access turnstile lane configuration providing a clear passage width of 32 inches (810 mm) or more shall be credited with a maximum egress capacity as calculated in accordance with Section 1005.
  5. Each secured physical barrier shall automatically retract or swing to an unobstructed open position in the direction of egress, under each of the following conditions:
    5.1. Upon loss of power to the turnstile or any part of the access control system that secures the physical barrier.
    5.2. Upon actuation of a clearly identified manual release device with ready access that results in direct interruption of power to each secured physical barrier, after which such barriers remain in the open position for not less than 30 seconds. The manual release device shall be positioned at one of the following locations:
    5.2.1. On the egress side of each security access turnstile lane.
    5.2.2. At an approved location where it can be actuated by an employee assigned to the area at all times that the building is occupied.
    5.3. Upon actuation of the building fire alarm system, if provided, after which the physical barrier remains in the open position until the fire alarm system is manually reset.
    Exception: Actuation of a manual fire alarm box.
    5.4. Upon actuation of the building automatic sprinkler system or fire detection system, after which the physical barrier remains in the open position until the fire alarm system is manually reset.
Turnstiles more than 39 inches (991 mm) high shall meet the requirements for revolving doors or the requirements of Section 1010.5.2 for security access turnstiles.

Where serving an occupant load greater than 300, each turnstile that is not portable shall have a side-hinged swinging door that conforms to Section 1010.1 within 50 feet (15 240 mm).
Exception: A side-hinged swinging door is not required at security access turnstiles that comply with Section 1010.5.2.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairways and Ramps: When Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because there is potential for occupants to fall from exterior exit stairways and ramps the code limits when they may be used as a required part of the means of egress. Section 1027.2 limits their use to buildings that are either not a high rise and are less then 6 stories in height above grade plane. The section also does not allow for exterior exit stairs and ramps to be part of the required means of egress for group I-2 occupancies; exterior stairways and ramps could be a danger due to the physical and mental limitations some of the occupants.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Area of Refuge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairways located in the accessible means of egress, shall either incorporate an area of refuge within enlarged floor-level landing or shall be accessed from an area of refuge complying with Section 1009.6.

An area of refuge is an area where persons unable to use stairways can remain temporarily to await instructions or assistance during an emergency evacuation.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order for stairways to be part of the accessible means of egress, there must be a clear distance of 48" minimum between the handrails. Exceptions exist for certain sprinkered buildings and stairs accessed from a refuge area related to a horizontal exit. The purpose of a stairway meeting these width requirements is to provide the width to allow two firemen to assist a wheelchair user down the stairs, one on each side of the person, or other related fire rescue operations.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1023.4 defines the type of wall openings that may be placed in interior exit stair walls. The only openings allowed in interior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures are exit doors that provide access to the stairway enclosure from normally occupied spaces and for exiting from the enclosure. Since interior exit stairways need to be separated from the rest of the building by vertical fire barriers (707) or a rated horizontal assembly (711), section 1023.4 also requires any openings in the interior walls to be protected in accordance with section 716. The actual level of opening protection required is established by table 716.1(2) which defines the rating/level of protection of any openings between an interior space and the exit stairway. 1023.4 further clarifies that elevators may not open into interior exit stairway enclosures.

diagrams.title: Stair Landings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stair landings are required to be of a minimum dimension to provide for changing directions and to provide sufficient space for the safe opening of a door onto a stair landing.

diagrams.title: Dimensions at Stairs: Reference Surfaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The dimensions of stair risers and treads should be measured in a manner that does not include carpets, rugs or runners. Carpets, rugs, or runners are not permanent fixtures. They can be removed, replaced, or wear out over time, which could alter the actual dimensions of the stairs. Thus, building codes require that stairs meet size and uniformity standards without the inclusion of these additional elements.

diagrams.title: Stair Enclosures at Exterior Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairway enclousure walls are intended to provide a specific hourly fire resistance from a fire occurring within the same building. Therefore they are required for adjoining interior walls, but not necessarily exterior walls. However, if the walls are near to a property line fire-separation distance datum line, then the building itself, which includes the stairway, must still be protected from outside hazards as an exterior wall of a building would. Keep in mind that stairways also have an occupancy group, and that occupancy group is required to determine the required exterior wall fire rating.

diagrams.title: Alternating Tread Devices
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Alternating tread devices, or alternating stair treads, are typically used in steep, compact, or narrow staircases where regular stairs will not fit.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Combustible Stairway Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When stairwells are constructed of combustible construction they must be fully sprinklered. Sprinklers are required to be installed under every stairway, at the top of the shaft, beneath each landing, and at the lowest intermediate landing.

diagrams.title: Stairway and Flight of Stairs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines a flight of stairs as a continuous run of rectangular treads, winders or combination thereof from one landing to another. A stairway is One or more flights of stairs, either exterior or interior, with the necessary landings and platforms connecting them, to form a continuous and uninterrupted passage from one level to another.

Stairways play an integral role in the means of egress, serving as pivotal paths for people to evacuate a building safely during emergencies.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Combustible Stairway Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When stairwells are constructed of combustible construction they must be fully sprinklered. Sprinklers are required to be installed under every stairway, at the top of the shaft, beneath each landing, and at the lowest intermediate landing.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Non-Combustible Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When stairwells are constructed of noncombustible materials, differing sprinkler requirements apply. Based on the requirements, openings, fire rated separations, and storage configurations, sprinklers may only be required at the top and bottom of the shaft. Or they may be required at every landing and every opening.

diagrams.title: Egress From Stories or Occupied Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml: For a building to be safe all stories need to be provided with adequate egress. Section 1006.3 requires that each story or occupied roof be provided with the number of separate exits or access to exits based on the occupant load of the story. The number of required exits required for a story are defined in Table 1006.3.3. The exits or exit access from each story need to sized to address the occupant load of the story being served. Section 1005 defines how to size various egress elements. The various stories and occupied roof may share a common exit stairway. An exit stairway serving multiple stories needs to be sized to serve the occupant load of the story or occupied roof with the greatest occupant load that it serves not the aggregate occupant load of all stories served.

diagrams.title: Non-Uniform Height Risers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1011.5.4.1 addresses stairway compliance when the bottom or top landing is sloped. It allows the top or bottom riser to be reduced to address the variation of the grade that the stairway needs to interface with along riser the face. Normally the minimum allowed riser height is 4", this section of code allows the riser height to be reduced to less than 4". The riser height reduction variation is limited to 8% of the stair width

diagrams.title: Exterior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require an illumination source to be used safely. Stairways to a basement would be those meeting the rise/run and other requirements of the stairway. Illumination would not be required at stairs covered by hinged bulkhead doors, where the height from the basement finished floor level to grade adjacent to the stairway is not more than 8 feet, per Section R311.7.10.2.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A foot-candle (fc) is a unit of illuminance, representing the amount of light that falls onto a surface. It is defined as one lumen per square foot. To visualize what one foot-candle of illuminance looks like, consider the following description:

Imagine a single candle lit in a completely dark room. If you were to measure the light falling on a one-square-foot surface situated one foot away from the candle (in direct line with the flame and without any obstructions), that would be approximately equivalent to one foot-candle of illuminance.

In practical terms, this is a rather low level of light, akin to the soft, dim light you might experience in a room illuminated only by candlelight. It's more than enough to make out shapes and some details, but it's much dimmer than the lighting levels we're used to in well-lit indoor spaces. To put it into perspective, a typical home living room in the evening with artificial light might range from 10 to 50 foot-candles, whereas an office lighting is typically brighter, often around 30 to 50 foot-candles.

diagrams.title: High Rise: Additional Stairway
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a building (other than Group R-2 occupancy type) exceeds 420' in height, an additional stairwell is required. This is in addition to the minimum egress requirements of Section 1006.3. If the building is equipped with an occupant evacuation elevator, then this additional stairwell is not required. Where other parts of the building have a maximum occupiable height of less than 420', that section of the building is not required to have the extra stairwell.

diagrams.title: Stairway Discharge Identification
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit Stairways require signage to indicate the exit discharge, as well as barriers such as gates to prevent those exiting from continuing down into areas below the level of exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Walkline at Winder Treads
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The walkline across winder treads is based on the user's path while climbing or descending the stair. It should follow the shape of the direction of travel throughout the turn of the stairs. The walkline must be located 12 inches from the side where the winders are the narrowest and the measurement is taken from the widest point of the clear stair width of the walking surface.

diagrams.title: Stairways: Outdoor Conditions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Outdoor stairways must be designed in such a way that water will not accumulate on the walking surfaces. Accumulated water can cause a stairway to become slippery, thereby increasing the risk of accidents and injuries due to slips and falls. This is particularly important in commercial or public buildings with significant foot traffic, where a slip could create a domino effect. Regular pooling of water can compromise the durability of the stairway's material, potentially leading to corrosion, rot, or erosion depending on the material used. Also, extended exposure to water can lead to the growth of mold and mildew, which can result in unwelcome odors, health risks, and possible structural damage over time.
To meet these safety provisions, construction designs often include appropriate drainage systems or a slight slope on the walking surface to divert water away. Additionally, the application of slip-resistant finishes on the stairway walking surfaces can also help prevent accidents. Only once these considered designs are implemented, can the stairway achieve adequate safety measures for users.

diagrams.title: Stairway Walking Surface
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The walking surface of treads and landings constructed for stairways, should not be sloped steeper than one unit vertical in 48 units horizontal (2-percent slope) in any direction. Stairways are also required to have a solid surface, with finish floor surfaces being securely attached. There are a few exceptions to these rules, for example, openings in stair walking surfaces should not permit the passage of a half-inch-diameter sphere.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Stairs, Ramps
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to stairs and ramps shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Ladders: Where Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Permanent ladders may not be a part of the means of egress from any occupied space. Details related to the ladder construction are in the mechanical code section 306.5. The ladder's structural live load requirements are defined in section 1607.17 of the building code. Permanent ladders may be utilized to provide access to the following types of areas and spaces.
  1. Spaces that only need to be accessed by personnel for the maintenance, repair or monitoring of equipment.
  2. Nonoccupied spaces such as crawl spaces, catwalks, freight elevators or very narrow passageways as may be found in a theater or large mechanical room.
  3. Areas primarily utilized for security, life safety or fire safety such as guard towers and lifeguard stands, typically encountered in institutional occupancies.
  4. In group U occupancies areas not open to the general public.
  5. Roofs that are nonoccupied and do not require a stairway by Section 1011.12.1
  6. Where Section 306.5 of the Mechanical Code allows for ladders to access equipment and appliances.

diagrams.title: Solid Risers in Stairs: Exceptions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stair risers are generally required to be solid. However, there are a few exceptions:
  • Solid risers are not required for stairways that are not required to comply with Section 1009.3, provided that the opening between treads does not permit the passage of a sphere with a diameter of 4 inches.
  • Solid risers are not required for occupancies in Group I-3 or in Group F, H, and S occupancies other than areas accessible to the public. The size of the opening in the riser is not restricted.
  • Solid risers are not required for spiral stairways constructed in accordance with Section 1011.10.

diagrams.title: Stair Width with Chair Lift (Metal Pan Condition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1011.2 defines the required exit stair width. The required width is based on the Occupant load served by the stairway. The minimum width required is 0.3" per occupant per section 1005.1 but not less than 44". There are a few exceptions: The code does allow for 36" wide stairs for stairs that serve and occupant load of <50. Spiral stairs width is covered by section 1011.10. Stairways that serve R-3 occupancy or are within R-2 dwelling units with a folding inclined platform or stairway chairlift must have 20" clear passage measured at the folded lift.

Commentary: Encroachment of stringers appear to depend on if it is a structural member, or just a skirt trim board. If the stringer is a structural element, then 1005.7.2 would seem to prohibit the obstruction, and the stair width would need to be measured between the face of stringers. However, if it were a non-structural trim piece such as a skirt board, then a projection may be allowed. Check with your local building official for the final interpretation of allowed projections into a stairway.

diagrams.title: Enclosures Under Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The spaces under both interior and exterior stairways, if enclosed, are required to be protected by 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction. Under-staircase spaces, if not properly enclosed, can act as a channel for flames, heat, and smoke, thereby allowing a fire to spread more rapidly throughout a building. Fire-resistance-rated construction or the fire-resistance rating of the stairway enclosure, whichever is greater, is required by law for spaces under stairways. A fire under a stairway could potentially cut off a crucial escape route. Enclosed spaces under stairways should also not provide direct access within the stairway enclosure.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stair w/ Exit Passageway: Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an interior exit stairway or ramp cannot provide direct access to an exit discharge or public way, the code permits the use of an exit passageway to extend the interior exit stairway or ramp to facilitate such access. Exit passageways' enclosures, which encompass walls, floors, and ceilings, are mandated to be constructed as fire-barriers. They must possess a fire-resistance of either 1-hour or the fire-resistance requisite for any connected interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure, opting for whichever specification is greater. For reference, a typical exit stairway enclosure has a 2-hour fire-resistance rating.

The interior exit stairway or ramp must be separated from the exit passageway by a fire barrier, which should carry a fire-resistance rating not less than that of the interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure. In order to access the exit passageway from the exit stairway or ramp, a fire door, compliant with Section 716, must be incorporated into the fire barrier, which establishes separation between the exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway. Any openings and penetrations in the fire barrier that segregates the exit stairway or ramp from the passageway—apart from the fire door intended to provide exit from the stairway or ramp—are prohibited.

However, the code does provide allowance for incidental penetrations of the fire barrier, required for construction and life safety elements related to ventilation, fire protection, security, and communications systems, in addition to electrical raceways serving fire communications and the exit stairway or ramp, and for structural elements sustaining the stairway or ramp. All penetrations must be safeguarded in accordance with Section 714.

Moreover, the fire barrier and fire door, positioned between the exit passageway and the exit stairway or ramp, may be omitted under specific circumstances: where there are no openings into the exit passageway or where the interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway are pressurized in line with Section 909.20.5.

Ships Ladders in Group I-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In group I-3 facilities, a ship ladder may be used as part of the means of egress from control rooms or elevated observation stations when the following two conditions are met:
  • The control room or observation station must be not more than 250 sf.
  • The occupant load of the control room or observation station must not exceed 3.
A ships ladder may also be used to access unoccupied roofs in group I-3 facilities.

children.body:
Stairways serving occupied portions of a building shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1011.2 through 1011.13. Alternating tread devices shall comply with Section 1011.14. Ship's ladders shall comply with Section 1011.15. Ladders shall comply with Section 1011.16.
Exception: Within rooms or spaces used for assembly purposes, stepped aisles shall comply with Section 1030.

diagrams.title: Ladders: Where Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Permanent ladders may not be a part of the means of egress from any occupied space. Details related to the ladder construction are in the mechanical code section 306.5. The ladder's structural live load requirements are defined in section 1607.17 of the building code. Permanent ladders may be utilized to provide access to the following types of areas and spaces.
  1. Spaces that only need to be accessed by personnel for the maintenance, repair or monitoring of equipment.
  2. Nonoccupied spaces such as crawl spaces, catwalks, freight elevators or very narrow passageways as may be found in a theater or large mechanical room.
  3. Areas primarily utilized for security, life safety or fire safety such as guard towers and lifeguard stands, typically encountered in institutional occupancies.
  4. In group U occupancies areas not open to the general public.
  5. Roofs that are nonoccupied and do not require a stairway by Section 1011.12.1
  6. Where Section 306.5 of the Mechanical Code allows for ladders to access equipment and appliances.

children.body:
The required capacity of stairways shall be determined as specified in Section 1005.1, but the minimum width shall be not less than 44 inches (1118 mm). The minimum width for stairways that serve as part of the accessible means of egress shall comply with Section 1009.3.
Exceptions:
  1. Stairways serving an occupant load of less than 50 shall have a width of not less than 36 inches (914 mm).
  2. Spiral stairways as provided for in Section 1011.10.
  3. Where an incline platform lift or stairway chairlift is installed on stairways serving occupancies in Group R-3, or within dwelling units in occupancies in Group R-2, a clear passage width not less than 20 inches (508 mm) shall be provided. Where the seat and platform can be folded when not in use, the distance shall be measured from the folded position.

diagrams.title: Platform Lift Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Platform lifts may be used as part of an accessible means of egress under certain conditions. Inclined platform lifts may be used within dwelling units, but the stairways in which they exist must meet the requirements of Section 1011.2, Exception 3. Platform and stairway (inclined) chairlifts must meet the requirements of ASME A18.1.

diagrams.title: Stair Width with Chair Lift (Metal Pan Condition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1011.2 defines the required exit stair width. The required width is based on the Occupant load served by the stairway. The minimum width required is 0.3" per occupant per section 1005.1 but not less than 44". There are a few exceptions: The code does allow for 36" wide stairs for stairs that serve and occupant load of <50. Spiral stairs width is covered by section 1011.10. Stairways that serve R-3 occupancy or are within R-2 dwelling units with a folding inclined platform or stairway chairlift must have 20" clear passage measured at the folded lift.

Commentary: Encroachment of stringers appear to depend on if it is a structural member, or just a skirt trim board. If the stringer is a structural element, then 1005.7.2 would seem to prohibit the obstruction, and the stair width would need to be measured between the face of stringers. However, if it were a non-structural trim piece such as a skirt board, then a projection may be allowed. Check with your local building official for the final interpretation of allowed projections into a stairway.

children.body:
Stairways shall have a headroom clearance of not less than 80 inches (2032 mm) measured vertically from a line connecting the nosings. Such headroom shall be continuous above the stairway to the point where the line intersects the landing below, one tread depth beyond the bottom riser. The minimum clearance shall be maintained the full width of the stairway and landing.
Exceptions:
  1. Spiral stairways complying with Section 1011.10 are permitted a 78-inch (1981 mm) headroom clearance.
  2. In Group R-3 occupancies; within dwelling units in Group R-2 occupancies; and in Group U occupancies that are accessory to a Group R-3 occupancy or accessory to individual dwelling units in Group R-2 occupancies; where the nosings of treads at the side of a flight extend under the edge of a floor opening through which the stair passes, the floor opening shall be allowed to project horizontally into the required headroom not more than 43/4 inches (121 mm).

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom and Vert. Rise
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

In addition, stairways that are too long could be dangerous from falls, or could be too physically taxing for those not able to sustain the effort to traverse a long stairway. Therefore, stair runs are limited to 12 feet in vertical rise.

children.body: The walkline across winder treads shall be concentric to the direction of travel through the turn and located 12 inches (305 mm) from the side where the winders are narrower. The 12-inch (305 mm) dimension shall be measured from the widest point of the clear stair width at the walking surface of the winder. Where winders are adjacent within the flight, the point of the widest clear stair width of the adjacent winders shall be used.

diagrams.title: Walkline at Winder Treads
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The walkline across winder treads is based on the user's path while climbing or descending the stair. It should follow the shape of the direction of travel throughout the turn of the stairs. The walkline must be located 12 inches from the side where the winders are the narrowest and the measurement is taken from the widest point of the clear stair width of the walking surface.

children.body: Stair treads and risers shall comply with Sections 1011.5.1 through 1011.5.5.3.

diagrams.title: Solid Risers in Stairs: Exceptions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stair risers are generally required to be solid. However, there are a few exceptions:
  • Solid risers are not required for stairways that are not required to comply with Section 1009.3, provided that the opening between treads does not permit the passage of a sphere with a diameter of 4 inches.
  • Solid risers are not required for occupancies in Group I-3 or in Group F, H, and S occupancies other than areas accessible to the public. The size of the opening in the riser is not restricted.
  • Solid risers are not required for spiral stairways constructed in accordance with Section 1011.10.
