diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity - Excpt. 1-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. There are several situations in which exceptions are permitted:
  • Handrails within dwelling units are permitted to be interrupted by a newel post at a turn or landing.
  • Within a dwelling unit, the use of a volute, turnout, starting easing or starting newel is allowed over the lowest tread.
  • Handrail brackets or balusters attached to the bottom surface of the handrail that do not project horizontally beyond the sides of the handrail within 1-1/2 inches of the bottom of the handrail shall not be considered obstructions. For each 1/2 inch of additional handrail perimeter dimension above 4 inches, the vertical clearance dimension of 1-1/2 inches shall be permitted to be reduced by 1/8 inch.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Handrails' continuation without interruption by newel posts or other obstructions, also facilitates quicker and safer evacuation during an emergency.

children.body: Handrails shall not rotate within their fittings.

Handrails shall return to a wall, guard or the walking surface or shall be continuous to the handrail of an adjacent flight of stairs or ramp run. Where handrails are not continuous between flights, the handrails shall extend horizontally not less than 12 inches (305 mm) beyond the top landing nosing and continue to slope for the depth of one tread beyond the bottom tread nosing. At ramps where handrails are not continuous between runs, the handrails shall extend horizontally above the landing 12 inches (305 mm) minimum beyond the top and bottom of ramp runs. The extensions of handrails shall be in the same direction of the flights of stairs at stairways and the ramp runs at ramps and shall extend the required minimum length before any change in direction or decrease in the clearance required by Section 1014.5 or 1014.8.
Exceptions:
  1. Handrails within a dwelling unit that is not required to be accessible need extend only from the top riser to the bottom riser.
  2. Handrails serving aisles in rooms or spaces used for assembly purposes are permitted to comply with the handrail extensions in accordance with Section 1030.16.
  3. Handrails for alternating tread devices and ships ladders are permitted to terminate at a location vertically above the top and bottom risers. Handrails for alternating tread devices are not required to be continuous between flights or to extend beyond the top or bottom risers.

diagrams.title: Stairway and Flight of Stairs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines a flight of stairs as a continuous run of rectangular treads, winders or combination thereof from one landing to another. A stairway is One or more flights of stairs, either exterior or interior, with the necessary landings and platforms connecting them, to form a continuous and uninterrupted passage from one level to another.

Stairways play an integral role in the means of egress, serving as pivotal paths for people to evacuate a building safely during emergencies.

diagrams.title: Handrail Extensions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Some jurisdictions, such as California, may require a horizontal extension at the bottom of the handrail. Double check what state or local requirements there might be in addition to the requirement of the ADA illustrated here.

children.body:
Clear space between a handrail and a wall or other surface shall be not less than 11/2 inches (38 mm). A handrail and a wall or other surface adjacent to the handrail shall be free of any sharp or abrasive elements.
Exceptions:
  1. A decrease in the clearance due to the curvature or angle of handrail returns shall be allowed.
  2. Mounting flanges not more than 1/2-inch (12.7 mm) in thickness at the returned ends of handrails shall be allowed.

diagrams.title: Type II Handrail Profile
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A Type 2 handrail is one that is larger than the graspable perimeter of a Type 1 handrail. In this condition, handrails with a perimeter greater than 6-1/4 inches are required to provide a graspable finger recess area on both sides of the profile. The Stair Manufacturers Association funded a study that determined that a pinch grip could provide graspable handrail. This was added to the Residential Code in 2001 and the Building Code for multifamily residential in 2009.

diagrams.title: Handrails: Cross Section (Type I)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In the building code, two types of handrails are listed: type I and type II. The ADA Standards has a single handrail specification. Surface requirements and clearances facilitate a power grip along the length of handrails. Handrails can have circular or non-circular cross-sections, but must have rounded edges. The gripping surface and adjacent surfaces must be free of abrasive or sharp elements. Wall-mounted handrails with leading edges higher than 27" cannot protrude more than 41/2" into circulation paths (§307.2).

ADA Standards Advisory 505.6 Gripping Surface. People with disabilities, older people, and others benefit from continuous gripping surfaces that permit users to reach the fingers outward or downward to grasp the handrail, particularly as the user senses a loss of equilibrium or begins to fall.

children.body: On ramps and on ramped aisles that are part of an accessible route, the clear width between handrails shall be 36 inches (914 mm) minimum. Projections into the required width of aisles, stairways and ramps at each side shall not exceed 41/2 inches (114 mm) at or below the handrail height. Projections into the required width shall not be limited above the minimum headroom height required in Section 1011.3. Projections due to intermediate handrails shall not constitute a reduction in the egress width. Where a pair of intermediate handrails are provided within the stairway width without a walking surface between the pair of intermediate handrails and the distance between the pair of intermediate handrails is greater than 6 inches (152 mm), the available egress width shall be reduced by the distance between the closest edges of each such intermediate pair of handrails that is greater than 6 inches (152 mm).

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Stairs Horizontal Encroachments
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Generally, projections of more than 4" are not allowed into the circulation path. This doesn't include the 48" clear width between handrails for stairways used as an accessible means of egress.

The allowance for a 1-1/2" projection into the required width for trim or other non-structural projection at the base would not include structural items such as stringers for steel pan-tread type stairways. The minimum required stair width would have to be accommodated for between the structural items in that condition.

children.body: Stairways shall have intermediate handrails located in such a manner that all portions of the stairway minimum width or required capacity are within 30 inches (762 mm) of a handrail. On monumental stairs, handrails shall be located along the most direct path of egress travel.

diagrams.title: Intermediate Handrails
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The intent behind the guardrail placement requirements in 1014.9 is to ensure that, during an emergency or in daily use, people traversing a stairway always have access to a handrail within a reasonable reach. For ordinary stairs, this is accomplished by making sure every point along the stairway's width is within 30 inches of a handrail, providing consistent support and a sense of safety for all users. However, monumental stairs—those especially wide, open, or visually prominent—warrant an additional layer of attention. Here, the code moves beyond purely geometric compliance and calls for handrails to be positioned where people are most likely to walk, not just at the margins or in routine locations. This approach addresses the reality that people tend to travel in the straightest and most efficient lines, particularly in urgent situations, and are unlikely to veer far from their intended route just to reach a handrail.

This language opens up some interpretive gray space. "Most direct path" does not translate to a requirement for absolute, mathematical alignment with every possible trajectory on the stairs, nor does it suggest a single fixed path. Instead, it asks designers and inspectors to apply reasonable judgment: anticipating the primary lines of movement and placing handrails in those areas. For example, on a broad, centrally-used flight of stairs, a handrail running alongside the central zone may be appropriate even if it isn't exactly centered, so long as it reliably supports the actual ways people move. The law's focus is on intent—providing support in practical, real-world travel patterns—rather than imposing a rigid technical solution. This encourages architects both to observe human behavior and to prioritize realistic safety measures when planning handrail locations on large, public stairs

diagrams.title: Guards:  Connection Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
ASCE 7 requires the 200 pound load to be placed in any direction at any point on the handrail or top rail to produce a maximum load effect. This would mean a load pulling on the rail inward would create a maximum tension on the bottom bolt, but a 200 pound force outward (typically associated with "falling" outward) would put the maximum tension on the top bolt.

However, the Residential Code, in Table R301.5, footnote d, states: "A single concentrated load applied in any direction at any point along the top. For a guard not required to serve as a handrail, the load need not be applied to the top element of the guard in a direction parallel to such element." This language does not seem to appear in ASCE 7 at this time.

Therefore, the designer should consider providing tension resisting hardware on both bolts, or consider an alternate design. Simply relying on the rim board would put the member into cross-grain bending, which has considerably lower strength than the beam itself.

diagrams.title: Guards at Ramps
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to the Building Code, a guard is a building component located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to a lower level.
When ramps are located more than 30 inches vertically above the floor or grade below at any point within 36 inches horizontally to the edge of the open side, then guards are required. The required guards shall be a minimum of 42 inches in height from the ramp surface and shall not allow the passage of a sphere 4 inches in diameter through the openings.

diagrams.title: Glass in Guards and Handrails
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where glass is used in a guardrail or handrail it is required to be laminated glass. The actual glass that makes up the laminated glazing is required to be fully tempered or heat-strengthened glass and comply with Category II of CPSC 16 CFR Part 1201 or Class A of ANSI Z97.1. The glazing used in a guard or handrail must also be an approved safety glazing material that conforms to the provisions of Section 2406.1.1. Glazing in guard and handrails is required to have a minimum nominal thickness shall be 1/4 inch.

diagrams.title: Guards at Retaining Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When the finish grade on the downslope side of a guardrail is more than 30" below the grade on the upslope side within 36" of a retaining wall and there is a walking surface within 36" on the uphill side of a retaining wall a guard is required. The guard must be located between the walking surface and the edge of the retaining wall. The guard must be at least 42" tall. The size of any openings withing the guard shall prevent the passage of a 4" sphere.

children.body: Guards shall comply with the provisions of Sections 1015.2 through 1015.7. Operable windows with sills located more than 72 inches (1829 mm) above finished grade or other surface below shall comply with Section 1015.8.

Guards shall be located along open-sided walking surfaces, such as mezzanines, equipment platforms, aisles, stairs, ramps and landings, that are located more than 30 inches (762 mm) measured vertically to the floor or grade below at any point within 36 inches (914 mm) horizontally to the edge of the open side and at the perimeter of occupiable roofs. Guards shall be adequate in strength and attachment in accordance with Section 1607.9.
Exceptions: Guards are not required for the following locations:
  1. On the loading side of loading docks or piers.
  2. On the audience side of stages and raised platforms, including stairs leading up to the stage and raised platforms.
  3. On raised stage and platform floor areas, such as runways, ramps and side stages used for entertainment or presentations.
  4. At vertical openings in the performance area of stages and platforms.
  5. At elevated walking surfaces appurtenant to stages and platforms for access to and utilization of special lighting or equipment.
  6. Along vehicle service pits not accessible to the public.
  7. In assembly seating areas at cross aisles in accordance with Section 1030.17.2.
  8. On the loading side of station platforms on fixed guideway transit or passenger rail systems.
  9. Portions of an occupiable roof located less than 30 inches (762 mm) measured vertically to adjacent unoccupiable roof areas where approved guards are present at the perimeter of the roof.
  10. At portions of an occupiable roof where an approved barrier is provided.

diagrams.title: Equipment Platforms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Equipment platforms by definition have zero occupant load and are elevated platforms that may only be used for mechanical systems equipment or industrial process equipment. Equipment platforms do not contribute to the building area, fire area, or number of stories, and are not considered a portion of the floor below. Elements providing access to the platform such as walkways, stairs, alternating tread devices and ladders may not serve as part of the building's means of egress. Equipment platforms may not be part of a mezzanine.

diagrams.title: Guardrail Opening Limitations (Ex. 5)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1015.4 Exception 5
In assembly seating areas, guards required at the end of aisles in accordance with Section 1030.17.4 shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 4 inches in diameter up to a height of 26 inches. From a height of 26 inches to 42 inches above the adjacent walking surfaces, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 8 inches in diameter.

diagrams.title: Guardrail Openings - Exceptions 3 & 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1015.4 Exception 3
At elevated walking surfaces for access to and use of electrical, mechanical or plumbing systems or equipment, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.
Section 1015.4 Exception 4
In areas that are not open to the public within occupancies in Group I-3, F, H or S, and for alternating tread devices and ships ladders, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches in diameter.

children.body: Where glass is used to provide a guard or as a portion of the guard system, the guard shall comply with Section 2407. Where the glazing provided does not meet the strength and attachment requirements of Section 1607.9, complying guards shall be located along glazed sides of open-sided walking surfaces.

Required guards shall be not less than 42 inches (1067 mm) high, measured vertically as follows:
  1. From the adjacent walking surfaces.
  2. On stairways and stepped aisles, from the line connecting the nosings.
  3. On ramps and ramped aisles, from the ramp surface at the guard.
Exceptions:
  1. For occupancies in Group R-3 not more than three stories above grade in height and within individual dwelling units in occupancies in Group R-2 not more than three stories above grade in height with separate means of egress, required guards shall be not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in height measured vertically above the adjacent walking surfaces.
  2. For occupancies in Groups R-2 and R-3, within the interior conditioned space of individual dwelling units, where the open-sided walking surface is located not more than 25 feet (7.62 meters) measured vertically to the floor or walking surface below, required guards shall not be less than 36 inches (914 mm) in height measured vertically above the adjacent walking surface.
  3. For occupancies in Group R-3, and within individual dwelling units in occupancies in Group R-2, guards on the open sides of stairs shall have a height not less than 34 inches (864 mm) measured vertically from a line connecting the nosings.
  4. For occupancies in Group R-3, and within individual dwelling units in occupancies in Group R-2, where the top of the guard serves as a handrail on the open sides of stairs, the top of the guard shall be not less than 34 inches (864 mm) and not more than 38 inches (965 mm) measured vertically from a line connecting the nosings.
  5. The guard height in assembly seating areas shall comply with Section 1030.17 as applicable.
  6. Along alternating tread devices and ships ladders, guards where the top rail serves as a handrail shall have height not less than 30 inches (762 mm) and not more than 34 inches (864 mm), measured vertically from a line connecting the leading edge of the treads.
  7. In Group F occupancies where exit access stairways serve fewer than three stories and such stairways are not open to the public, and where the top of the guard also serves as a handrail, the top of the guard shall be not less than 34 inches (864 mm) and not more than 38 inches (965 mm) measured vertically from a line connecting the nosings.

diagrams.title: Handrails, Guards (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guards and handrails are required at both sides of stairs and ramps (exceptions as noted in section 7.2.2.1.4.5 and section 7.2.2.1.4.6). Handrails must be between 34" and 38" above tread surface. For existing stairs and handrails the height can be reduced to 30". Where a handrail is part of the guard is can be extended to 42" in height. Where handrails are mounted to a wall, there must be at least 2 1/4" space between the handrail and the wall. All guards must be at least 42" in height. Additional handrails above or below this height are permitted. Handrails must terminate at newel posts, return into themself, or turn into the wall.

diagrams.title: Perimeter Guards at Assembly Seating
diagrams.descriptionHtml: GUARD. A building component or a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to the lower level.

diagrams.title: Guards: Stairs (Non-Res)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guardrails at stairs for that are not within a multifamily dwelling unit or for an R-3 residential occupancy have more robust requirements than is required for those that are residential in nature. Verify with the Existing Building Code what requirements must be met when removing / replacing a guardrail, as more current requirements can be more restrictive than when the railing was installed.

children.body:
Required guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 4 inches (102 mm) in diameter from the walking surface to the required guard height.
Exceptions:
  1. From a height of 36 inches (914 mm) to 42 inches (1067 mm), guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 43/8 inches (111 mm) in diameter.
  2. The triangular openings at the open sides of a stair, formed by the riser, tread and bottom rail shall not allow passage of a sphere 6 inches (152 mm) in diameter.
  3. At elevated walking surfaces for access to and use of electrical, mechanical or plumbing systems or equipment, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches (533 mm) in diameter.
  4. In areas that are not open to the public within occupancies in Group I-3, F, H or S, and for alternating tread devices and ships ladders, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 21 inches (533 mm) in diameter.
  5. In assembly seating areas, guards required at the end of aisles in accordance with Section 1030.17.4 shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 4 inches (102 mm) in diameter up to a height of 26 inches (660 mm). From a height of 26 inches (660 mm) to 42 inches (1067 mm) above the adjacent walking surfaces, guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 8 inches (203 mm) in diameter.
  6. Within individual dwelling units and sleeping units in Group R-2 and R-3 occupancies, guards on the open sides of stairs shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 43/8 (111 mm) inches in diameter.

children.body: Porches and decks that are enclosed with insect screening shall be provided with guards where the walking surface is located more than 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor or grade below.

Guards shall be provided where various components that require service are located within 10 feet (3048 mm) of a roof edge or open side of a walking surface and such edge or open side is located more than 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor, roof or grade below. The guard shall extend not less than 30 inches (762 mm) beyond each end of such components. The guard shall be constructed so as to prevent the passage of a sphere 21 inches (533 mm) in diameter.
Exception: Guards are not required where personal fall arrest anchorage connector devices that comply with ANSI/ASSE Z 359.1 are installed.

diagrams.title: Guards: Mechanical Equip. & Roof Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guards at the roof level are required to protect those servicing equipment or for other reasons from falls. OSHA requirements may be more restrictive and require protection outside of the 10 foot limits in the Mechanical Code at which no guards are required. Other requirements found in laws adopting the Uniform Mechanical code may appear less restrictive than the Building Code, however, the most restrictive requirement for your situation would apply. The links provided here may not be all inclusive, and more stringent local and state requirements may apply.

children.body:
Guards shall be provided where the roof hatch opening is located within 10 feet (3048 mm) of a roof edge or open side of a walking surface and such edge or open side is located more than 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor, roof or grade below. The guard shall extend not less than 30 inches (762 mm) beyond each end of the hatch parallel to the roof edge. The guard shall be constructed so as to prevent the passage of a sphere 21 inches (533 mm) in diameter.
Exception: Guards are not required where personal fall arrest anchorage connector devices that comply with ANSI/ASSE Z 359.1 are installed.

diagrams.title: Example: Roof Access Hatch for Built-Up Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A roof hatch is an access point designed on a roof to allow entry and exit for maintenance, inspection, and emergency purposes.

children.body:
Windows in Group R-2 and R-3 buildings including dwelling units, where the bottom of the clear opening of an operable window is located less than 36 inches (914 mm) above the finished floor and more than 72 inches (1829 mm) above the finished grade or other surface below on the exterior of the building, shall comply with the following:
  1. Where the bottom of the clear opening of the window is located more than 72 inches (1829 mm) and less than 75 feet (22 860 mm) above the finished grade or other surface below on the exterior of the building, the window shall comply with one of the following:
    1.1.  Operable windows where the openings will not allow a 4-inch-diameter (102 mm) sphere to pass through the opening when the window is in its largest opened position, provided that the opening is not required for emergency escape or rescue.
    1.2.  Operable windows where the openings are provided with window fall prevention devices that comply with ASTM F2090.
    1.3.  Operable windows where the openings are provided with window opening control devices that comply with ASTM F2090. The window opening control device, after operation to release the control device allowing the window to fully open, shall not reduce the minimum net clear opening area of the window unit to less than the area required by Section 1031.3.1 for emergency escape and rescue openings.
  2. Where the bottom of the clear opening of the window is located 75 feet (22,860 mm) or more above the finished grade or other surface below on the exterior of the building, the window shall comply with one of the following:
    2.1.  Operable windows where the openings are provided with window fall prevention devices that comply with ASTM F2090.
    2.2.  Operable windows where the openings will not allow a 4-inch-diameter (102 mm) sphere to pass through the opening when the window is in its largest opened position.
    2.3.  Window fall prevention devices that comply with ASTM F2006.

diagrams.title: Window Reqs. in Patient Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the natural daylight and its cycle are important for the psychological well-being of patients the code requires windows in patient rooms. The code defines the minimum window size based on the required clear floor area for the room, which is defined elsewhere in the code. The window must be sized to provide a minimum net glazed area of 8% of the required clear floor area for the room. If the window provided is operable, its operation needs to be limited such that a 4" sphere cannot pass through the opening to prevent accidental falls from the window. In new construction the window sill height may not exceed 36" above the floor. In renovation work where meeting the standards is impractical or impossible the jurisdiction having authority may grant approval to deviate from the requirements noted above.

diagrams.title: Window Fall Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Window fall protection is a safety measure implemented to prevent accidents and injuries, especially for children, due to falls from windows. It typically involves installing devices like window guards, safety nets, window stops, or window-opening control devices that restrict the extent a window can be opened, making it difficult to accidentally fall through the window.

Installation of window fall protection measures ensures that the occupants of a building remain safe from potential accidents. These safety measures are especially crucial in multi-story buildings, where the risk of severe injury or fatalities due to window falls is higher.

diagrams.title: Separation of Exit and Exit Access Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Minimum separation of exits provides for the safe exit from a space, floor or building if one exit becomes blocked. Note that the separation distance applies to any part of the width of the doorway per 1007.1.1.1.

If scissor stairs (not shown here), are connected by a 1-hour fire resistance rated corridor per 1020, exit separation distance may be measured along the corridor. In order to use this measurement method, the corridor must meet the rating requirement, even if Table 1020.1 does not require a rating for the occupancy. The interconnected scissor stairs must also be fully separated per 1023.2.

diagrams.title: Remoteness of Exit Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Remoteness of exit access stairways or ramps refers to the concept where exits are placed a safe distance apart from each other. This helps ensure that if one exit is blocked or compromised in an emergency situation, occupants can still evacuate the building through alternative routes.

diagrams.title: Exit Access, Exit and Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines exit, exit access and exit discharge as the following:

Exit Access: That portion of a means of egress system that leads from any occupied portion of a building or structure to an exit.

Exit: That portion of a means of egress system between the exit access and the exit discharge or public way. Exit components include exterior exit doors at the level of exit discharge, interior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, exterior exit stairways and ramps and horizontal exits.

Exit Discharge: That portion of a means of egress system between the termination of an exit and a public way.

diagrams.title: Separation of Exit and Exit Access Doors (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Minimum separation of exits provides for the safe exit from a space, floor or building if one exit becomes blocked. Note that the separation distance applies to the nearest edges of the width of the doorway per Section 7.5.1.3.2, whereas the building code allows measurement to any point along the doorway.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Basic Components
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Commentary:

The building code requires that a complete means of egress consist of three distinct parts: exit access, exit, and exit discharge. Exit access provides a clear and direct path to exits. An example is a corridor system. Exits are part of the building that provide a higher level of protection than the exit access. Examples include interior exit stairways and exit passageways. Exits then lead to the exit discharge.

The exit discharge provides a path of travel to the public way or safe dispersal area. While this looks straightforward in plan view, the interpretation and implementation can pose challenges when it's considered in three dimensions. Without reviewing site grading, what was budgeted as a sidewalk turns into an expensive stair and ramp combination.

The code defines a public way as at least 10 feet wide and open to the sky, but does not offer a prescriptive definition for safe dispersal areas—leaving it to the AHJ (Authority Having Jurisdiction) to determine what is acceptable. Designers must ensure that such areas are not only at least 50 feet away (per Section 1028) but also provide sufficient space for the expected occupant load, with at least 5 square feet per person.

It is critical to coordinate with landscape and civil disciplines early, since site grading, fencing, and even planting can unintentionally block or reduce the required egress path width.

diagrams.title: Occupant Evacuation Elevator Lobbies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupant evacuation elevator lobbies must be enclosed and provide direct access to an interior exit stairway or a protected path with equivalent fire resistance. These enclosures are not required at exit discharge levels. Lobbies must be enclosed with 1-hr rated smoke barriers, and doors, excluding equipment/ control room doors, must be 3/4-hour fire-rated, include vision panels, and close automatically upon fire alarm activation. Each lobby must be large enough to hold 25% of the floor's occupants at 3 sq ft per person and provide one wheelchair space for every 50 occupants. Signage must indicate the elevators are suitable for evacuation, and a two-way communication system is required to connect with the fire command center or approved location. Also, the Fire Code requires that occupant evacuation elevator lobbies be maintained free of storage and furniture.

diagrams.title: Egress Through an Elevator Lobby
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Egress through intervening spaces lets a person exit a building by going through other rooms or spaces instead of directly into a hallway or exit. The main idea is that exit routes should stay safe, clear, and easy to follow, but there are a few exceptions. You're allowed to exit through elevator lobbies, but at least one exit must be reachable without going through the lobby. In other than Group H occupancy buildings you can also pass through nearby rooms if they're related to the main space and the way out is obvious. For hazardous occupancies, the adjoining room must be the same or a lower hazard level. There are also limits on where exits can go. You can't exit through rooms that can be locked against you, through other people's bedrooms, bathrooms, kitchens, storage rooms, or closets, unless certain conditions are met. In Group M, you can exit through a stockroom, but only if it meets certain requirements. The stock should be the same hazardous class as what's in the main sales area, no more than half the path goes through the stockroom, the door isn't locked, and there's a clearly marked 44" wide aisle that leads directly to the exit. The rules let people use adjoining spaces as exit paths, but only when it's safe, obvious, and not blocked or locked.

children.body: The exit access shall comply with the applicable provisions of Sections 1003 through 1015. Exit access arrangement shall comply with Sections 1016 through 1021.

Egress through intervening spaces shall comply with this section.
  1. Exit access through an enclosed elevator lobby is permitted. Where access to two or more exits or exit access doorways is required in Section 1006.2.1, access to not less than one of the required exits shall be provided without travel through the enclosed elevator lobbies required by Section 3006. Where the path of exit access travel passes through an enclosed elevator lobby, the level of protection required for the enclosed elevator lobby is not required to be extended to the exit unless direct access to an exit is required by other sections of this code.
  2. In other than Group H occupancies, egress from a room or space is allowed to pass through adjoining or intervening rooms or areas provided that such adjoining rooms or areas and the area served are accessory to one or the other and provide a discernible path of egress travel to an exit.
  3. In Group H occupancies, egress from a room or space is allowed to pass through adjoining or intervening rooms or areas provided that such adjoining rooms or areas are the same or lesser hazard occupancy group and provide a discernible path of egress travel to an exit.
  4. An exit access shall not pass through a room that can be locked to prevent egress.
    Exception: An electrically locked exit access door providing egress from an elevator lobby shall be permitted in accordance with Section 1010.2.14.
  5. Means of egress from dwelling units or sleeping areas shall not lead through other sleeping areas, toilet rooms or bathrooms.
  6. Egress shall not pass through kitchens, storage rooms, closets or spaces used for similar purposes.
    Exceptions:
    1. Means of egress are not prohibited through a kitchen area serving adjoining rooms constituting part of the same dwelling unit or sleeping unit.
    2. Means of egress are not prohibited through stockrooms in Group M occupancies where all of the following are met:
      2.1.  The stock is of the same hazard classification as that found in the main retail area.
      2.2.  Not more than 50 percent of the exit access is through the stockroom.
      2.3.  The stockroom is not subject to locking from the egress side.
      2.4.  There is a demarcated, minimum 44-inch-wide (1118 mm) aisle defined by full- or partial-height fixed walls or similar construction that will maintain the required width and lead directly from the retail area to the exit without obstructions.

diagrams.title: Hospital Reception Areas or Lobbies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because there will likely be a disproportionate number of disabled people served by a hospital in comparison to other businesses, the hospital guidelines define what needs to be provided and accessed from within hospital lobbies and reception areas. Within the lobby the following need to be provided:
  • Access to information (typically a reception desk with an attendant).
  • A public waiting area.
  • Public toilet room(s).
  • Access to drinking water.
  • Access to public communications services (phone and internet where available).

diagrams.title: Admissions Area Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The hospital guidelines call out the minimum programmatic requirements for the Admissions Area. An admissions area is required to contain a waiting area for both patients and persons accompanying the patient. A work counter is required for the admissions staff. Space for wheelchair storage that is not within the required path of egress travel is also required.

diagrams.title: Fire Service Elev: Smoke Proof Enclosure
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Service Access Elevators (FSAE) provide a protected means by which firefighters can access occupied building floors more than 120 feet above the lowest level of fire apparatus access. When FSAE are required by 403.6.1, they need to meet the requirements of 3007, including provision for a lobby meeting 3007.6. Lobbies for FSAE must meet specified criteria, including:
  • Lobby is not required for FSAE opening at level of exit discharge
  • FSAE Lobby must have direct access to an interior exit stairway/ramp or by way of an approved path, constructed consistent with requirements of FSAE lobby
  • FSAE lobby must be enclosed by 1-hour smoke barrier
  • FSAE lobby doorways must have minimum 3/4 hour rating meeting smoke/draft control requirements of 716.2.2.1.1
  • 3/4 hour fire door(s) / smoke and draft control assembly(ies)
  • FSAE lobby must be minimum 150 square feet with least dimension not less than 8 feet

NOTE: Stairs or ramps serving floors more than 75 feet above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access shall be a smokeproof enclosure per 403.5.4, designed in accordance with 909.20. Where 3007.6.1 requires direct access from the FSAE to an interior exit stairway or ramp, this should be taken to mean direct access to the smokeproof enclosure that includes the stairway or ramp, such that the FSAE lobby does not compromise the integrity of the smokeproof enclosure. It would be acceptable to have the FSAE lobby directly access a open exterior balcony, ventilated vestibule or pressurized entrance vestibule that provides access to the pressurized stair, as established in 909.20.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

You're allowed to exit through elevator lobbies, but at least one exit must be reachable without going through the lobby. In other than Group H occupancy buildings you can also pass through nearby rooms if they're related to the main space and the way out is obvious. For hazardous occupancies, the adjoining room must be the same or a lower hazard level. There are also limits on where exits can go. You can't exit through rooms that can be locked against you, through other people's bedrooms, bathrooms, kitchens, storage rooms, or closets, unless certain conditions are met. In Group M, you can exit through a stockroom, but only if it meets certain requirements. The stock should be the same hazardous class as what's in the main sales area, no more than half the path goes through the stockroom, the door isn't locked, and there's a clearly marked 44" wide aisle that leads directly to the exit. The rules let people use adjoining spaces as exit paths, but only when it's safe, obvious, and not blocked or locked.

children.body:
Where more than one tenant occupies any one floor of a building or structure, each tenant space, dwelling unit and sleeping unit shall be provided with access to the required exits without passing through adjacent tenant spaces, dwelling units and sleeping units.
Exception: The means of egress from a smaller tenant space shall not be prohibited from passing through a larger adjoining tenant space where such rooms or spaces of the smaller tenant occupy less than 10 percent of the area of the larger tenant space through which they pass; are the same or similar occupancy group; a discernible path of egress travel to an exit is provided; and the means of egress into the adjoining space is not subject to locking from the egress side. A required means of egress serving the larger tenant space shall not pass through the smaller tenant space or spaces.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Increase: Group F-1 and S-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group F-1 and S-1 under special conditions the code allows for the exit access travel to be increased to 400'. All of the following need to be complied with for the increase to be allowed. The building needs to be equipped throughout with a sprinkler system per section 903.1.1.1. The part of the building that is classified as F-1 or S-1 may only be 1 story in height. The ceiling or bottom of the roof deck above the F-1 or S-1 portion of the building must be at least 24' above the floor.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance Measurement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit access travel distance needs to be established for each and every room area or space within a facility. The distance is measured from the most remote location in each space required to be evaluated to the nearest available exit or exit entrance. Exit access travel distance on exit access stairways is at the center line of the stairs tangent to the stair nosings, i.e. it is not the horizontal projection of the centerline of the stair and needs to be the sloped distance of the stairway run. At ramps the measurement is along the centerline of the sloped ramp surface. At landings for ramps and stairs the travel distance is measured along the center line of the landings. The code has an exception for OPEN parking garages where the travel distance may be measured from the most remote location to the center of the closest riser of an exit access stairway or where the slope starts on and exit access ramp. There is an exception for smoke protect or open air assembly seating which needs to be in accordance with section 1030.7.

diagrams.title: Measurement of Travel Distance (NFPA 101)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To measure travel distance to exits, the path must be measured, from the farthest point to an exit, on the walking surface along the centerline of travel. When curving around corners a minimum 12" clearance must be maintained. The travel distance ends in the center of the doorway or where the exit begins.

children.body: Travel distance within the exit access portion of the means of egress system shall be in accordance with this section.

diagrams.title: Travel Distance to Area of Refuge
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area of refuge adjacent to a stairwell is considered an a part of the exit feature itself. It is part of the area of higher protection afforded by a stairwell for the means of egress, as an exit component. Therefore, the exit travel distance should be measured to the area of refuge location.

children.body: Exit access travel distance shall not exceed the values given in Table 1017.2.

diagrams.title: Example: Exit Access Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Common path of egress travel and exit access distances are two different but related concepts. Common path of egress travel measures the distance from the start of egress travel to the point at which occupants have a choice of travel to more than one exit. The exit access travel distance is a cumulative measurement of the common path of travel, and the remaining distance to the nearest exit.

If the common path of egress travel does not provide access to two separate and distinct exits or exit access doorways, within the distance specified by Section 1006, an additional exit or exit access is required. The maximum travel distance in the exit access is dependent on the occupancy group and fire sprinkler status and is limited to that specified by Table 1017.2. So long as the allowable common path of egress travel is met, the exit access travel distance (Table 1017.2) must only be satisfied for the closest exit to the space under consideration.

In the example, a B occupancy with NFPA 13 sprinkler system throughout, the maximum exit access travel distance is 300 feet. Given the dimensions shown, both the common path of egress travel and exit access travel distances are satisfied.

children.body: Exit access travel distances specified in Table 1017.2 shall be increased up to an additional 100 feet (30 480 mm) provided that the last portion of the exit access leading to the exit occurs on an exterior egress balcony constructed in accordance with Section 1021. The length of such balcony shall be not less than the amount of the increase taken.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where balconies are used as an exit pathway, or part of a means of egress, they must be constructed in accordance with the dimensions for corridors listed in Section 1020. Egress balconies must be separated from the interior of the building by a fire rated wall construction, and protected openings. The wall rating can be omitted if there are at least two stairways from the exit balcony. If the balcony creates a dead end corridor situation, then the fire rating separation requirement can be omitted if the path to the stairwell does not pass any unprotected openings. Balconies must have adequate space open to the outside atmosphere to prevent the build up of smoke and allow for safe occupant escape. The code requires this open space to be a minimum of 50%. Egress balconies must be a minimum of 10' from lot lines, other parts of the same building, and other buildings on the same lot. However, if buildings on the same lot are protected in accordance with Section 705, then the 10' clearance can be decreased or eliminated.

  2. The minimum height from the finished floor to the bottom of the ceiling or roof slab or deck is 24 feet (7315 mm).

children.body:
The maximum exit access travel distance shall be 300 feet (91 m) in the fabrication areas of Group H-5 occupancies where all of the following conditions are met:
  1. The width of the fabrication area is 300 feet (91 m) or greater.
  2. The area of the fabrication area is 220,000 square feet (18 600 m2) or greater.
  3. The height of the fabrication area, measured between the raised metal floor and the clean filter ceiling, is 16 feet (48 768 mm) or greater.
  4. The supply ventilation rate is 20 cubic feet per minute per square foot (0.556 m3/min/m2) or greater and shall remain operational.

Exit access travel distance shall be measured from the most remote point of each room, area or space along the natural and unobstructed path of horizontal and vertical egress travel to the entrance to an exit. Where more than one exit is required, exit access travel distance shall be measured to the nearest exit.
Exceptions:
  1. In open parking garages, exit access travel distance is permitted to be measured to the closest riser of an exit access stairway or the closest slope of an exit access ramp.
  2. In smoke protected seating and open air assembly seating, exit access travel distance shall be measured in accordance with Section 1030.7.

diagrams.title: Common Path of Egress Travel
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines COMMON PATH OF EGRESS TRAVEL. as that portion of exit access travel distance measured from the most remote point of each room, area or space to that point where the occupants have separate and distinct access to two exits or exit access doorways.

Common Path of Egress Travel limitations establish the maximum distance occupants may travel before optional egress route(s) must be provided. Rooms or spaces otherwise permitted to exist with one exit access route, by occupancy, use occupant load or stories, will require additional exit access when common path of egress travel exceeds values in Table 1006.2.1. Travel should be measured orthogonally and not as a direct diagonal. The path should be measured along the longest potential path around known and anticipated obstructions to travel, including partitions, tables, chairs, and other fixtures reasonably likely to occur in the space.

Most state codes refer to "Maximum Common Path of Egress Travel Distance" in Table 1006.2.1. New Jersey has amended the table to reference "Exit Access Travel Distance". Exit access travel distance (1017.3) is measured along the "natural and unobstructed path of horizontal... egress travel." This definition would suggest a case-by-case consideration of the appropriate path of travel through a room.

Where a second exit access is provided due to excessive common path of egress travel, the exit access shall be separated per 1007.1.1. Additionally, the separate exit access from a room or space shall provide access to independent exits. Two or more means of egress from a room or space that then converge to depend on a single exit are still considered a common path of egress travel, and do not meet the code intent.

The measurement along stairways shall be made on a plane parallel and tangent to the stair tread nosings in the center of the stair and landings. The measurement along ramps shall be made on the walking surface in the center of the ramp and landings.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stair: Balconies (Ex. 8)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways serving balconies that end in the main assembly space don't have to be enclosed. But keep in mind that unenclosed exit access stairways are not exits. They are a part of the exit access. When the path of exit access includes unenclosed stairways, Section 1017.3.1 requires the distance of travel on such means of egress components to be included in the total travel distance measurement. The measurement along stairways must be made on a plane parallel and tangent to the stair tread nosings in the center of the stairway. This increases the actual exit path distance compared to a simple plan view measurement.

diagrams.title: Aisles with Tables and Fixtures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Aisle accessways and aisles must be maintained in areas where non-fixed seating exists. Chairs and tables are easy to be moved, rearranged and placed in locations that block aisle accessways and aisles. Even though this is not typically a feature installed during construction, the design of the space and operations after occupancy must continue to consider this code requirement.

diagrams.title: Aisle Req. by Occ. Group
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where an aisle or aisle accessway is used as a part of means of egress, it must meet the requirements of this section. The required clearances must be maintained throughout the entirety of the aisle or accessway. For assembly occupancies this section sends the user to Section 1029. For all other occupancy groups the user is sent to section 1005.1, Means of Egress Sizing. This section provides an exception for nonpublic aisles that serve occupant loads of less than 50, for these areas the minimum aisle width can be reduced to 28". Specific to Group M occupancies with merchandise pads, the aisle space between the merchandise pads cannot be less than 30" and the travel distance from these merchandise pads to the path of egress cannot exceed 30'.

Careful attention should also be paid to accessibility requirements of the ADA and state and local accessibility regulations. In such cases where an accessible aisle is required, which includes many work areas, the minimum width is 36", and allows a narrowing of the aisle due to impingements or obstructions to a maximum length of 24" of travel

children.body:
Aisles and aisle accessways serving as a portion of the exit access in the means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of this section. Aisles or aisle accessways shall be provided from all occupied portions of the exit access that contain seats, tables, furnishings, displays and similar fixtures or equipment. The minimum width or required capacity of aisles shall be unobstructed.
Exception: Encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Aisles at Tables (NFPA 101)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Rooms used for assembly purposes that contains seats, tables, displays, similar fixtures or equipment are also required to maintain the basic concepts of the means of egress. Many of these items may be placed after the Certificate of Occupancy is issued. It's imperative that the placement be part of any design so that the Owner and their representatives will be able to ensure compliance with this section post-occupancy, without the benefit of inspections by the AHJ. Lack of maintained aisles can lead to a hazardous situation, especially in an event that has full occupancy of the space.
