The required clearances must be maintained throughout the entirety of the aisle or accessway. For assembly occupancies this section sends the user to Section 1029. For all other occupancy groups the user is sent to section 1005.1, Means of Egress Sizing. This section provides an exception for nonpublic aisles that serve occupant loads of less than 50, for these areas the minimum aisle width can be reduced to 28". Specific to Group M occupancies with merchandise pads, the aisle space between the merchandise pads cannot be less than 30" and the travel distance from these merchandise pads to the path of egress cannot exceed 30'.

Careful attention should also be paid to accessibility requirements of the ADA and state and local accessibility regulations. In such cases where an accessible aisle is required, which includes many work areas, the minimum width is 36", and allows a narrowing of the aisle due to impingements or obstructions to a maximum length of 24" of travel

children.displayTitle: 1018.5 Aisles in Other Than Assembly Spaces and Groups B and M
children.titleText: Aisles in Other Than Assembly Spaces and Groups B and M

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairs: Accessible Means of Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1009.3.1 is to ensure that all different accessible floor areas and levels within the same story are provided with an accessible means of egress as required by section 1009.1. It does so by eliminating exit access stairways that interconnect different levels on the same story as part of an accessible means of egress. Section 1009.3.1 also provides a special exception for exit access stairways that serve mezzanines to be a part of an accessible means of egress.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairway Enclosures: I-2 and I-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 and I-3 occupancies exit access stairways or ramps are always required to be enclosed in a shaft enclosure as required by section 713, 2 hour fire resistance where connecting 4 or more stories and not less than 1 hour fire resistance when connecting less than 4 stories (713.4). There is an exception for I-3 occupancies that allows for 1 interior exit stairway enclosure to be glazed provided all the requirements spelled out in section 408.3.8 are met, but even this exception requires the stairway to be enclosed and essentially a smoke protected environment. In California, this also applies to Group R-2.1 occupancies.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairways at Same Story
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An exit access stairway is an essential component of the means of egress system within a building. It connects differing levels within a building, typically serving floor levels within one or multiple stories, and guides occupants towards an exit from the building. When the exit access stairway is serving areas within the same story, those stairways are not required to be enclosed.

diagrams.title: Exit Stairways in Atriums
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways in atriums have several requirements to be met, per Section 404.10, in order for them to be used as an interior exit stairway. This shows the upper floor level of an atrium condition. The level of exit discharge shall comply with Section 1028.

diagrams.title: Atriums: Exiting, Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The maximum exit access travel distance is generally regulated by section 1017. The same is true for travel within an atrium at the level of exit discharge. However, when exit access traverses space open to an atrium, above or below the level of exit discharge, Section 404.9 restricts such travel to 200 feet of the total distance.

For example, if the maximum allowable distance (T-1017.2) is 300 feet, up to 100 feet may occur in tenant/dwelling space then up to 200 feet within the atrium before reaching a qualifying exit. The cumulative exit access travel distance to an exit must not exceed that specified in T-1017.2.

When the level of exit discharge includes an atrium, not more than 50 percent of the required exits may discharge to areas open to the atrium. This is consistent with permissible exit discharge interior to the building, per Section 1028.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A means of egress is an unobstructed path to leave buildings, structures, and spaces. A means of egress is comprised of exit access, exit, and exit discharge. An accessible means of egress, as defined by the code, is a "continuous and unobstructed way of egress travel from any point in a building or facility that provides an accessible route to an area of refuge, a horizontal exit, or a public way." Where more than one means of egress is required from any accessible space, each accessible portion of the space must be served by at least two accessible means of egress. Accessible spaces can be served by one accessible means of egress only where the code permits one means of egress.

children.displayTitle: Section 1019 Exit Access Stairways and Ramps

children.body: Exit access stairways and ramps serving as an exit access component in a means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of this section. The number of stories connected by exit access stairways and ramps shall include basements, but not mezzanines.
Exit access stairways and ramps that serve floor levels within a single story are not required to be enclosed.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairways at Same Story
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An exit access stairway is an essential component of the means of egress system within a building. It connects differing levels within a building, typically serving floor levels within one or multiple stories, and guides occupants towards an exit from the building. When the exit access stairway is serving areas within the same story, those stairways are not required to be enclosed.

children.body:
In other than Group I-2 and I-3 occupancies, floor openings containing exit access stairways or ramps shall be enclosed with a shaft enclosure constructed in accordance with Section 713.
Exceptions:
  1. Exit access stairways and ramps within a two-story opening complying with Section 712.1.9.
  2. In Group R-1, R-2 or R-3 occupancies, exit access stairways and ramps connecting four stories or less serving and contained within an individual dwelling unit or sleeping unit or live/work unit.
  3. Exit access stairways serving and contained within a Group R-3 congregate residence or a Group R-4 facility are not required to be enclosed.
  4. Exit access stairways and ramps in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, where the area of the vertical opening between stories does not exceed twice the horizontal projected area of the stairway or ramp and the opening is protected by a draft curtain and closely spaced sprinklers in accordance with NFPA 13. In other than Group B and M occupancies, this provision is limited to openings that do not connect more than four stories.
  5. Exit access stairways and ramps within an atrium complying with the provisions of Section 404.
  6. Exit access stairways and ramps in open parking garages that serve only the parking garage.
  7. Exit access stairways and ramps serving smoke-protected or open-air assembly seating complying with the exit access travel distance requirements of Section 1030.7.
  8. Exit access stairways and ramps between the balcony, gallery or press box and the main assembly floor in occupancies such as theaters, places of religious worship, auditoriums and sports facilities.
  9. Exterior exit access stairways or ramps between occupiable roofs.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stair: Occupied Roofs (Ex. 9)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exit access stairs between different levels of occupied roofs are not requried to be enclosed. Similar to smoke-protected or open-air seating areas, the risk of smoke accumulation is low, reducing the risk.

Remember that the number of stairways, travel distance, separation of stairs and other requirements still must comply with Chapter 10, even though they are not required to be enclosed.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stair: Balconies (Ex. 8)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways serving balconies that end in the main assembly space don't have to be enclosed. But keep in mind that unenclosed exit access stairways are not exits. They are a part of the exit access. When the path of exit access includes unenclosed stairways, Section 1017.3.1 requires the distance of travel on such means of egress components to be included in the total travel distance measurement. The measurement along stairways must be made on a plane parallel and tangent to the stair tread nosings in the center of the stairway. This increases the actual exit path distance compared to a simple plan view measurement.

diagrams.title: Enclosure of Atriums: Exceptions 6 & 7 - Escalators and Exit Access Stairs

children.displayTitle: 1019.3 Occupancies Other Than Groups I-2 and I-3
children.titleText: Occupancies Other Than Groups I-2 and I-3

children.body:
In Group I-2 and I-3 occupancies, floor openings between stories containing exit access stairways or ramps are required to be enclosed with a shaft enclosure constructed in accordance with Section 713.
Exception: In Group I-3 occupancies, exit access stairways or ramps constructed in accordance with Section 408 are not required to be enclosed.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairway Enclosures: I-2 and I-3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 and I-3 occupancies exit access stairways or ramps are always required to be enclosed in a shaft enclosure as required by section 713, 2 hour fire resistance where connecting 4 or more stories and not less than 1 hour fire resistance when connecting less than 4 stories (713.4). There is an exception for I-3 occupancies that allows for 1 interior exit stairway enclosure to be glazed provided all the requirements spelled out in section 408.3.8 are met, but even this exception requires the stairway to be enclosed and essentially a smoke protected environment. In California, this also applies to Group R-2.1 occupancies.

diagrams.title: Egress Balconies: Wall Separation (Life Safety Code)
Corridor Widths in Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Life and Safety Code and the Building Code. Section 18.2.3.4 of Life and Safety Code calls for exit access corridors to have width not less than 8'. Section 1020.3 of the building code calls for the width to be the greater width as determined by occupant load per section 1005.1 or per Table 1020.2 (or Table 1020.3). This table calls for 96" minimum width for exit access corridors in areas required for bed movement and 44" minimum width in areas where bed movement is not required. The width may be reduced to 6' at fixed furniture provided the width meets the occupant load egress required per section 1005.1 of the building code. The hospital facilities guidelines code calls for corridor width to comply with two other codes.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Air Movement Above Corridor
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1020.6.1 addresses how and when the space above the ceiling of a corridor may be utilized as a return air plenum and calls for 1 or more of 5 conditions being met to ensure the corridor's safety is not compromised.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Air Movement within Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1020.6 is to ensure that corridors remain as smoke-free as reasonably possible in the event of an emergency. The section limits how the way air in corridors may be shared with other spaces within the building by expressly prohibiting the corridors to be used as ventilation air ducts. The code makes exceptions for a few specific conditions. Corridors within tenant spaces 1000 sf or less and within dwelling units may be used for return air conveyance. Service rooms with exhaust systems that open directly onto the corridor may be utilized for makeup air provided the corridor is directly supplied with a greater quantity of outdoor makeup air. Within healthcare facilities air movement required to maintain required pressure differences in accordance with ASHRAE 170 are permitted.

Section 1020.6.1 addresses how and when the space above the ceiling of a corridor may be utilized as a return air plenum and calls for 1 or more of 5 conditions to be met to ensure the corridor's safety is not compromised.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Dead end corridors provide access to an exit in only one direction. Because of this, they provide a unique hazard in emergency conditions. Therefore, the length of dead end corridors are limited. Dead end corridor lengths are not limited where only one exit or exit access is required.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridor Measurement
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In facilities or spaces that require access to more than one means of egress, dead-end corridors may not exceed 20 feet in length. The code provides an exception for Group I-3,Condition 2, 3 or 4, occupancies where dead-end corridors may not exceed 50 feet. The code provide an exception for Groups B, E, F, I-1, M, R-1, R-2, S and U, occupancies that are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system where dead-end corridors may not exceed 50feet. The last exception notes dead-end corridor length is not limited where the corridor's length does not exceed 2.5 times its narrowest width.

Starting with the 2021 year cycle, an exception was added for Group I-2, Condition 2 occupancies. The length of dead-end corridors that do not serve patient rooms or patient treatment spaces shall not exceed 30 feet in that occupancy group.

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Corridor Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units In I-1 and Group R occupancies
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.0
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

diagrams.title: Exit Separation Distance with Rated Corridors - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If exit stair enclosures are connected with a one-hour rated corridor, the required exit separation distance can be measured along the shortest direct line of travel within the corridor instead of the standard one-half of the diagonal of the area served (Building Code, Reference: 1007.1.1, Exception 1). The corridor must conform to the requirements of Sections 1020 and 708.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridors (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Dead end corridors provide access to an exit in only one direction. Because of this, they provide a unique hazard in emergency conditions. Therefore, the length of dead end corridors are limited. Dead end corridor lengths are not limited where only one exit or exit access is required.

diagrams.title: Handrails at Hospital Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The hospital guidelines call for handrails on both sides of corridors used by patients. Rails are require to be continuous with exceptions being made for doors, nurses stations, alcoves, fire extinguisher cabinets and where features are less than 24" apart (2022). Railing ends are required to return wall or floor. The gripping surface is required to be smooth and free of sharp or abrasive conditions, with 1/8"min. radius. Edges and corners are required to be eased. The finish of the railing must contrast with the wall surface finish by a minimum of 30% and be able to withstand cleaning and disinfection.

diagrams.title: Exit Separation at Scissor Stairs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit Separation at Scissor Stairs: If scissor stairs (not shown here), are connected by a 1-hour fire resistance rated corridor per 1020, exit separation distance may be measured along the corridor. In order to use this measurement method, the corridor must meet the rating requirement, even if Table 1020.1 does not require a rating for the occupancy. The interconnected scissor stairs must also be fully separated per 1023.2.

diagrams.title: Corridor Width Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Corridor widths are determined by the total occupants feeding into the corridor without consideration for how many exits are from that corridor. If a Emergency Voice / Alarm Communications System is used with either an NFPA 13 or 13R system, then a narrower corridor is possible if the corridor does not serve an H or I-2 occupancy space.

children.body: Corridors serving as an exit access component in a means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of Sections 1020.2 through 1020.7.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Sprinklered, 75-120 ft) - 2024
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(4))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(6)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(6) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7).
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1).
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), §1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless:
    (a) the shaft is pressurized, or
    (b) "S" (smoke) label (swinging) doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors). (§3006.2 + §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)
  10. Exit access corridors must have direct access to at least one exit not requiring passage through the enclosed elevator lobby. (§1016.2(1) + §3006.2)
  11. Rated corridors are not required for corridors serving these occupancy groups (Table 1020.2)
    Corridors which connect an elevator lobby to an exit are not required to be fire rated (§1016.2(1))
  12. (Reserved)
  13. (Reserved)
  14. (Reserved)
  15. (Reserved)
  16. (Reserved)
  17. An enclosed elevator lobby requires (nonrated) smoke partitions. (§3006.3(2))
  18. Enclosed elevator lobby doors must be self-closing "S" (smoke) label doors. (§3006.3(2) + §710.5.2.2 and §710.5.2.3)
  19. Elevator shafts require 2-hour fire barriers. (§713.4)
  20. Elevator shafts require 90-minute (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2)) automatic-closing (§716.2.6.6) fire doors. An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), provided the mitigation described in Note 9 is provided. (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2) and §716.2.6.6)
  21. Enclosed exit stairways require 2-hour fire barriers. (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways require 90-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) label. (§707.6 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)

children.body:
Corridors shall be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Table 1020.2. The corridor walls required to be fire-resistance rated shall comply with Section 708 for fire partitions.
Exceptions:
  1. A fire-resistance rating is not required for corridors in an occupancy in Group E where each room that is used for instruction has not less than one door opening directly to the exterior and rooms for assembly purposes have not less than one-half of the required means of egress doors opening directly to the exterior. Exterior doors specified in this exception are required to be at ground level.
  2. A fire-resistance rating is not required for corridors contained within a dwelling unit or sleeping unit in an occupancy in Groups I-1 and R.
  3. A fire-resistance rating is not required for corridors in open parking garages.
  4. A fire-resistance rating is not required for corridors in an occupancy in Group B that is a space requiring only a single means of egress complying with Section 1006.2.
  5. Corridors adjacent to the exterior walls of buildings shall be permitted to have unprotected openings on unrated exterior walls where unrated walls are permitted by Table 705.5 and unprotected openings are permitted by Table 705.9.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated wall assemblies are of three varieties: fire walls, fire barriers and fire partitions. Fire barriers can be used as shaft enclosures, occupancy separations and others. Fire partitions are often used as demising walls and corridor separations, among other uses.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Corridor Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units In I-1 and Group R occupancies
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.0
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

diagrams.title: Fire Partition Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Construction requirements for fire partitions include continuity to floors above or below and foundations to preclude the passage of fire and smoke from one area to another, to prevent an "end-run" effect that would compromise the protection provided.

diagrams.title: Fire Partition Continuity: Corridors (Ex. 2.1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 708.4 Exception 2.1 more easily applies to floor construction that does not have cavities within, such as wood or light gauge metal joists. In those situations, special care needs to be paid to the detailing of the room side membrane extending to the floor/roof sheathing above.

diagrams.title: Fire Partition Continuity: Corridors (Ex. 2.2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 708.4 Exception 2.2 allows the presence of NFPA13 or NFPA13R (where allowed) automatic sprinkler systems above a fire partition to provide equivalent protection as the extension of the fire partitions at a corridor to the underside of the floor above.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Multiple Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a building is comprised of multiple occupancies, the means of egress serving each occupancy shall apply to that portion of the building for which it is provided.

Example 1: in a building that is part B occupancy and part H-4 occupancy where each is provided it's own exit corridor, the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the B occupancy need not be rated and the exit corridor within and exclusively serving the H-4 occupancy is required to have a 1-hour fire resistance (per Table 1020.1). When a means of egress component is utilized or shared by two or more occupancies the component shall be required to meet the most stringent requirements of the occupancies served.

Example 2: in a mixed use building where a B occupancy and an H-4 occupancy share an exit corridor the exit corridor must have a 1-hour fire resistance rating as that (as we know from Example 1) is the most stringent corridor requirement of the uses that will share the corridor. The applicable requirements apply to the entire component, not just the walls or elements adjacent to each occupancy, i.e. both sides of the corridor for the entire length in the example would be required to meet the requirements for 1-hour fire resistant construction for it to be shared by both a B and H-4 occupancy.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Travel Distance
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where balconies are used as an exit pathway, or part of a means of egress, they must be constructed in accordance with the dimensions for corridors listed in Section 1020. Egress balconies must be separated from the interior of the building by a fire rated wall construction, and protected openings. The wall rating can be omitted if there are at least two stairways from the exit balcony. If the balcony creates a dead end corridor situation, then the fire rating separation requirement can be omitted if the path to the stairwell does not pass any unprotected openings. Balconies must have adequate space open to the outside atmosphere to prevent the build up of smoke and allow for safe occupant escape. The code requires this open space to be a minimum of 50%. Egress balconies must be a minimum of 10' from lot lines, other parts of the same building, and other buildings on the same lot. However, if buildings on the same lot are protected in accordance with Section 705, then the 10' clearance can be decreased or eliminated.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Nonsprinklered, 0-75 ft) - 2024
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited except for rooms with an electrically locked exit access door providing egress from an elevator lobby shall be permitted in accordance with Section 1010.2.14 (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. In other than group H occupancies, egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2)). In group H occupancies, egress through adjoining or intervening room or areas of the same or lesser hazard occupancy group with a discernible path of egress travel to an exit is allowed.
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7)
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1)
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby, is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), 1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed elevator lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless (a)the shaft is pressurized, or (b)smoke-stop doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors) (§716.2.2.1.1). This applies for all rated corridors, even if smoke protection for the elevator shaft is not required per §3006.2. (Table 1020.2 + Table 716.1(2) + 716.2.2.1) (If the elevator connects 4 or more floors, the enclosed elevator lobby is also required per §3006.2, except at the level of exit discharge.)
  10. At least one exit without passing through the enclosed elevator lobby.(§1016.2(1)
  11. Corridors require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2)

children.body: Elevator hoistway doors in elevators hoistway enclosures required to be fire-resistance rated shall be protected in accordance with Section 716. Elevator hoistway doors shall also be protected in accordance with Section 3006.2.

The required capacity of corridors shall be determined as specified in Section 1005.1, but the minimum width shall be not less than that specified in Table 1020.3.
Exception: In Group I-2 occupancies, corridors are not required to have a clear width of 96 inches (2438 mm) in areas where there will not be stretcher or bed movement for access to care or as part of the defend-in-place strategy.

diagrams.title: Corridor Widths in Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Life and Safety Code and the Building Code. Section 18.2.3.4 of Life and Safety Code calls for exit access corridors to have width not less than 8'. Section 1020.3 of the building code calls for the width to be the greater width as determined by occupant load per section 1005.1 or per Table 1020.2 (or Table 1020.3). This table calls for 96" minimum width for exit access corridors in areas required for bed movement and 44" minimum width in areas where bed movement is not required. The width may be reduced to 6' at fixed furniture provided the width meets the occupant load egress required per section 1005.1 of the building code. The hospital facilities guidelines code calls for corridor width to comply with two other codes.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Unobstructed Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The unobstructed width of a corridor is determined based on the specific occupancy and utilization of the structure. Corridors must maintain their minimum required width or capacity unobstructed, to ensure safe and easy passage. However, under specific circumstances, exceptions are allowed which include encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Corridor Width Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Corridor widths are determined by the total occupants feeding into the corridor without consideration for how many exits are from that corridor. If a Emergency Voice / Alarm Communications System is used with either an NFPA 13 or 13R system, then a narrower corridor is possible if the corridor does not serve an H or I-2 occupancy space.

children.body:
The minimum width or required capacity of corridors shall be unobstructed.
Exception: Encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Projections in Nursing Home Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 occupancies, as long as the corridor width is not less than 96", furniture is allowed to project into the corridor as long as the furniture is attached to the floor or wall, does not reduce the clear width to less than 72", is positioned on only one side of the corridor, does not exceed 50 sq. ft. in area, is separated from other furniture pieces by 10' minimum and it is considered as part of the dire and safety plans in accordance with Section 1002.2.

diagrams.title: Doors: Swing & Hardware (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Hospital Guidelines, Except for doors serving non-habitable spaces, doors may not swing into corridors unless provided with an alcove that is deep enough to contain the door swing. Latching lever or push/pull type strike side hardware is required on doors except for some operating room conditions. Operating rooms in a designated suite that do not open to an egress corridor are not required to have latching hardware and may be self-closing with push/pull plates.

children.body:
Where more than one exit or exit access doorway is required, the exit access shall be arranged such that dead-end corridors do not exceed 20 feet (6096 mm) in length.
Exceptions:
  1. In Group I-3, Condition 2, 3 or 4, occupancies, the dead end in a corridor shall not exceed 50 feet (15 240 mm).
  2. In occupancies in Groups B, E, F, I-1, M, R-1, R-2, S and U, where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, the length of the dead-end corridors shall not exceed 50 feet (15 240 mm).
  3. A dead-end corridor shall not be limited in length where the length of the dead-end corridor is less than 2.5 times the least width of the dead-end corridor.
  4. In Group I-2, Condition 2 occupancies, the length of dead-end corridors that do not serve patient rooms or patient treatment spaces shall not exceed 30 feet (9144 mm).

diagrams.title: Example: Single Exit Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Non-Sprinklered

Spaces are allowed to have only a single exit if they have less than a prescribed amount of occupants, depending on the occupancy group. Also, the common path of egress travel must be less than that allowed by Table 1006.2.1. However, dead end corridors themselves are not limited when only one exit is required.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Dead end corridors provide access to an exit in only one direction. Because of this, they provide a unique hazard in emergency conditions. Therefore, the length of dead end corridors are limited. Dead end corridor lengths are not limited where only one exit or exit access is required.

diagrams.title: Dead End Corridor Measurement
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In facilities or spaces that require access to more than one means of egress, dead-end corridors may not exceed 20 feet in length. The code provides an exception for Group I-3,Condition 2, 3 or 4, occupancies where dead-end corridors may not exceed 50 feet. The code provide an exception for Groups B, E, F, I-1, M, R-1, R-2, S and U, occupancies that are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system where dead-end corridors may not exceed 50feet. The last exception notes dead-end corridor length is not limited where the corridor's length does not exceed 2.5 times its narrowest width.

Starting with the 2021 year cycle, an exception was added for Group I-2, Condition 2 occupancies. The length of dead-end corridors that do not serve patient rooms or patient treatment spaces shall not exceed 30 feet in that occupancy group.

children.body:
Corridors shall not serve as supply, return, exhaust, relief or ventilation air ducts.
Exceptions:
  1. Use of a corridor as a source of makeup air for exhaust systems in rooms that open directly onto such corridors, including toilet rooms, bathrooms, dressing rooms, smoking lounges and janitor closets, shall be permitted, provided that each such corridor is directly supplied with outdoor air at a rate greater than the rate of makeup air taken from the corridor.
  2. Where located within a dwelling unit, the use of corridors for conveying return air shall not be prohibited.
  3. Where located within tenant spaces of 1,000 square feet (93 m2) or less in area, utilization of corridors for conveying return air is permitted.
  4.  Transfer air movement required to maintain the pressurization difference within health care facilities in accordance with ASHRAE 170.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Air Movement Above Corridor
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1020.6.1 addresses how and when the space above the ceiling of a corridor may be utilized as a return air plenum and calls for 1 or more of 5 conditions being met to ensure the corridor's safety is not compromised.

diagrams.title: Corridors: Air Movement within Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1020.6 is to ensure that corridors remain as smoke-free as reasonably possible in the event of an emergency. The section limits how the way air in corridors may be shared with other spaces within the building by expressly prohibiting the corridors to be used as ventilation air ducts. The code makes exceptions for a few specific conditions. Corridors within tenant spaces 1000 sf or less and within dwelling units may be used for return air conveyance. Service rooms with exhaust systems that open directly onto the corridor may be utilized for makeup air provided the corridor is directly supplied with a greater quantity of outdoor makeup air. Within healthcare facilities air movement required to maintain required pressure differences in accordance with ASHRAE 170 are permitted.

Section 1020.6.1 addresses how and when the space above the ceiling of a corridor may be utilized as a return air plenum and calls for 1 or more of 5 conditions to be met to ensure the corridor's safety is not compromised.

diagrams.title: Non-rated Doors in Group I-2 Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At Group I-2 corridors, non rated doors shall comply with following requirements; solid doors must fit tightly with proper stops; Dutch-style doors require proper edge treatments, latching hardware on both sections, and a mechanism to operate as one unit. To provide for makeup air for exhaust systems, doors may include louvers or a bottom clearance of up to 2/3 inch.

children.body:
Use of the space between the corridor ceiling and the floor or roof structure above as a return air plenum is permitted for one or more of the following conditions:
  1. The corridor is not required to be of fire-resistance-rated construction.
  2. The corridor is separated from the plenum by fire-resistance-rated construction.
  3. The air-handling system serving the corridor is shut down upon activation of the air-handling unit smoke detectors required by the International Mechanical Code.
  4. The air-handling system serving the corridor is shut down upon detection of sprinkler water flow where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system.
  5. The space between the corridor ceiling and the floor or roof structure above the corridor is used as a component of an approved engineered smoke control system.

diagrams.title: Plenum (definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A plenum is an enclosed portion of the building structure, other than an occupiable space being conditioned, that is designed to allow air movement, and thereby serve as part of an air distribution system. The Life Safety Code further defines that at least one duct connects to this component.

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Slip Joint Plan: Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors. Free joints allow for the movement of ceilings and walls in a way that does not contribute to compression induced buckling of suspended ceiling members.

source: oshpd.ca.gov OPD CL2.30

diagrams.title: Plenums: General Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The mechanical code allows the following spaces to be utilized as plenums for supply, return, exhaust and relief ventilation purposes:
  • Uninhabited crawl spaces
  • Areas above a ceiling
  • Areas below a floor
  • Uninhabited attic spaces
  • Mechanical equipment rooms
The mechanical code allows wall stud cavity spaces and the spaces between solid floor joists to be utilized as plenums for return, exhaust and relief ventilation purposes when in compliance with section 602.3. Appliances installed within plenums may not be fuel-fired appliances.

children.body:
Fire-resistance-rated corridors shall be continuous from the point of entry to an exit, and shall not be interrupted by intervening rooms. Where the path of egress travel within a fire-resistance-rated corridor to the exit includes travel along unenclosed exit access stairways or ramps, the fire-resistance rating shall be continuous for the length of the stairway or ramp and for the length of the connecting corridor on the adjacent floor leading to the exit.
Exceptions:
  1. Foyers, lobbies or reception rooms constructed as required for corridors shall not be construed as intervening rooms.
  2. Enclosed elevator lobbies as permitted by Item 1 of Section 1016.2 shall not be construed as intervening rooms.

diagrams.title: Foyers and Lobbies (Group A-1) Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1029.4 provides the requirements that ensure that lobbies may be exited safely and do not reduce the exiting capacity for the associated A-1 assembly space. It requires that the Foyer or Lobby space does not encroach upon or reduce the capacity of any of the components of the required means of egress for the assembly space. The lobby is required to have a direct connection to all of the main entries and exits or it shall be connected by an unobstructed and straight corridor or path of travel to all main entries and exits.

The lobby is required to have a direct connection to all of the main entries and exits or it shall be connected by an unobstructed and straight corridor or path of travel to all main entries and exits.

  16. Foyers, lobbies, or reception rooms serving a rated corridor require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (§1020.7 Exception 1 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1).
  17. Any enclosed elevator lobby bisecting a rated corridor requires 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2).
  18. Corridor doors at an enclosed elevator lobby must be 20-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).
  19. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Shafts connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§713.4). In Type I construction, 2-hour fire barriers are required in all cases (§713.4 + Table 601).
  20. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute automatic-closing smoke-activated fire doors. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §713.7 + §716.2.6.6). An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), but the mitigation described in Note 9 is mandatory
  21. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Stair enclosures connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1)

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Egress Balcony Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.1
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

diagrams.title: Egress Balconies: Location
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where balconies are used as an exit pathway, or part of a means of egress, they must be constructed in accordance with the dimensions for corridors listed in Section 1020. Egress balconies must be separated from the interior of the building by a fire rated wall construction, and protected openings. The wall rating can be omitted if there are at least two stairways from the exit balcony. If the balcony creates a dead end corridor situation, then the fire rating separation requirement can be omitted if the path to the stairwell does not pass any unprotected openings. Balconies must have adequate space open to the outside atmosphere to prevent the build up of smoke and allow for safe occupant escape. The code requires this open space to be a minimum of 50%. Egress balconies must be a minimum of 10' from lot lines, other parts of the same building, and other buildings on the same lot. However, if buildings on the same lot are protected in accordance with Section 705, then the 10' clearance can be decreased or eliminated.

diagrams.title: Egress Balconies: Openness
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where balconies are used as an exit pathway, balconies must have adequate space open to the outside atmosphere to prevent the build up of smoke and allow for safe occupant escape. The building code requires this open space to be a minimum of 50%.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

Egress balconies must be a minimum of 10' from lot lines, other parts of the same building, and other buildings on the same lot. However, if buildings on the same lot are protected in accordance with Section 705, then the 10' clearance can be decreased or eliminated.

diagrams.title: Balcony Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Ventilating balconies is important so that moisture is able to escape, and dry rot is prevented for wood framing members in concealed conditions. When the covering of the balcony leaks and allows rainwater to intrude, or condensation occurs inside the concealed space from the humidity in the air, a method of ventilating the space is important, just like in crawlspaces and attics.

diagrams.title: Exterior Wall Projections
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.2 defines the extent to which elements may project beyond the face of an exterior building wall. The designer must know where the Fire Separation Line is located relative to the wall from which the element will project. This will define the Fire Separation Distance for the wall and then use table 705.2 to determine the minimum distance the projection must remain from the Fire Separation Line. i.e.: The allowable projection or overhang is the FSD minus the minimum allowable projection distance from the Fire Separation Line.

Section 705.2 references section 1405 which defines the materials from which the projections may be comprised of. If the projection is an exterior egress balcony it will need to be protected per section 1021. If the projection is an exterior exit stairway or ramp the projection will need to be protected per sections 1027.

children.body: Balconies used for egress purposes shall conform to the same requirements as corridors for minimum width, required capacity, headroom, dead ends and projections.

Exterior egress balconies shall be separated from the interior of the building by walls and opening protectives as required for corridors.
Exception: Separation is not required where the exterior egress balcony is served by not less than two stairways and a dead-end travel condition does not require travel past an unprotected opening to reach a stairway.

  2. Other portions of the building.
  3. Other buildings on the same lot unless the adjacent building exterior walls and openings are protected in accordance with Section 705 based on fire separation distance.

Egress balconies must be separated from the interior of the building by a fire rated wall construction, and protected openings. diagrams.title: Exterior Egress Door Arrangement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1022.2.2 is to ensure that exits lead to a location that provides adequate escape from the building upon exiting. It ensures that all exits provide adequate access to a public way, either directly or via an exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Exit Access, Exit and Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines exit, exit access and exit discharge as the following:

Exit Access: That portion of a means of egress system that leads from any occupied portion of a building or structure to an exit.

Exit: That portion of a means of egress system between the exit access and the exit discharge or public way. Exit components include exterior exit doors at the level of exit discharge, interior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, exterior exit stairways and ramps and horizontal exits.

Exit Discharge: That portion of a means of egress system between the termination of an exit and a public way.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Basic Components
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Commentary:

The building code requires that a complete means of egress consist of three distinct parts: exit access, exit, and exit discharge. Exit access provides a clear and direct path to exits. An example is a corridor system. Exits are part of the building that provide a higher level of protection than the exit access. Examples include interior exit stairways and exit passageways. Exits then lead to the exit discharge.

The exit discharge provides a path of travel to the public way or safe dispersal area. While this looks straightforward in plan view, the interpretation and implementation can pose challenges when it's considered in three dimensions. Without reviewing site grading, what was budgeted as a sidewalk turns into an expensive stair and ramp combination.

The code defines a public way as at least 10 feet wide and open to the sky, but does not offer a prescriptive definition for safe dispersal areas—leaving it to the AHJ (Authority Having Jurisdiction) to determine what is acceptable. Designers must ensure that such areas are not only at least 50 feet away (per Section 1028) but also provide sufficient space for the expected occupant load, with at least 5 square feet per person.

It is critical to coordinate with landscape and civil disciplines early, since site grading, fencing, and even planting can unintentionally block or reduce the required egress path width.

children.body: Exits shall comply with Sections 1022 through 1027 and the applicable requirements of Sections 1003 through 1015. An exit shall not be used for any purpose that interferes with its function as a means of egress. Once a given level of exit protection is achieved, such level of protection shall not be reduced until arrival at the exit discharge. Exits shall be continuous from the point of entry into the exit to the exit discharge.
Buildings or structures used for human occupancy shall have not less than one exterior door that meets the requirements of Section 1010.1.1.

diagrams.title: Ext. Doors and the Public Way
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Windows and door are not permitted to open or project into the public right-of-way.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

children.body: Exterior exit doors shall comply with the applicable requirements of Section 1010.1.
Exterior exit doors shall lead directly to the exit discharge or the public way.

diagrams.title: Exterior Egress Door Arrangement
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1022.2.2 is to ensure that exits lead to a location that provides adequate escape from the building upon exiting. It ensures that all exits provide adequate access to a public way, either directly or via an exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1023.4 defines the type of wall openings that may be placed in interior exit stair walls. The only openings allowed in interior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures are exit doors that provide access to the stairway enclosure from normally occupied spaces and for exiting from the enclosure. Since interior exit stairways need to be separated from the rest of the building by vertical fire barriers (707) or a rated horizontal assembly (711), section 1023.4 also requires any openings in the interior walls to be protected in accordance with section 716. The actual level of opening protection required is established by table 716.1(2) which defines the rating/level of protection of any openings between an interior space and the exit stairway. 1023.4 further clarifies that elevators may not open into interior exit stairway enclosures.

diagrams.title: Area of Refuge Access to Stairway or Elevator
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Areas of refuge are fire-resistance rated and smoke protected areas where those unable to use stairs can register a call for evacuation assistance and await instructions or assistance. They must provide direct access to an exit stairway (or to an elevator equipped with standby power). Horizontal exits can substitute for areas of refuge.

When areas of refuge are not designed to be directly in the stairway enclosure, the area of refuge must generally be directly adjacent to the stairway, accessible means-of-egress elevator. An exception exists for an interior area of refuge at the level of exit discharge that provides direct access to an exterior exit door. These are not required to be located adjacent to a stair or accessible means of egress elevator.

diagrams.title: Stair Enclosures at Exterior Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairway enclousure walls are intended to provide a specific hourly fire resistance from a fire occurring within the same building. Therefore they are required for adjoining interior walls, but not necessarily exterior walls. However, if the walls are near to a property line fire-separation distance datum line, then the building itself, which includes the stairway, must still be protected from outside hazards as an exterior wall of a building would. Keep in mind that stairways also have an occupancy group, and that occupancy group is required to determine the required exterior wall fire rating.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1023.6 is to ensure that the environment within exit stairways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Stairway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The stairway ventilation system(s) must be completely separated from the buildings ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with section 716.

diagrams.title: High Rise: Additional Stairway
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a building (other than Group R-2 occupancy type) exceeds 420' in height, an additional stairwell is required. This is in addition to the minimum egress requirements of Section 1006.3. If the building is equipped with an occupant evacuation elevator, then this additional stairwell is not required. Where other parts of the building have a maximum occupiable height of less than 420', that section of the building is not required to have the extra stairwell.

diagrams.title: Accessible Means of Egress: Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A means of egress is an unobstructed path to leave buildings, structures, and spaces. A means of egress is comprised of exit access, exit, and exit discharge. An accessible means of egress, as defined by the code, is a "continuous and unobstructed way of egress travel from any point in a building or facility that provides an accessible route to an area of refuge, a horizontal exit, or a public way." Where more than one means of egress is required from any accessible space, each accessible portion of the space must be served by at least two accessible means of egress. Accessible spaces can be served by one accessible means of egress only where the code permits one means of egress.

diagrams.title: Exit Access, Exit and Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines exit, exit access and exit discharge as the following:

Exit Access: That portion of a means of egress system that leads from any occupied portion of a building or structure to an exit.

Exit: That portion of a means of egress system between the exit access and the exit discharge or public way. Exit components include exterior exit doors at the level of exit discharge, interior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, exterior exit stairways and ramps and horizontal exits.

Exit Discharge: That portion of a means of egress system between the termination of an exit and a public way.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairway Termination
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior stairways are considered to be an "Exit" component of the means of egress system. The next required component is either an exit discharge. Exit discharges can include egress courts and any portion of the means of egress system between the termination of an exit and the public way. Section 1028 provides conditions where the means of egress may go through a building element to the exit discharge. But generally, interior exit stairs must exit directly to the outside of the building.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stair w/ Exit Passageway: Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an interior exit stairway or ramp cannot provide direct access to an exit discharge or public way, the code permits the use of an exit passageway to extend the interior exit stairway or ramp to facilitate such access. Exit passageways' enclosures, which encompass walls, floors, and ceilings, are mandated to be constructed as fire-barriers. They must possess a fire-resistance of either 1-hour or the fire-resistance requisite for any connected interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure, opting for whichever specification is greater. For reference, a typical exit stairway enclosure has a 2-hour fire-resistance rating.

The interior exit stairway or ramp must be separated from the exit passageway by a fire barrier, which should carry a fire-resistance rating not less than that of the interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure. In order to access the exit passageway from the exit stairway or ramp, a fire door, compliant with Section 716, must be incorporated into the fire barrier, which establishes separation between the exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway. Any openings and penetrations in the fire barrier that segregates the exit stairway or ramp from the passageway—apart from the fire door intended to provide exit from the stairway or ramp—are prohibited.

However, the code does provide allowance for incidental penetrations of the fire barrier, required for construction and life safety elements related to ventilation, fire protection, security, and communications systems, in addition to electrical raceways serving fire communications and the exit stairway or ramp, and for structural elements sustaining the stairway or ramp. All penetrations must be safeguarded in accordance with Section 714.

Moreover, the fire barrier and fire door, positioned between the exit passageway and the exit stairway or ramp, may be omitted under specific circumstances: where there are no openings into the exit passageway or where the interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway are pressurized in line with Section 909.20.5.

diagrams.title: Roof Assemblies at Interior Exit Stairs (2024)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Roofs adjacent to interior exit stairways that extend above the roof are require to be a 1 hour fire-resistance rated assembly where the roof is within 10' of the stairway wall. Openings with the area of roof that is required to be a 1 hour rated assembly are required to have opening 3/4 hour rated opening protectives. Where the stairway exterior walls adjacent to the roof are 1 hour fire-resistance rated with 3/4 hour opening protectives the adjacent roof assembly does not have to be fire rated or have opening protectives.

children.displayTitle: Section 1023 Interior Exit Stairways and Ramps

children.body: Interior exit stairways and ramps serving as an exit component in a means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of this section. Interior exit stairways and ramps shall be enclosed and lead directly to the exterior of the building or shall be extended to the exterior of the building with an exit passageway conforming to the requirements of Section 1024, except as permitted in Section 1028.2. An interior exit stairway or ramp shall not be used for any purpose other than as a means of egress and a circulation path.

Enclosures for interior exit stairways and ramps shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both. Interior exit stairway and ramp enclosures shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 2 hours where connecting four stories or more and not less than 1 hour where connecting less than four stories. The number of stories connected by the interior exit stairways or ramps shall include any basements, but not any mezzanines. Enclosures for interior exit stairways and ramps shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than the floor assembly penetrated, but need not exceed 2 hours.
Exceptions:
  1. Interior exit stairways and ramps in Group I-3 occupancies in accordance with the provisions of Section 408.3.8.
  2. Interior exit stairways within an atrium enclosed in accordance with Section 404.6.
  3. Interior exit stairways in accordance with Section 510.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated wall assemblies are of three varieties: fire walls, fire barriers and fire partitions. Fire barriers can be used as shaft enclosures, occupancy separations and others. Fire partitions are often used as demising walls and corridor separations, among other uses.

diagrams.title: Exit Separation at Scissor Stairs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit Separation at Scissor Stairs: If scissor stairs (not shown here), are connected by a 1-hour fire resistance rated corridor per 1020, exit separation distance may be measured along the corridor. In order to use this measurement method, the corridor must meet the rating requirement, even if Table 1020.1 does not require a rating for the occupancy. The interconnected scissor stairs must also be fully separated per 1023.2.

diagrams.title: Separation of Exit and Exit Access Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Minimum separation of exits provides for the safe exit from a space, floor or building if one exit becomes blocked. Note that the separation distance applies to any part of the width of the doorway per 1007.1.1.1.

If scissor stairs (not shown here), are connected by a 1-hour fire resistance rated corridor per 1020, exit separation distance may be measured along the corridor. In order to use this measurement method, the corridor must meet the rating requirement, even if Table 1020.1 does not require a rating for the occupancy. The interconnected scissor stairs must also be fully separated per 1023.2.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Sprinklered, 75-120 ft) - 2024
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
