    Corridors which connect an elevator lobby to an exit are not required to be fire rated (§1016.2(1))
  12. (Reserved)
  13. (Reserved)
  14. (Reserved)
  15. (Reserved)
  16. (Reserved)
  17. An enclosed elevator lobby requires (nonrated) smoke partitions. (§3006.3(2))
  18. Enclosed elevator lobby doors must be self-closing "S" (smoke) label doors. (§3006.3(2) + §710.5.2.2 and §710.5.2.3)
  19. Elevator shafts require 2-hour fire barriers. (§713.4)
  20. Elevator shafts require 90-minute (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2)) automatic-closing (§716.2.6.6) fire doors. An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), provided the mitigation described in Note 9 is provided. (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2) and §716.2.6.6)
  21. Enclosed exit stairways require 2-hour fire barriers. (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways require 90-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) label. (§707.6 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)

diagrams.title: Separation of Exit and Exit Access Doors (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Minimum separation of exits provides for the safe exit from a space, floor or building if one exit becomes blocked. Note that the separation distance applies to the nearest edges of the width of the doorway per Section 7.5.1.3.2, whereas the building code allows measurement to any point along the doorway.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Nonsprinklered, 0-75 ft) - 2024
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited except for rooms with an electrically locked exit access door providing egress from an elevator lobby shall be permitted in accordance with Section 1010.2.14 (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. In other than group H occupancies, egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2)). In group H occupancies, egress through adjoining or intervening room or areas of the same or lesser hazard occupancy group with a discernible path of egress travel to an exit is allowed.
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7)
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1)
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby, is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), 1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed elevator lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless (a)the shaft is pressurized, or (b)smoke-stop doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors) (§716.2.2.1.1). This applies for all rated corridors, even if smoke protection for the elevator shaft is not required per §3006.2. (Table 1020.2 + Table 716.1(2) + 716.2.2.1) (If the elevator connects 4 or more floors, the enclosed elevator lobby is also required per §3006.2, except at the level of exit discharge.)
  10. At least one exit without passing through the enclosed elevator lobby.(§1016.2(1)
  11. Corridors require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2)
  12. Corridors require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke)rating (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).
  13. Unenclosed exit access stairs or ramps serving a rated corridor require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.7 + §1020.2)
  14. Unenclosed exit access stairs or ramps serving a rated corridor require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (1020.7 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1).
  15. Foyers, lobbies, or reception rooms serving a rated corridor require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.7 Exception 1 + §1020.2)
  16. Foyers, lobbies, or reception rooms serving a rated corridor require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (§1020.7 Exception 1 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1).
  17. Any enclosed elevator lobby bisecting a rated corridor requires 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2).
  18. Corridor doors at an enclosed elevator lobby must be 20-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).
  19. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Shafts connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§713.4). In Type I construction, 2-hour fire barriers are required in all cases (§713.4 + Table 601).
  20. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute automatic-closing smoke-activated fire doors. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §713.7 + §716.2.6.6). An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), but the mitigation described in Note 9 is mandatory
  21. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Stair enclosures connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1)

children.body:
Interior exit stairways and ramps shall terminate at an exit discharge or a public way.
Exception: A combination of interior exit stairways, interior exit ramps and exit passageways, constructed in accordance with Sections 1023.2, 1023.3.1 and 1024, respectively, and forming a continuous protected enclosure, shall be permitted to extend an interior exit stairway or ramp to the exit discharge or a public way.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairway Termination
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior stairways are considered to be an "Exit" component of the means of egress system. The next required component is either an exit discharge. Exit discharges can include egress courts and any portion of the means of egress system between the termination of an exit and the public way. Section 1028 provides conditions where the means of egress may go through a building element to the exit discharge. But generally, interior exit stairs must exit directly to the outside of the building.

children.body:
Where interior exit stairways and ramps are extended to an exit discharge or a public way by an exit passageway, the interior exit stairway and ramp shall be separated from the exit passageway by a fire barrier constructed in accordance with Section 707 or a horizontal assembly constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both. The fire-resistance rating shall be not less than that required for the interior exit stairway and ramp. A fire door assembly complying with Section 716 shall be installed in the fire barrier to provide a means of egress from the interior exit stairway and ramp to the exit passageway. Openings in the fire barrier other than the fire door assembly are prohibited. Penetrations of the fire barrier are prohibited.
Exceptions:
  1. Penetrations of the fire barrier in accordance with Section 1023.5 shall be permitted.
  2. Separation between an interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway extension shall not be required where there are no openings into the exit passageway extension.
  3. Separation between an interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway extension shall not be required where the interior exit stairway and the exit passageway extension are pressurized in accordance with Section 909.20.4.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stair w/ Exit Passageway: Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an interior exit stairway or ramp cannot provide direct access to an exit discharge or public way, the code permits the use of an exit passageway to extend the interior exit stairway or ramp to facilitate such access. Exit passageways' enclosures, which encompass walls, floors, and ceilings, are mandated to be constructed as fire-barriers. They must possess a fire-resistance of either 1-hour or the fire-resistance requisite for any connected interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure, opting for whichever specification is greater. For reference, a typical exit stairway enclosure has a 2-hour fire-resistance rating.

The interior exit stairway or ramp must be separated from the exit passageway by a fire barrier, which should carry a fire-resistance rating not less than that of the interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure. In order to access the exit passageway from the exit stairway or ramp, a fire door, compliant with Section 716, must be incorporated into the fire barrier, which establishes separation between the exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway. Any openings and penetrations in the fire barrier that segregates the exit stairway or ramp from the passageway—apart from the fire door intended to provide exit from the stairway or ramp—are prohibited.

However, the code does provide allowance for incidental penetrations of the fire barrier, required for construction and life safety elements related to ventilation, fire protection, security, and communications systems, in addition to electrical raceways serving fire communications and the exit stairway or ramp, and for structural elements sustaining the stairway or ramp. All penetrations must be safeguarded in accordance with Section 714.

Moreover, the fire barrier and fire door, positioned between the exit passageway and the exit stairway or ramp, may be omitted under specific circumstances: where there are no openings into the exit passageway or where the interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway are pressurized in line with Section 909.20.5.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Termination; Openings (BC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
An exit passageway is an integral part of a building's means of egress system. It plays a crucial role in providing a continuous and unobstructed way of travel from any point in a building or structure to a public way. The means of egress is composed of three distinct parts: the exit access, the exit, and the exit discharge.
Exit passageways on the level of exit discharge should terminate at an exit discharge. Those on other levels should terminate at an exit.
Penetrations into or through an exit passageway are mainly prohibited except for essential systems such as equipment and ductwork necessary for independent ventilation or pressurization, fire protection systems, security systems, and two-way communication systems. Openings in exit passageways other than unprotected exterior openings must be limited to those necessary for exit access to the exit passageway from normally occupied spaces and for egress from the exit passageway. Elevators are not allowed to open into an exit passageway.

children.body:
Interior exit stairway and ramp opening protectives shall be in accordance with the requirements of Section 716.
Openings in interior exit stairways and ramps other than unprotected exterior openings shall be limited to those required for exit access to the enclosure from normally occupied spaces and for egress from the enclosure.
Elevators shall not open into interior exit stairways and ramps.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1023.4 defines the type of wall openings that may be placed in interior exit stair walls. The only openings allowed in interior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures are exit doors that provide access to the stairway enclosure from normally occupied spaces and for exiting from the enclosure. Since interior exit stairways need to be separated from the rest of the building by vertical fire barriers (707) or a rated horizontal assembly (711), section 1023.4 also requires any openings in the interior walls to be protected in accordance with section 716. The actual level of opening protection required is established by table 716.1(2) which defines the rating/level of protection of any openings between an interior space and the exit stairway. 1023.4 further clarifies that elevators may not open into interior exit stairway enclosures.

children.body:
Penetrations into or through interior exit stairways and ramps are prohibited except for the following:
  1. Equipment and ductwork necessary for independent ventilation or pressurization.
  2. Fire protection systems.
  3. Security systems.
  4. Two-way communication systems.
  5. Electrical raceway for fire department communication systems.
  6. Electrical raceway serving the interior exit stairway and ramp and terminating at a steel box not exceeding 16 square inches (0.010 m2).
  7. Structural elements, such as beams or joists, supporting the interior exit stairway or ramp or enclosure.
  8. Structural elements, such as beams or joists, supporting a roof at the top of the interior exit stairway or ramp.
Such penetrations shall be protected in accordance with Section 714. There shall not be penetrations or communication openings, whether protected or not, between adjacent interior exit stairways and ramps.
Exception: Membrane penetrations shall be permitted on the outside of the interior exit stairway and ramp. Such penetrations shall be protected in accordance with Section 714.4.2.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The enclosures for exit stairways and ramps are to protect occupants from fire and products of combustion like poisonous gas and smoke. As such, the code prohibits any penetrations that could compromise the safety of the enclosure to items specifically required by the exit stairway and ramp or its protection by emergency services by specifically defining what may penetrate the enclosure and lists seven types of allowed penetrations. To further ensure the enclosure remains safe the code goes on to prohibit penetrations and communication openings between adjacent fire exit stairway and ramps. Single membrane penetrations of the exit stairway and ramp enclosures is only permitted to happen on the outside face of the enclosure and must be in accordance with section 714.4.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Through Penetrations - Exceptions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: THROUGH-PENETRATION FIRESTOP SYSTEM.An assemblage consisting of a fire-resistance-rated floor, floor-ceiling, or wall assembly, one or more penetrating items passing through the breaches in both sides of the assembly and the materials or devices, or both, installed to resist the spread of fire through the assembly for a prescribed period of time.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Membrane Penetration Exception 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Membrane-Penetration Firestop:A material, device or construction installed to resist for a prescribed time period the passage of flame and heat through openings in a protective membrane in order to accommodate cables, cable trays, conduit, tubing, pipes or similar items.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1023.6 is to ensure that the environment within exit stairways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Stairway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The stairway ventilation system(s) must be completely separated from the buildings ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with section 716.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stair w/ Exit Passageway: Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an interior exit stairway or ramp cannot provide direct access to an exit discharge or public way, the code permits the use of an exit passageway to extend the interior exit stairway or ramp to facilitate such access. Exit passageways' enclosures, which encompass walls, floors, and ceilings, are mandated to be constructed as fire-barriers. They must possess a fire-resistance of either 1-hour or the fire-resistance requisite for any connected interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure, opting for whichever specification is greater. For reference, a typical exit stairway enclosure has a 2-hour fire-resistance rating.

The interior exit stairway or ramp must be separated from the exit passageway by a fire barrier, which should carry a fire-resistance rating not less than that of the interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure. In order to access the exit passageway from the exit stairway or ramp, a fire door, compliant with Section 716, must be incorporated into the fire barrier, which establishes separation between the exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway. Any openings and penetrations in the fire barrier that segregates the exit stairway or ramp from the passageway—apart from the fire door intended to provide exit from the stairway or ramp—are prohibited.

However, the code does provide allowance for incidental penetrations of the fire barrier, required for construction and life safety elements related to ventilation, fire protection, security, and communications systems, in addition to electrical raceways serving fire communications and the exit stairway or ramp, and for structural elements sustaining the stairway or ramp. All penetrations must be safeguarded in accordance with Section 714.

Moreover, the fire barrier and fire door, positioned between the exit passageway and the exit stairway or ramp, may be omitted under specific circumstances: where there are no openings into the exit passageway or where the interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway are pressurized in line with Section 909.20.5.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Membrane Penetrations: Electrical Boxes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Membrane-Penetration Firestop:A material, device or construction installed to resist for a prescribed time period the passage of flame and heat through openings in a protective membrane in order to accommodate cables, cable trays, conduit, tubing, pipes or similar items.

children.body:
Equipment and ductwork for interior exit stairway and ramp ventilation as permitted by Section 1023.5 shall comply with one of the following items:
  1. Such equipment and ductwork shall be located exterior to the building and shall be directly connected to the interior exit stairway and ramp by ductwork enclosed in construction as required for shafts.
  2. Where such equipment and ductwork is located within the interior exit stairway and ramp, the intake air shall be taken directly from the outdoors and the exhaust air shall be discharged directly to the outdoors, or such air shall be conveyed through ducts enclosed in construction as required for shafts.
  3. Where located within the building, such equipment and ductwork shall be separated from the remainder of the building, including other mechanical equipment, with construction as required for shafts.
In each case, openings into the fire-resistance-rated construction shall be limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and shall be protected by opening protectives in accordance with Section 716 for shaft enclosures.
The interior exit stairway and ramp ventilation systems shall be independent of other building ventilation systems.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1023.6 is to ensure that the environment within exit stairways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Stairway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The stairway ventilation system(s) must be completely separated from the buildings ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with section 716.

diagrams.title: Air Intake Opening Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Air intake openings provide a way for outdoor air to enter a building and supply fresh air to its occupants. The ventilation can occur from either natural or mechanical ventilation.
When the intake air or exhaust system is not properly designed, contaminated air has the possibility of entering the building which would reduce the indoor air quality and potentially cause unwanted odors or even potential health issues for the buildings occupants.

children.body: Exterior walls of the interior exit stairway or ramp shall comply with the requirements of Section 705 for exterior walls. Where nonrated walls or unprotected openings enclose the exterior of the stairway or ramps and the walls or openings are exposed by other parts of the building at an angle of less than 180 degrees (3.14 rad), building construction within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the exterior walls of the interior exit stairway or ramp shall comply with Sections 1023.7.1 and 1023.7.2.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair & Ramp Exterior Wall Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The exterior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures only need to meet the typical exterior wall requirements for the building based on its fire separation distance as defined in section 705. Where the exit stairway exterior wall is non-rated or has unprotected openings and the angle between the adjacent wall and the exterior wall of the exit stairway is less than 180 degrees, the first 10' of the immediately adjacent wall is required to have a fire-resistance rating of 1 hour or more and 3/4 hour opening protection. The fire-rated wall and opening protection needs to be provided vertically from the ground up to 10' above the top floor landing or the roof line, whichever is lower. If the exterior wall of the exit stairway is rated and its openings are protected the wall immediately adjacent to the exit stairway may be constructed based on the fire separation distance per section 705.

diagrams.title: Roof Assemblies at Interior Exit Stairs (2024)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Roofs adjacent to interior exit stairways that extend above the roof are require to be a 1 hour fire-resistance rated assembly where the roof is within 10' of the stairway wall. Openings with the area of roof that is required to be a 1 hour rated assembly are required to have opening 3/4 hour rated opening protectives. Where the stairway exterior walls adjacent to the roof are 1 hour fire-resistance rated with 3/4 hour opening protectives the adjacent roof assembly does not have to be fire rated or have opening protectives.

children.displayTitle: 1023.7 Interior Exit Stairway and Ramp Exterior Walls
children.titleText: Interior Exit Stairway and Ramp Exterior Walls

children.body: Building exterior walls within 10 feet (3048 mm) horizontally of a nonrated wall or unprotected opening in an interior exit stairway or ramp shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour. This construction shall extend vertically from the ground to a point 10 feet (3048 mm) above the topmost landing of the stairway or ramp, or to the roof line, whichever is lower.

Where the interior exit stairway or ramp extends above an adjacent roof of the same building, the adjacent roof assembly shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour and openings shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.  The fire-resistance rating and opening protection shall extend horizontally not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from the exterior wall of the stairway or ramp, or to the perimeter of the adjacent roof, whichever is less.
Exceptions:
  1. The roof assembly need not be rated and openings in the roof need not be protected where they are adjacent to the penthouse of the stairway or ramp, unless otherwise required by this code.
  2. The adjacent roof assembly need not be rated and adjacent openings in the roof need not be protected where the exterior wall of the stairway or ramp has a fire-resistance rating of 1 hour and openings are protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour, extending not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) above the roof.

diagrams.title: Roof Assemblies at Interior Exit Stairs (2024)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Roofs adjacent to interior exit stairways that extend above the roof are require to be a 1 hour fire-resistance rated assembly where the roof is within 10' of the stairway wall. Openings with the area of roof that is required to be a 1 hour rated assembly are required to have opening 3/4 hour rated opening protectives. Where the stairway exterior walls adjacent to the roof are 1 hour fire-resistance rated with 3/4 hour opening protectives the adjacent roof assembly does not have to be fire rated or have opening protectives.

children.body: An interior exit stairway and ramp shall not continue below its level of exit discharge unless an approved barrier is provided at the level of exit discharge to prevent persons from unintentionally continuing into levels below. Directional exit signs shall be provided as specified in Section 1013.

diagrams.title: Stairway Discharge Identification
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit Stairways require signage to indicate the exit discharge, as well as barriers such as gates to prevent those exiting from continuing down into areas below the level of exit discharge.

children.displayTitle: 1023.8 Barrier at Level of Exit Discharge
children.titleText: Barrier at Level of Exit Discharge

children.body: A sign shall be provided at each floor landing in an interior exit stairway and ramp connecting more than three stories designating the floor level, the terminus of the top and bottom of the interior exit stairway and ramp and the identification of the stairway or ramp. The signage shall state the story of and direction to the exit discharge, and the availability of roof access from the interior exit stairway and ramp for the fire department. The bottom of the sign shall be located not less than 5 feet (1524 mm) above the floor landing in a position that is readily visible when the doors are in the open and closed positions.

Stairway identification signs shall comply with all of the following requirements:
  1. The signs shall be a minimum size of 18 inches (457 mm) by 12 inches (305 mm).
  2. The letters designating the identification of the interior exit stairway and ramp shall be not less than 11/2 inches (38 mm) in height.
  3. The number designating the floor level shall be not less than 5 inches (127 mm) in height and located in the center of the sign.
  4. Other lettering and numbers shall be not less than 1 inch (25 mm) in height.
  5. Characters and their background shall have a nonglare finish. Characters shall contrast with their background, with either light characters on a dark background or dark characters on a light background.
  6. Where signs required by Section 1023.9 are installed in the interior exit stairways and ramps of buildings subject to Section 1025, the signs shall be made of the same materials as required by Section 1025.4.

At landings in interior exit stairways where two or more doors lead to the floor level, any door with direct access to an enclosed elevator lobby shall be identified by signage located on the door or directly adjacent to the door stating "Elevator Lobby." Signage shall be in accordance with Section 1023.9.1, Items 4, 5 and 6.

Where floor level signs are provided in interior exit stairways and ramps, a floor-level sign identifying the floor level in visual characters, raised characters and braille complying with  ICC A117.1 shall be located at each floor-level landing adjacent to the door leading from the interior exit stairway and ramp into the corridor.
Where required by Section 403.5.4, 405.7.2 or 412.2.2.1, interior exit stairways and ramps shall be smokeproof enclosures in accordance with Section 909.20.

diagrams.title: High Rise Smokeproof Encl: No Vestibule
High Rise Smokeproof Encl: Natural Ventilation

children.body:
A smokeproof enclosure shall terminate at an exit discharge or a public way. The smokeproof enclosure shall be permitted to be extended by an exit passageway in accordance with Section 1023.3. The exit passageway shall be without openings other than the fire door assembly required by Section 1023.3.1 and those necessary for egress from the exit passageway. The exit passageway shall be separated from the remainder of the building by 2-hour fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both.
Exceptions:
  1. Openings in the exit passageway serving a smokeproof enclosure are permitted where the exit passageway is protected and pressurized in the same manner as the smokeproof enclosure, and openings are protected as required for access from other floors.
  2. The fire barrier separating the smokeproof enclosure from the exit passageway is not required, provided that the exit passageway is protected and pressurized in the same manner as the smokeproof enclosure.
  3. A smokeproof enclosure shall be permitted to egress through areas on the level of exit discharge or vestibules as permitted by Section 1028.

Access to the stairway or ramp within a smokeproof enclosure shall be by way of a vestibule or an open exterior balcony.
Exception: Access is not required by way of a vestibule or exterior balcony for stairways and ramps using the pressurization alternative complying with Section 909.20.4.
Standpipes and standpipe hose connections shall be provided where required by Sections 905.3 and 905.4.

diagrams.title: Standpipe Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Standpipes, Types: - There are five types of standpipes - automatic dry, automatic wet, manual dry, manual wet, and semiautomatic dry. Automatic dry systems are pressurized with air, when a hose valve is opened, the air is released and the system fills with water. Automatic wet systems are filled with water at all times. Manual dry systems are not connected to a water supply, and must be supplied with water from the fire department. This is done via a fire department connection (FDC). Manual wet systems are filled with water, but require a supplemental fire department connection to meet required demand. Semiautomatic dry systems do not have water in them, but when a hose valve is opened, a remote switch opens the valve and allows water to fill the system.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Construction (IBC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit passageways are to provide a safe way to exit a building from an interior exit stairway or ramp, to protect occupants the enclosure must provide fire protection. The fire rating of the exit passageways walls, floors, and ceilings shall be not less than 1 hour or the rating of the exit stairway or ramp enclosure, which ever is greater. Exit passageway walls are required to be constructed as fire-barriers in accordance with section 707. Exit passageway floors and ceilings, horizontal assemblies, are required to be constructed in accordance with section 711.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Exterior Walls (IBC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At a minimum, the exterior wall of an exit passageway must comply with section 705, which defines how exterior walls may be constructed in relation to the design fire separation distance. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is fire rated and openings within the wall are protected no additional measures are required on the exterior walls within 10' of the passageway beyond what section 705 calls for. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is nonrated and openings within the wall are unprotected no additional measures are required on the exterior of the building provided the exit passageway exterior wall aligns with or is proud of (in front of) all adjacent exterior walls within 10' horizontally of the exit passageway exterior wall. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is nonrated or has unprotected opening and an adjacent exterior wall meets the passageway wall at an angle of less than 180 degrees, such that the adjacent wall within 10' of the passageway wall is proud of the passageway wall, the adjacent wall shall be 1 hour fire-resistance rated within 10' of the passageway and openings within the same 10' of the adjacent wall shall have a 3/4 hour fire-protection rating. The fire-resistant construction and opening protections where required within 10' of the passageway must extend from the ground to 10' above the passageway floor or the roof line, whichever is lower.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Termination; Openings (BC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
An exit passageway is an integral part of a building's means of egress system. It plays a crucial role in providing a continuous and unobstructed way of travel from any point in a building or structure to a public way. The means of egress is composed of three distinct parts: the exit access, the exit, and the exit discharge.
Exit passageways on the level of exit discharge should terminate at an exit discharge. Those on other levels should terminate at an exit.
Penetrations into or through an exit passageway are mainly prohibited except for essential systems such as equipment and ductwork necessary for independent ventilation or pressurization, fire protection systems, security systems, and two-way communication systems. Openings in exit passageways other than unprotected exterior openings must be limited to those necessary for exit access to the exit passageway from normally occupied spaces and for egress from the exit passageway. Elevators are not allowed to open into an exit passageway.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Width and Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The width of an exit passageway should be sized to accommodate the required capacity of all exits, however the minimum width shall not be less than 44 inches. Exit passageways that serve an occupant load of less than 50 shall not be less than 36 inches in width.

diagrams.title: Separation of a Third Stairway
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Separation of a third or more stairways from others are addressed simply by the statement that they "shall be arranged a reasonable distance apart so that if one becomes blocked, the others will be available.". However, in practice this may not be so easy. The shape of the building or lot might require the exit system from a third stairway to double back or be in close proximity to the second stairway. Alternately, local officials may determine that the design does not provide a reasonable distance apart, and may force a redesign of the building or an alternate means application might be required to provide compliance. In conditions where the placement of the third stair is in doubt, it's always a best practice to check with the building official and/or fire marshal to verify the placement of such stairs would be acceptable to the jurisdiction.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Prohibited Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The enclosures for exit passageways are to protect occupants from fire and products of combustion like poisonous gas and smoke. As such, the code prohibits any penetrations that could compromise the safety of the enclosure to items specifically required by the exit passageway or its protection by emergency services by specifically defining what may penetrate the enclosure and lists six types of allowed penetrations. To further ensure the enclosure remains safe the code goes on to prohibit penetrations and communication openings between adjacent exit passageways. Single membrane penetrations of the exit stairway and ramp enclosures is only permitted to happen on the outside face of the enclosure and must be in accordance with section 714.4.2.

children.body: Exit passageways serving as an exit component in a means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of this section. An exit passageway shall not be used for any purpose other than as a means of egress and a circulation path.

The required capacity of exit passageways shall be determined as specified in Section 1005.1 but the minimum width shall be not less than 44 inches (1118 mm), except that exit passageways serving an occupant load of less than 50 shall be not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in width. The minimum width or required capacity of exit passageways shall be unobstructed.
Exception: Encroachments complying with Section 1005.7.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Width and Capacity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The width of an exit passageway should be sized to accommodate the required capacity of all exits, however the minimum width shall not be less than 44 inches. Exit passageways that serve an occupant load of less than 50 shall not be less than 36 inches in width.

children.body: Exit passageway enclosures shall have walls, floors and ceilings of not less than a 1-hour fire-resistance rating, and not less than that required for any connecting interior exit stairway or ramp. Exit passageways shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Construction (IBC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit passageways are to provide a safe way to exit a building from an interior exit stairway or ramp, to protect occupants the enclosure must provide fire protection. The fire rating of the exit passageways walls, floors, and ceilings shall be not less than 1 hour or the rating of the exit stairway or ramp enclosure, which ever is greater. Exit passageway walls are required to be constructed as fire-barriers in accordance with section 707. Exit passageway floors and ceilings, horizontal assemblies, are required to be constructed in accordance with section 711.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions

children.body:
Exit passageway opening protectives shall be in accordance with the requirements of Section 716.
Except as permitted in Section 402.8.7, openings in exit passageways other than unprotected exterior openings shall be limited to those necessary for exit access to the exit passageway from normally occupied spaces and for egress from the exit passageway.
Where an interior exit stairway or ramp is extended to an exit discharge or a public way by an exit passageway, the exit passageway shall comply with Section 1023.3.1.

children.body:
Penetrations into or through an exit passageway are prohibited except for the following:
  1. Equipment and ductwork necessary for independent ventilation or pressurization.
  2. Fire protection systems.
  3. Security systems.
  4. Two-way communication systems.
  5. Electrical raceway for fire department communication.
  6. Electrical raceway serving the exit passageway and terminating at a steel box not exceeding 16 square inches (0.010 m2).
  7. Structural elements, such as beams or joists, supporting a floor or roof at the top of the exit passageway.
Such penetrations shall be protected in accordance with Section 714. There shall not be penetrations or communicating openings, whether protected or not, between adjacent exit passageways.
Exception: Membrane penetrations shall be permitted on the outside of the exit passageway. Such penetrations shall be protected in accordance with Section 714.4.2.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Prohibited Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The enclosures for exit passageways are to protect occupants from fire and products of combustion like poisonous gas and smoke. As such, the code prohibits any penetrations that could compromise the safety of the enclosure to items specifically required by the exit passageway or its protection by emergency services by specifically defining what may penetrate the enclosure and lists six types of allowed penetrations. To further ensure the enclosure remains safe the code goes on to prohibit penetrations and communication openings between adjacent exit passageways. Single membrane penetrations of the exit stairway and ramp enclosures is only permitted to happen on the outside face of the enclosure and must be in accordance with section 714.4.2.

children.body:
Equipment and ductwork for exit passageway ventilation as permitted by Section 1024.6 shall comply with one of the following:
  1. The equipment and ductwork shall be located exterior to the building and shall be directly connected to the exit passageway by ductwork enclosed in construction as required for shafts.
  2. Where the equipment and ductwork is located within the exit passageway, the intake air shall be taken directly from the outdoors and the exhaust air shall be discharged directly to the outdoors, or the air shall be conveyed through ducts enclosed in construction as required for shafts.
  3. Where located within the building, the equipment and ductwork shall be separated from the remainder of the building, including other mechanical equipment, with construction as required for shafts.
In each case, openings into the fire-resistance-rated construction shall be limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and shall be protected by opening protectives in accordance with Section 716 for shaft enclosures.
Exit passageway ventilation systems shall be independent of other building ventilation systems.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Air Intake Opening Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Air intake openings provide a way for outdoor air to enter a building and supply fresh air to its occupants. The ventilation can occur from either natural or mechanical ventilation.
When the intake air or exhaust system is not properly designed, contaminated air has the possibility of entering the building which would reduce the indoor air quality and potentially cause unwanted odors or even potential health issues for the buildings occupants.

children.body: Exterior walls of the exit passageway shall comply with Section 705. Where nonrated walls or unprotected openings enclose the exterior of the exit passageway and the walls or openings are exposed by other parts of the building at an angle of less than 180 degrees (3.14 rad), the building exterior walls within 10 feet (3048 mm) horizontally of a nonrated wall or unprotected opening shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour. This construction shall extend vertically from the ground to a point 10 feet (3048 mm) above the floor of the exit passageway, or to the roof line, whichever is lower.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Exterior Walls (IBC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At a minimum, the exterior wall of an exit passageway must comply with section 705, which defines how exterior walls may be constructed in relation to the design fire separation distance. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is fire rated and openings within the wall are protected no additional measures are required on the exterior walls within 10' of the passageway beyond what section 705 calls for. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is nonrated and openings within the wall are unprotected no additional measures are required on the exterior of the building provided the exit passageway exterior wall aligns with or is proud of (in front of) all adjacent exterior walls within 10' horizontally of the exit passageway exterior wall. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is nonrated or has unprotected opening and an adjacent exterior wall meets the passageway wall at an angle of less than 180 degrees, such that the adjacent wall within 10' of the passageway wall is proud of the passageway wall, the adjacent wall shall be 1 hour fire-resistance rated within 10' of the passageway and openings within the same 10' of the adjacent wall shall have a 3/4 hour fire-protection rating. The fire-resistant construction and opening protections where required within 10' of the passageway must extend from the ground to 10' above the passageway floor or the roof line, whichever is lower.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
An exit passageway is an integral part of a building's means of egress system. It plays a crucial role in providing a continuous and unobstructed way of travel from any point in a building or structure to a public way. Openings in exit passageways other than unprotected exterior openings must be limited to those necessary for exit access to the exit passageway from normally occupied spaces and for egress from the exit passageway. Elevators are not allowed to open into an exit passageway.

children.body: Standpipes and standpipe hose connections shall be provided where required by Sections 905.3 and 905.4.

diagrams.title: Standpipe Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Standpipes, Types: - There are five types of standpipes - automatic dry, automatic wet, manual dry, manual wet, and semiautomatic dry. Automatic dry systems are pressurized with air, when a hose valve is opened, the air is released and the system fills with water. Automatic wet systems are filled with water at all times. Manual dry systems are not connected to a water supply, and must be supplied with water from the fire department. This is done via a fire department connection (FDC). Manual wet systems are filled with water, but require a supplemental fire department connection to meet required demand. Semiautomatic dry systems do not have water in them, but when a hose valve is opened, a remote switch opens the valve and allows water to fill the system.

diagrams.title: Luminous Egress Paths
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a high-rise houses a Group A, B, E, I-1, M, or R-1 occupancy type, the exit paths and stairways must be marked with a luminous striping. The luminous striping can be made of any material including paint, but must not require any electricity for illumination. These markings must be at least 1" and not exceed 2" (may be less than 1" if material and application is UL 1994 listed). These marking are required on each stair, landing, handrails, and around each egress door.

children.body:
Approved luminous egress path markings delineating the exit path shall be provided in high-rise buildings of Group A, B, E, I-1, M or R-1 occupancies in accordance with this section.
Exception: Luminous egress path markings shall not be required on the level of exit discharge in lobbies that serve as part of the exit path in accordance with Section 1028.2, Exception 1.
Egress path markings shall be provided in interior exit stairways, interior exit ramps and exit passageways, in accordance with Sections 1025.2.1 through 1025.2.6.3.

A solid and continuous stripe shall be applied to the horizontal leading edge of each step and shall extend for the full length of the step. Outlining stripes shall have a minimum horizontal width of 1 inch (25 mm) and a maximum width of 2 inches (51 mm). The leading edge of the stripe shall be placed not more than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) from the leading edge of the step and the stripe shall not overlap the leading edge of the step by not more than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) down the vertical face of the step.
Exception: The minimum width of 1 inch (25 mm) shall not apply to outlining stripes listed in accordance with UL 1994.
The leading edge of landings shall be marked with a stripe consistent with the dimensional requirements for steps.

Handrails and handrail extensions shall be marked with a solid and continuous stripe having a minimum width of 1 inch (25 mm). The stripe shall be placed on the top surface of the handrail for the entire length of the handrail, including extensions and newel post caps. Where handrails or handrail extensions bend or turn corners, the stripe shall not have a gap of more than 4 inches (102 mm).
Exception: The minimum width of 1 inch (25 mm) shall not apply to outlining stripes listed in accordance with UL 1994.

Stair landings and other floor areas within interior exit stairways, interior exit ramps and exit passageways, with the exception of the sides of steps, shall be provided with solid and continuous demarcation lines on the floor or on the walls or a combination of both. The stripes shall be 1 to 2 inches (25 mm to 51 mm) wide with interruptions not exceeding 4 inches (102 mm).
Exception: The minimum width of 1 inch (25 mm) shall not apply to outlining stripes listed in accordance with UL 1994.

Perimeter demarcation lines shall be placed within 4 inches (102 mm) of the wall and shall extend to within 2 inches (51 mm) of the markings on the leading edge of landings. The demarcation lines shall continue across the floor in front of all doors.
Exception: Demarcation lines shall not extend in front of exit discharge doors that lead out of an exit and through which occupants must travel to complete the exit path.

Perimeter demarcation lines shall be placed on the wall with the bottom edge of the stripe not more than 4 inches (102 mm) above the finished floor. At the top or bottom of the stairs, demarcation lines shall drop vertically to the floor within 2 inches (51 mm) of the step or landing edge. Demarcation lines on walls shall transition vertically to the floor and then extend across the floor where a line on the floor is the only practical method of outlining the path. Where the wall line is broken by a door, demarcation lines on walls shall continue across the face of the door or transition to the floor and extend across the floor in front of such door.
Exception: Demarcation lines shall not extend in front of exit discharge doors that lead out of an exit and through which occupants must travel to complete the exit path.

Where a wall-mounted demarcation line transitions to a floor-mounted demarcation line, or vice versa, the wall-mounted demarcation line shall drop vertically to the floor to meet a complimentary extension of the floor-mounted demarcation line, thus forming a continuous marking.

Obstacles at or below 6 feet 6 inches (1981 mm) in height and projecting more than 4 inches (102 mm) into the egress path shall be outlined with markings not less than 1 inch (25 mm) in width comprised of a pattern of alternating equal bands, of luminous material and black, with the alternating bands not more than 2 inches (51 mm) thick and angled at 45 degrees (0.79 rad). Obstacles shall include, but are not limited to, standpipes, hose cabinets, wall projections and restricted height areas. However, such markings shall not conceal any required information or indicators including but not limited to instructions to occupants for the use of standpipes.
Exception: The minimum width of 1 inch (25 mm) shall not apply to markings listed in accordance with UL 1994.
Doors through which occupants must pass in order to complete the exit path shall be provided with markings complying with Sections 1025.2.6.1 through 1025.2.6.3.

The doors shall be identified by a low-location luminous emergency exit symbol complying with NFPA 170. The exit symbol shall be not less than 4 inches (102 mm) in height and shall be mounted on the door, centered horizontally, with the top of the symbol not higher than 18 inches (457 mm) above the finished floor.

Door hardware shall be marked with not less than 16 square inches (10 323 mm2) of luminous material. This marking shall be located behind, immediately adjacent to, or on the door handle or escutcheon. Where a panic bar is installed, such material shall be not less than 1 inch (25 mm) wide for the entire length of the actuating bar or touchpad.

diagrams.title: Door Hardware Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code defines acceptable hardware mounting heights for that are a part of the means of egress. Handles, pulls, latches locks other operating devices are required to be from 34" minimum to 48" maximum above the finish floor. Locks used only for security purposes may be at any height provided the lock is not used for normal operation of the door. The code makes an exception for doors and gates that are part of a barrier for pools, spas or hot tubs, which may have the latch release for the self-latching device not more than 54" above the finish floor.

children.body: The top and sides of the door frame shall be marked with a solid and continuous 1-inch- to 2-inch-wide (25 mm to 51 mm) stripe. Where the door molding does not provide sufficient flat surface on which to locate the stripe, the stripe shall be permitted to be located on the wall surrounding the frame.
Placement and dimensions of markings shall be consistent and uniform throughout the same enclosure.

Luminous egress path markings shall be permitted to be made of any material, including paint, provided that an electrical charge is not required to maintain the required luminance. Such materials shall include, but not be limited to, self-luminous materials and photoluminescent materials. Materials shall comply with either of the following standards:
  1. UL 1994.
  2. ASTM E2072, except that the charging source shall be 1 footcandle (11 lux) of fluorescent illumination for 60 minutes, and the minimum luminance shall be 30 milicandelas per square meter at 10 minutes and 5 milicandelas per square meter after 90 minutes.

Where photoluminescent exit path markings are installed, they shall be provided with not less than 1 footcandle (11 lux) of illumination for not less than 60 minutes prior to periods when the building is occupied and continuously during occupancy.

diagrams.title: Standpipes at Horiz. Exits and Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At horizontal exits the code requires a class I connection (FDC/Fire Department Connection) is provided on both sides of the wall regardless of the direction of egress through the horizontal exit opening. Because a horizontal exit cannot be the only exit and the code requires a class I connection at the main floor landing inside of required interior exit stairways there is an exception made for where the stairway FDC would be able to address the same area as the FDC at the horizontal exit. The FDC at the horizontal exit facing a required exit stairway may be omitted when all floor areas between the exits are reachable from the stairway FDC by a 30' hose stream from a 100' hose connected to the stairway FDC.

diagrams.title: Area of Refuge Access to Stairway or Elevator
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Areas of refuge are fire-resistance rated and smoke protected areas where those unable to use stairs can register a call for evacuation assistance and await instructions or assistance. They must provide direct access to an exit stairway (or to an elevator equipped with standby power). Horizontal exits can substitute for areas of refuge.

When areas of refuge are not designed to be directly in the stairway enclosure, the area of refuge must generally be directly adjacent to the stairway, accessible means-of-egress elevator. An exception exists for an interior area of refuge at the level of exit discharge that provides direct access to an exterior exit door. These are not required to be located adjacent to a stair or accessible means of egress elevator.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exits: Refuge Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a horizontal exit is required a refuge area adequate to accommodate its occupant load plus the anticipated occupant load of the adjoining compartment from the horizontal exit must be provided. The refuge area must be occupied by the same tenant or be a public area such as a hallway. The refuge area size must provide at least 3 sf of net floor area for each occupant and anticipated occupants from the horizontal exit. The number of exits required for the refuge area is based only on design occupant loads defined in section 1004 and does not need to include the anticipated occupant load from the adjoining compartment. In some jurisdictions, exceptions for Group I-3 occupancies exist that don't require a direct exit to a stair, presumably for security reasons.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exit Egress Analysis
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When used correctly, in certain situations, use of a horizontal exit can reduce the number of stairways provided while maintaining a consistent level of protection for all occupants. With certain exceptions, horizontal exits are limited to satisfying no more than 50% of the required exits, exit capacity or exit width required from a space under consideration. They may not serve as the only exit from any space. The space to which a horizontal exit leads must be a public area, or occupied by the same tenant and shall serve as a refuge area. The refuge area must be of sufficient size to accommodate the occupants existing in the space and the occupants entering the space assuming 3 s.f. per person for the combined occupant load.

children.body:
Horizontal exits serving as an exit in a means of egress system shall comply with the requirements of this section. A horizontal exit shall not serve as the only exit from a portion of a building, and where two or more exits are required, not more than one-half of the total number of exits or total exit minimum width or required capacity shall be horizontal exits.
Exceptions:
  1. Horizontal exits are permitted to comprise two-thirds of the required exits from any building or floor area for occupancies in Group I-2.
  2. Horizontal exits are permitted to comprise 100 percent of the exits required for occupancies in Group I-3. Not less than 6 square feet (0.6 m2) of accessible space per occupant shall be provided on each side of the horizontal exit for the total number of people in adjoining compartments.

The separation between buildings or refuge areas connected by a horizontal exit shall be provided by a fire wall complying with Section 706; or by a fire barrier complying with Section 707 or a horizontal assembly complying with Section 711, or both. The minimum fire-resistance rating of the separation shall be 2 hours. Opening protectives in horizontal exits shall also comply with Section 716. Duct and air transfer openings in a fire wall or fire barrier that serves as a horizontal exit shall also comply with Section 717. The horizontal exit separation shall extend vertically through all levels of the building unless floor assemblies have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 2 hours and do not have unprotected openings.
Exception: A fire-resistance rating is not required at horizontal exits between a building area and an above-grade pedestrian walkway constructed in accordance with Section 3104, provided that the distance between connected buildings is more than 20 feet (6096 mm).
Horizontal exits constructed as fire barriers shall be continuous from exterior wall to exterior wall so as to divide completely the floor served by the horizontal exit.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Horiz. Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Fire walls have special requirements for horizontal continuity at or beyond the exterior face of the building. If the wall is not extended 18" beyond the face of the exterior wall, then special attention must be given to the interface and construction of the fire wall to extend into the construction of the exterior wall to the backside of the exterior sheathing or finishes. In addition the types of exterior sheathing or finishes determines the requirements for opening protection within four feet each side of the wall. If the angle of the intersecting walls are more than 180 degrees, it becomes more difficult for a fire to "end run" around the end of the fire wall, and requirements on these intersecting walls becomes less.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions

children.body: Fire doors in horizontal exits shall be self-closing or automatic-closing when activated by a smoke detector in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6. Doors, where located in a cross-corridor condition, shall be automatic-closing by activation of a smoke detector installed in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6.

The refuge area of a horizontal exit shall be a space occupied by the same tenant or a public area and each such refuge area shall be adequate to accommodate the original occupant load of the refuge area plus the occupant load anticipated from the adjoining compartment. The anticipated occupant load from the adjoining compartment shall be based on the capacity of the horizontal exit doors entering the refuge area or the total occupant load of the adjoining compartment, whichever is less.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exits: Refuge Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a horizontal exit is required a refuge area adequate to accommodate its occupant load plus the anticipated occupant load of the adjoining compartment from the horizontal exit must be provided. The refuge area must be occupied by the same tenant or be a public area such as a hallway. The refuge area size must provide at least 3 sf of net floor area for each occupant and anticipated occupants from the horizontal exit. The number of exits required for the refuge area is based only on design occupant loads defined in section 1004 and does not need to include the anticipated occupant load from the adjoining compartment. In some jurisdictions, exceptions for Group I-3 occupancies exist that don't require a direct exit to a stair, presumably for security reasons.

children.body: The capacity of the refuge area shall be computed based on a net floor area allowance of 3 square feet (0.2787 m2) for each occupant to be accommodated therein. Where the horizontal exit also forms a smoke compartment, the capacity of the refuge area for Group I-1, I-2 and I-3 occupancies and ambulatory care facilities shall comply with Sections 407.5.3, 408.6.2, 420.6.1 and 422.3.2 as applicable.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exits: Refuge Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a horizontal exit is required a refuge area adequate to accommodate its occupant load plus the anticipated occupant load of the adjoining compartment from the horizontal exit must be provided. The refuge area must be occupied by the same tenant or be a public area such as a hallway. The refuge area size must provide at least 3 sf of net floor area for each occupant and anticipated occupants from the horizontal exit. The number of exits required for the refuge area is based only on design occupant loads defined in section 1004 and does not need to include the anticipated occupant load from the adjoining compartment. In some jurisdictions, exceptions for Group I-3 occupancies exist that don't require a direct exit to a stair, presumably for security reasons.

diagrams.title: Gross vs. Net Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
BUILDING CODE DEFINITION
Floor Area, Gross: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the exterior walls of the building under consideration, exclusive of vent shafts and courts, without deduction for corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, the thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. The floor area of a building, or portion thereof, not provided with surrounding exterior walls shall be the usable area under the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above. The gross floor area shall not include shafts with no openings or interior courts.

Area, Building: The area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the building area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.

Floor Area, Net: The actual occupied area not including unoccupied accessory areas such as corridors, stairways, ramps, toilet rooms, mechanical rooms and closets.

The 2014 NYC Building Code further explicitly excludes wall thicknesses, columns, fixed cabinets, equipment and furred-in spaces. Other codes do not explicitly address these items in the definition of Net Floor Area.

NFPA 1 and NFPA 101 DEFINITION
Gross Floor Area: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the outside walls of the building under consideration with no deduction for hallways, stairs, closets, thickness of interior walls, columns, elevator and building services shafts, or other features, but excluding floor openings associated with atriums and communicating spaces.

Net Floor Area: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the outside walls, or the outside walls and fire walls of the building, or outside and/or inside walls that bound an occupancy or incidental use area requiring the occupant load to be calculated using net floor area under consideration with deductions for hallways, stairs, closets, thickness of interior walls, columns, or other features.

Both Gross and Net area is used for occupant load calculations depending the function of the space chosen in Table 1004.5. Although effectively the same, the Building Area used for allowable building area calculations found in Chapter 5 has a unique definition, "Area, Building", in Chapter 2.

Net floor areas are also used for specific items, such as minimum required areas of dwelling unit spaces, calculation of refuge areas for horizontal exits, and calculation of occupant load factors related to determining the Risk Category in Chapter 16 when gross areas would normally be required. Also, keep in mind that local zoning / planning floor area calculations, as well as height calculations may substantially differ from the building code.

children.body:
The refuge area into which a horizontal exit leads shall be provided with exits adequate to meet the occupant requirements of this chapter, but not including the added occupant load imposed by persons entering the refuge area through horizontal exits from other areas. Not less than one refuge area exit shall lead directly to the exterior or to an interior exit stairway or ramp.
Exception: The adjoining compartment shall not be required to have a stairway or door leading directly outside, provided that the refuge area into which a horizontal exit leads has stairways or doors leading directly outside and are so arranged that egress shall not require the occupants to return through the compartment from which egress originates.

The refuge area must be occupied by the same tenant or be a public area such as a hallway. The refuge area size must provide at least 3 sf of net floor area for each occupant and anticipated occupants from the horizontal exit. The number of exits required for the refuge area is based only on design occupant loads defined in section 1004 and does not need to include the anticipated occupant load from the adjoining compartment. In some jurisdictions, exceptions for Group I-3 occupancies exist that don't require a direct exit to a stair, presumably for security reasons.

children.body: Standpipes and standpipe hose connections shall be provided where required by Sections 905.3 and 905.4.

diagrams.title: Standpipes at Horiz. Exits and Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At horizontal exits the code requires a class I connection (FDC/Fire Department Connection) is provided on both sides of the wall regardless of the direction of egress through the horizontal exit opening. Because a horizontal exit cannot be the only exit and the code requires a class I connection at the main floor landing inside of required interior exit stairways there is an exception made for where the stairway FDC would be able to address the same area as the FDC at the horizontal exit. The FDC at the horizontal exit facing a required exit stairway may be omitted when all floor areas between the exits are reachable from the stairway FDC by a 30' hose stream from a 100' hose connected to the stairway FDC.

diagrams.title: Standpipe Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Standpipes, Types: - There are five types of standpipes - automatic dry, automatic wet, manual dry, manual wet, and semiautomatic dry. Automatic dry systems are pressurized with air, when a hose valve is opened, the air is released and the system fills with water. Automatic wet systems are filled with water at all times. Manual dry systems are not connected to a water supply, and must be supplied with water from the fire department. This is done via a fire department connection (FDC). Manual wet systems are filled with water, but require a supplemental fire department connection to meet required demand. Semiautomatic dry systems do not have water in them, but when a hose valve is opened, a remote switch opens the valve and allows water to fill the system.

diagrams.title: Standpipe System Classes
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standpipe Systems - There are three classification of standpipes:
  • Class I standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection and are intended for fire department use only.
  • Class II standpipes are equipped with a 1-1/2" hose and connection, and are intended primarily for building occupant use.
  • Class III standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection, reduced down to a 1-1/2" connected hose. These are intended for use by building occupants and fire department personnel.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairways and Ramps: When Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because there is potential for occupants to fall from exterior exit stairways and ramps the code limits when they may be used as a required part of the means of egress. Section 1027.2 limits their use to buildings that are either not a high rise and are less then 6 stories in height above grade plane. The section also does not allow for exterior exit stairs and ramps to be part of the required means of egress for group I-2 occupancies; exterior stairways and ramps could be a danger due to the physical and mental limitations some of the occupants.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection - Exception 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.
